The texture exhibited by sands, loamy sands, and sandy loams-except very fine, sandy loam. A soil containing large quantities of these textural classes.
The deteriorating chemical reaction of a metal with the fluids with which it is in contact.
A set of hydraulic lift cylinders that can be used to lift casing strings.

The ratio, either on a weight or on a molecular basis, of carbon-to-hydrogen in a hydrocarbon material. Materials with a high carbon/hydrogen ratio (e.g., coal) are solid. The ratio is useful as a preliminary indication of the hydrogen quantity needed to convert the hydrocarbon to a gas and/or liquid (AGA).
Any operation where a smaller tubing is inserted through a larger tubing string.  Normally done with the wellhead in place. Often done with the well under pressure.
Oilfield related cements.
Pressure in the annulus between the tubing O.D. and the casing I.D.
The control sections that sits above the basic wellhead.  It may contain hangers, master valves, annular valves, wing valves, and gauges or pressure, flow rate or monitoring measurement equipment.
Construction grade Portland cement.

A method of killing a well where the choke is adjusted to maintain a constant casing pressure as the a water kick rises in the annulus.  The method should not be used with a gas kick (will not keep a constant BHP).
A chemical substance or combination of substances that, when present in the environment, prevents or reduces corrosion (NACE).
Pipe tongs used to make connections.
A wireline set plug without a profile.  It is set in a coupling and grips with packer-like slips.
Several logs spliced or overlayed to form a single group log record.
Closed chamber DST.

Poorly sorted collection of sediments, generally formed in a very high energy environment. Similar to sandstones but have much larger grains (pebbles grade 4 to 64 mm).  The space between the grains may be partly or completely filled with sand grains.
The porosity exponent, m, in the Archie Factor.
Potential of a corroding surface in an electrolyte relative to a reference electrode under open-circuit conditions.
Central gas facility.
Larger particles of material made up of small, independent pieces.
Aggregate may refer to
The velocity of fluids flowing in the annulus.  Important in clean-up and displacement processes.
Appraisal (well)

One of three common goodness-of-fit metrics used when fitting probability distributions to data (the others being the chi-square and Kolmogorov-Smirinov), which places additional emphasis on the fit at the extreme values of the distribution.
In a seismic context, absorptance is the ratio of the energy absorbed by a formation in relationship to the total energy passing through it.
the initial nitrogen charge on a BOP accumulator that is placed before the fluid is pumped in to charge the accumulator.
A formation is called abnormally pressured, when its pore pressure is above or below the pressure dictated by the pressure gradient of hydrostatic column.
Radioactive decay process where the loss of an alpha particle from the nucleus lowers the atomic number by two and the atomic mass by four.
Attraction and adherence of clumps of small particles.
In a chemical context, accelerators are chemicals that speeds up the rate of a chemical reaction.  Most common are the accelerators used in cementing.
In a seismic context, an adsorption band is the range of wavelength energy that can be adsorbed by a given formation.
Use of a mineral acid (typically HCl or HCl/HF) or an organic acid (typically acetic or formic) to remove damage or stimulate the permeability of a formation.
An unconformity in which the beds below the unconformity dip at different angles than the beds above it.
Annular isolation sleeve.
The weak section of soft rock in the upper mantle just below the lithosphere. It is involved in plate movement. Depth is 70 to 100 km below the surface.
A large, load supporting formation that may serve to reduce the total overburden load on a pay zone.  These formations may cover hundreds of square miles over a basin.
Annular flow valve.
Annulus wing valve.
ALARP
A standard fluid leakoff test published by API.
A trailer or other vehicle, designed for soft ground, often used as the staging platform for fighting well fires.
A surfactant whose charge is dependent on another variable, normally pH.
Formations transported by fault or similar earth shift movements.
A very weak organic acid used for minor and shallow damage removal.  Also used as a moderately effective iron precipitation preventer. 4% acetic acid is vinegar.
-Another word for mean or arithmetic mean, obtained by summing N numbers and dividing by N.
Estimation/measurement of age of a formation, fossil, etc., in years before the present.
A piece of equipment that connects pipe, flanges or other equipment with different root threads or connection mechanisms.
Unusual data or measurement that is away from or out of the range of other data.
Process where a special resin exchanges chloride or hydroxide for contaminant anions such as fluoride, nitrate, sulfate and bicarbonate. Water purification is the primary use.
Trademarked name for an annular pressure response valve for a DST string.
In the context of bacteria, aerobic describes bacteria that require oxygen to survive and multiply.
Depositional environment of the deepest areas of the oceans.

The phase that may follow successful exploratory drilling. Activities to further evaluate the discovery, such as seismic acquisition, geological studies, and drilling additional wells may be conducted to reduce technical uncertainties and commercial contingencies.
A perforating process involving pumping a slurry of liquid and size particles through a nozzle to cut through steel and rock.

A soil with a preponderance of hydrogen ions, and probably aluminum, in proportion to hydroxyl ions. Specifically, soil with a pH value of less than 7.0; for most practical purposes, a soil with a pH value of less than 6.6.
The measure of a fluid's ability to resist flow without regards to its density. It is defined as a fluid's kinematic viscosity multiplied by its density.

An empirical relationship between the formation resistivity, F, and porosity,  φ, in which F=1/φm, where the porosity exponent or cementing factor, m, is a constant for a particular formation.  Typical m's are 1.8 to 2.0 for consolidated sandstones and 1.3 for poorly consolidated sandstones.
A tension or compression force, usually along the length of an object.
In a training context, ADP stands for accelerated development program.
A nonionic polymer (polyacrylamide) used in flocculation, clarifying and even gelling acids and other brines.  Very stable, but difficult to effectively break.

In vibration theory, the amplitude of a frequency is the difference between the maximum or minimum values of a sinusoidally varying quantity and its mean. A wave’s crest is its maximum amplitude, and the trough is its minimum amplitude.
A suspension of fine liquid droplets or solid particles in a gas.

In context of semivariogram models, admissibility is the condition in which the kriging variance is ≥0 for a given covariance model. Also known as positive definite. A semivariogram model is said to be admissible if it does not generate negative variances under any conditions.

The natural gas found in contact with or dissolved in crude oil in the reservoir. It may be free or dissolved. It can be further categorized as gas cap or solution gas. When it occurs as free gas, it may be called unassociated gas.

Injection of fluids down the annulus or Common as a gas supply path for gas lift.  Also used in some fracturing operations, to spot fluids downhole when no packer is used or a type of injection valve is in the tubing to allow entry of chemicals, gas or water.
Oxide coating of a metal surface to reduce corrosion.
A resin polymerized from one of several sources: acrylonitrile, acrylic acid, methacrylic acid, etc.
In the context of perforating, ablation debris are small pieces of rock broken up by the perforating process.

In the context of crack development, arrest marks are characteristic markings (ridges, tears, risers, etc.) on fracture surfaces after fatigue crack of fracture propagation (also known as beach marks, clamshell marks, and conchoidal marks).
A thread for tools and equipment that has three parallel threads per inch (similar to a BW thread). Used in applications of 1.75" OD thread or less.
In the context of facilities, absorption oil is the wash oil used to remove heavier hydrocarbons from the gas stream.
In the context of minerals, an area-to-volume ratio is the area of the surface of a grain to its physical volume.
A recommended practice published by the API.
Annular Pressure Buildup - sometimes also referred to as ACP - Annular Casing Pressure
A chemical, heat, radiation, or mechanical action that starts or accelerates a chemical reaction.
A copolymer.  Acrylamido-methyl-propane sulfonate polymer.
Any soil whose pH is greater than 7.0.
A secondary fault, often in a set, with opposite direction to the primary fault.

Additional wells drilled after a discovery, to confirm the size of a hydrocarbon deposit.  Normally used to run buildup tests, drill stem tests, top and bottom of formation, gather core or fluid samples or other evaluations.
A negatively charged surfactant.  Normally water wets sands.
A device with slips that holds equipment in the wellbore.
The maximum stress allowed by code or other agreement or study as a fraction of test pressure.  Design pressure of the system is related to hoop stress.
A high temperature seal elastomer.
Straight or branched chain hydrocarbons with single bonded carbon atoms.  Describes most oils.
In the context of processing, absorption is the ability of one material to absorb another.
Authorization for definition.
A pressure step-reduction choke that can be changed while actively flowing the well.
A stamp indicating that the item is manufactured to API specifications.
Advanced Geothermal Systems with closed-loop circulation of fluids for harvesting the heat (example: Eavor Loops, etc)
An adaptor that allows BOP's to be connected to wellhead flanges of various sizes.
Actual cubic feet per minute.
The weight of a string in air without the effect of buoyancy provided by wellbore fluids.
Annular safety valve.

Or "ADR", is a process (and associated costs) of returning part or all of a project to a safe and environmentally compliant condition when operations cease. Examples include, but are not limited to, the removal of surface facilities, wellbore plugging procedures, and environmental remediation. In some instances, there may be salvage value associated with the equipment removed from the project. ADR costs are presumed to be without consideration of any salvage value, unless presented as "ADR net of salvage".
The temperature of the surroundings, usually an average surface temperature or test surface temperature.
All terrain vehicle.
The closeness of agreement between the measure value and the exact value.
Assistant driller.
Any action designed to reduce or prevent fouling (deposits) on a surface.
Any produced gas, primarily H2, S, and CO2 that form an acid when produced in water.

Or Abandoning, Decomissioning, and Restoration, is a process (and associated costs) of returning part or all of a project to a safe and environmentally compliant condition when operations cease. Examples include, but are not limited to, the removal of surface facilities, wellbore plugging procedures, and environmental remediation. In some instances, there may be salvage value associated with the equipment removed from the project. ADR costs are presumed to be without consideration of any salvage value, unless presented as "ADR net of salvage".
In the context of processes, adiabatic is a process without exchange of heat with the surroundings.
The reading of gauge pressure plus the atmospheric pressure.
Annular circulation valve.
Annulus Isolation Valve
place where personnel spend their off-duty time on a rig.
In the context of expenses, AFE stands for Authority for Expenditure on a well (authorized funds for drilling or workover).
Polarization to a higher oxidizing potential to achieve a reduced corrosion rate (promotes passivity).
Formations below the deepest zones that can be imaged by an acoustic process.
Aluminum and potassium sulfate compound. Used in water clarifying.

One of several methods that provide pressure assistance to increase flow from a well. The most common systems lighten (decrease density) of the flowing fluid (gas lift), or remove all or part of the liquid head from the reservoir (beam and electric submersible pumps).
Without crystal form.
Preset value of a monitored parameter at which an alarm is actuated to warn of a condition that requires corrective action.
American National Standards Institute.
The unobstructed opening size diameter, length and width, or other shape factor.
A small hand level for leveling or measuring slope in percent or degrees.
Acceptance quality level.
A secondary fault, often in a set, with an opposite direction to the primary fault.
A method of allocating volumes to affected parties when an imbalance occurs.
Rocks or substances composed of clay minerals, less than 0.625mm, or having a high proportion of clay in their composition such as shale and slate.

The proportion of the bulk volume of soil that is filled with air at any given time or under a given condition, such as specified moisture tension. Usually the large pores, that is, those drained by a tension of less than approximately 100 em of water.
Approved permit to drill.
A reactive material with a low pH. Common oilfield mineral acids are HCl and HCl/HF.
A mud degasser chemical.
A pool in which the total oil or gas production is restricted and allocated to specific wells as defined in a proration agreement.

The near formation is irradiated with neutrons that transform some nuclei into radioisotopes. The isotopes produced can be detected by radioactivity energy levels and decay-time. The original elements can then be identified.
The area between the O.D. of an inside string and the I.D. of an outside string.

The geosciences, engineering, and associated studies, including economic analyses, conducted on a petroleum exploration, development, or producing project resulting in estimates of the quantities that can be recovered and sold and the associated cash flow under defined forward conditions. (Also called assessment.)
Forming larger droplets, bubbles, or particles from smaller droplets, bubbles, or particles.
Alaska well's group reporting system.
The change in pulsed neutron capture created by acidizing a carbonate.  Acidizing increases interconnected porosity and strands chlorides and other ions in the rock.

The ratio of the mass loss of actual corrosion of an anode to the theoretical corrosion mass loss calculated from the quantity of electricity that has passed between the anode and the cathode using Faraday's law (from NACE).
The relative density of a hydrocarbon based on a scale of degrees API.  Density in g/cc = (141 / (131 +API).
-Seismic source for ocean seismic work.
A component (e.g., bend stiffeners and buoyancy modules) used to control flexible pipe behavior.

Method used in resources estimation in the exploration and early development stages (including improved recovery projects) when direct measurement is limited. Based on evaluator's assessment of similarities of the analogous reservoir(s) together with the development plan.
Buoyancy device on a Spar.

In the context of logging, azimuth is a horizontal plane; it is the angle (measured clockwise) of well path departure usually from magnetic north. It may also be expressed as the compass direction of the path of the well bore as measured by a borehole survey. (Note:   check the specifics of the survey for the details).
The percent by weight loss of exposing a sample of material to an excess of acid.
American Chemical Society.
A steel with a microstructure consisting of austenite at room temperature.
The oldest terrain from the Cretaceous period.

Attractive forces between unlike molecules or compounds. Example: the attractive forces between water molecules and the walls of a clean glass tube are stronger than the cohesive forces, this leads to an upward turned contact or meniscus at the wall.
The theoretical maximum flow that a well could deliver with a zero back pressure at the middle of the perforations. Abbreviated AOFP.
A drill bit that, by its cutter placement, causes the bit to be forced against the side of the hole.

The process by which air in the soil is replaced by air from the atmosphere. In a well-aerated soil, the soil air is very similar in composition to the atmosphere above the soil. Poorly aerated soils usually contain a much higher percentage of carbon dioxide and a correspondingly lower percentage of oxygen than the atmosphere above the soil. The rate of aeration depends largely on the volume and continuity of pores within the soil.

In context of a pressure control device, accumulators are canisters of hydraulic fluid, pressurized with a nitrogen gas cap of sufficient pressure and volume to operate all the rams on a BOP in case of power failure to the BOP.
Detrital rock constituents and minerals derived elsewhere from older formations and redeposited.
Heat exchangers for cooling gas after compression.
A device that seals the annulus to pressure or flow.
A solid stick of chloro-acetic or sulfamic acid for small scale removal of acid soluble deposits.
In a subsea context, AHV abbreviates anchor handling vessel.
The action of particles forming adhering clumps on pipe.
The maximum rate that a well can produce at the lowest possible bottom hole pressure (usually figured with a gas gradient). Typically abbreviated as AOF.
In the context of fluid flow, AV is an abreviation for annular velocity.
American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
In the context of hydrate control, anti-agglomerants are chemicals which prevent hydrate crystals from sticking together and forming a larger mass.
The percentage of the total bulk volume that is pore spaces, voids or fractures.

The term allows for a single value to represent the sum of all the hydrocarbon products that are forecast as resources. Typically, condensate, oil, bitumen, and synthetic crude barrels are taken to be equal (1 bbl = 1 BOE). Gas and NGL quantities are converted to an oil equivalent based on a conversion factor that is recommended to be based on a nominal heating content or calorific value equivalent to a barrel of oil.
Ammonia based materials (NH3), in which one of more of the hydrogen atoms are replaced by hydrocarbons.
The attraction and holding of a layer of a chemical on the wall of a formation.  Usually held by ionic charge or wetting preference.
One acre (43560 ft2) to a depth of one foot.
Large, flat ocean floor, usually near a continent and usually over 4km (13100 ft) ss.
The volume a solid occupies when added to a fluid divided by its weight. m3/kg or gal/lb.
The valve on the side of the tree that controls access to the annulus.
A downhole safety valve that shuts off the annulus. Abbreviated ASV.
Straight or branched chain chemicals with some double bonds between carbons.

A comparable reservoir with many similar characteristics (e.g., lithology, depositional environment, porosity, perm, drive mechanism, produced fluids, etc.) that can be used for behavior projections comparison studies.
A filter rating that purports to set the maximum size of an opening in a filter or the maximum size of the particle that can pass through the filter. The definition varies with use and company.
As low as reasonably achievable.
Computation of a spatial covariance model for regionalized variable, measuring a change in variance (variogram) or correlation (correlogram) with distance and/or azimuth.
Absolute Open Flow.
Resistivity recording where the measured value differs from the true or defined state by the influence of the mud column, invasion of a zone by fluids, or wellbore anomalies.
A set or release mechanism where pickup or set down will release or set the tool.
The velocity of an imposed sound wave (acoustic velocity) through a rock times the density of the rock.
The total time required for an acoustic wave to travel through a substance.

Abiotic factors refer to all non-living physical components (temperature, pressure, pH, humidity, salinity, sunlight, etc.) and chemical or mineral features. These processes are integral to the generation of both natural gas and natural hydrogen in the subsurface.
Annular pressure relief valve.
A clay or other mineral that was formed within the pore spaces of the rock. The material is most often formed by reaction or precipitation from connate fluids.
Authorization for expenditure.
Sand particles, 0.625 to 2 mm on the Udden-Wentworth scale.
Pressure in an annular area.  May be a vented or trapped annuli.
All necessary approvals have been obtained, capital funds have been committed, and implementation of the development project is underway. A project maturity sub-class of Reserves.

The deviation angle (from vertical) at which a solid material will no longer fall down the pipe, but will begin to accumulate on the pipe wall.  The angle of repose for dry, round sand is about 62¼ and for wet sand about 50¼ to 60¼ depending on size, shape and moisture.
A colloidal, viscosity building clay used in water based muds. They generate viscosity due to the mechanical interference of their straw shaped bodies.
An investigation that focuses on aluminum content, an indirect measurement of clay content.
The production limit set on a specific well by a government regulatory body.  Rarely seen.
CaSO4 formation. Usually formed as an evaporite from a drying lake of trapped sea water.
American Institute of Professional Geologists.
Velocity of an imposed sound wave through a rock.
The unit of radioactivity used for natural gamma-ray logs.
A resin formed by reaction of polyhydric alcohols and polybasic salts. Saturated or unsaturated oils or fats are involved.
The flow area generated by perforations across a zone of interest. Typical calculated perforation entrance hole areas are 1% to 6% of the pipe body. Used in pressure drop calculations.
The collection of minerals that characterize a rock or facies.
-Differences in rock — segments showing different responses when measured.
To fill part or all of the pore spaces.
Oil and gas reservoir with a gas cap. Gas production from these reservoirs may be restricted in order to preserve the gas cap energy and ultimate recovery.
A material that can quickly destabilize foam in a production fluid treating facility.  Commonly needed after treatment with foamers, diesel, some polymers, some acids and gasified fluids.
American Society of Testing Materials.
Typically means to cease efforts, either temporarily or permanently, to produce a well. Abandon may have a legal meaning in some locations.
A form of financial option that allows the purchase on or before the exercise date.
Artificial lift.
A high grade coal.

The lowest temperature at which equal volumes of freshly distilled aniline and an oil are completely miscible. Aniline points are especially important when considering the possibility of running downhole tools with rubber parts exposed to oil based muds. If expected circulating bottom-hole temperature is greater than aniline point of exposed rubber part, then it is not advisable to run tools with such exposed rubber parts in that drilling scenario.
An eon of geologic time extending from about 3.9 billion to 2.5 billion years ago.
American Institute of Mining, Metallurgical and Petroleum Engineers.
NH4Cl.
A sandstone containing 25% or more of feldspars, usually derived from silicic igneous rocks.
A gas flow rate measurement device using Pitot tubes.  Common in pipelines.

Ring compound materials in the oil composed of carbon, hydrogen, sulfur, nickel and other trace materials. Asphaltenes are mostly very small platelets (35 A) suspended by micelles of maltenes and resins and carried through the oil.  They precipitate by agglomeration as the micelles break apart on shear, mixing with acids, or other interruption of the micelle stability. Also called asphaltene.

A convex-upward formation of rock layers a fold with the strata sloping down on the sides from a common crest. In association with a sealing rock, an anticline may form a trap for hydrocarbons.  Anticlines may be faulted or unfaulted. The majority of the hydrocarbons produced so far have been from anticlines.
See Gibbsite.
The positively charged site in a cell. Oxidation site. The site of metal loss in corrosion.
Metal that may corrode in either acids or alkalines.
To fracture stimulate a formation by injecting the acid over the parting pressure of the rock and using the acid to etch channels in the fracture face
Absolute open flow potential.
Acid corrosion inhibitor.  Slows the acid attack on metal.
Linear or ring compounds with a CO-NH2 attachment. Common in surfactants.
Arabian Gulf.
The raw, real time recording of the data, later formed into a digital or playback log.
Low ductility of a metal due to its adsorption of hydrogen. More commonly called hydrogen embrittlement.
The process of determining ownership of hydrocarbons delivered to the meter or LACT unit on a lease.
American Association of Drilling Engineers
Chemical analysis of the acid concentration and other chemical and physical measurements in the returning acid.
The clearance between the highest water surface that occurs during the extreme environmental conditions and the underside of the deck.
A substance that slows the reaction at the anode.
In a chemical context, aromatic describes members of a family of chemicals with a ring structure of carbon chains.  Normally xylene, toluene, etc. Benzene is an aromatic but is not used.

A somewhat amorphous clay mineral associated with soils which develop from volcanic ash deposits. They have a high and very pH dependent cation exchange capacity, and very high surface area to weight ratio.
The mechanism that provides pressure isolation between each casing hanger and the wellhead housing.
Drilling with air instead of drilling mud (requires diverters at the surface to handle cuttings and formation fluids).

The sum total of exchangeable anions that a soil can adsorb. In addition to predominantly negative charge sites which attract soil cations, all soil clays and organic matter simultaneously have a relatively small number of positive charge sites which retain anions in dynamic equilibrium with the soil solution. The number of anion negative charges retained by 100 grams of soil is called the anion exchange capacity. Expressed as milliequivalents per 100 grams of soil (or of other adsorbing material, such as clay).
An individual body of naturally occurring petroleum in a reservoir.
Wearing away by friction.
Annular friction pressure.
Water that is overpressured and may rise above the formation.

A theory of petroleum generation in which petroleum is thought to have formed from hydrocarbons trapped inside the earth's crust when the earth was forming. See also Biogenic theory and Organic theory.
American Petroleum Institute.
In context of corrosion, a corrosion state where a metal is corroding without control by a reaction product (or corrosion product layer).
Also known as - Available moisture capacity
Advanced technology parts.
A reverse cracking process that convents hydrocarbon light ends (olefins) into longer chain, liquid fuels.

Zero point on the absolute temperature scale; equal to -273.16 degrees C, or 0 degrees K (Kelvin), or -459.69 degrees F, or 0 degrees R (Rankine). This is the point at which there is no energy (i.e., no molecular movement).
A vertical, cylindrical vessel that recovers heavier (longer carbon chain) hydrocarbons from a mixture of lighter hydrocarbons.

Land counterpart of a river delta. Characteristic of sediments that have been transported by a fast moving stream then dropped out of the flow as the stream velocity drops as it spreads out. Typical of zones of heavy water runoff such as found at the base of mountains in arid and semi arid climates where flash floods may be seen. Often poorly sorted with pebble to boulder sized sediments. Weak cementing typical.
A precision sized micron particle material used for testing the solids stopping capability of filters.

American Association of State Highway Officials 
http://www.transportation.org/
Dry, without water.
Permeability to a single phase fluid in a cleaned core.
The minimum pressure of the reservoir when the wells are abandoned.
Algerian.
Particles propelled at a velocity sufficient to cause cleaning or wearing away of a surface.
Shielding over a cable or other device that needs to be protected from crushing.

An elastomer bag or donut type seal, pushed into contact with the pipe or tools in the blow out preventer (BOP).  It is designed to seal around pipe or any other irregular surface tool (packers, guns, pumps, etc.) that may be in the BOP, including itself if the wellbore is empty. May also be called a Hydril preventer.
In a subsea context, an AUV is an autonomous underwater vehicle.
Using the annulus as the flow path.
Large scale injection of pH>7 fluids.  The basic materials may react with oils to form reactants that can reduce viscosity or affect wetting.
Formations that formed in the present locations and have not been transported.
Australian Institute of Petroleum.
Siliceous rock with alternating bands of chalcedony and colored chert.
Nonaromatic (chemical).
Temperature measurement starting at absolute zero (total absence of heat).
American Gas Association.
In the context of risk, abject failure is a failure mode that can cause the cancellation of or immediate halt to a project or event. Generally expressed as a percent probability.
Land leased for drilling exploration.
A compound incorporated into a gas, liquid, or solid system to alter the properties for a particular purpose.
The viscosity at a given shear rate and a given temperature.
A surface piston driven pumping unit, similar to a beam lift unit.
When a form of energy is propagated through a medium, its amplitude (energy level) is decreased. This decrease is termed attenuation.
Costs associated with the abandonment of facilities or services, including costs for the removal of facilities and restoration of the land.
In the context of wells, an area of influence is the area surrounding a well within which drawdown and production has changed the saturation and energy of the system.
The initial wave of gravel transport when packing a well with a deviation over 55o.
A strongly basic solution.
Standard density of dry air, free of CO2 at 0 degrees C is 1.292 g/L. At standard temperature and pressure, air density is 0.0763 lb/ft3.

A sonic travel time record of a formation using a tool with an emitter and a detector. Measures porosity and is useful to compare to other porosity longs to estimate pore filling.  Also used to generate rock strength evaluations.
Asphaltene.
The amount of unused pull capacity of a rig after picking up the entire string weight.
In the context of depth, AHD stands for along hole depth or measured depth.
A patented screen design that allows gravel packing slurry to flow past an annular bridge point that would normally stop the placement of gravel.
Anaerobic.
In the context of perforating, an anvil is the strike plate over a TCP, drop-bar firing system.
Christmas tree.  Typically abbreviated as XT.
X-ray diffraction analysis.
Ultra-high pressure high temperature.
XN (nipple) locator.
Xanvis™ is a brand name modified Xanthan polymer.
Crossover.
A standard profile.  Can accept a plug or other tools.
X profile with a no-go or no-go ledge for selling a no-go sleeve.
Crossover.
XCD™ is a brand name biopolymer.
Cross linked gel.
Xanthan™ is a name brand biopolymer.
Exxon Mobil.
Plants that grow in or on extremely dry soils or soil materials.
Christmas tree.
Shut down valve.
A fishing tool that is designed to enter an opening of a fish and grip the ID.
The ratio of the density of a substance to the density of a comparison material, usually at a specific temperature and pressure.
A joint above a piece of equipment that is designed to fail and allow recovery of the upper string.
Shear stress over angle of deformation.
A log that measures the sonic amplitude of a formation to a sound wave. The log is used to locate fractures.
In the context of pipe running, stripping is holding back on a pipe as it is run into the well.

An exploration technique that can find structures and potential reservoir traps by reflecting sound waves from the rock strata. [Seismic acquisition (2-D, 3-D, 4-D) – seismic data are used to map subsurface formations. A 2-D survey reveals a cross section of the subsurface. In a 3-D survey, seismic data are collected in the inline and crossline directions to create a three-dimensional image of the subsurface. In a 4-D or time-lapse 3-D survey, 3-D surveys are repeated over time to track fluid movement in the reservoir. (from Baker Hughes).
The unconsolidated mineral material on the immediate surface of the earth serving as natural medium for the growth of land plants.
A production treating vessel designed to facilitate the separation of gas, oil, and/or water from a produced fluid stream.
A wellbore caliper, useful in larger wellbores and washouts that uses sound through thin liquids to map the wellbore.
A shaped explosive charge for perforating steel pipe.
A seal bore receptacle below the packer. Used where a longer seal assembly is needed.
The elastomer element that completes the seal in a stripper unit.
The casing string that protects the fresh water supply.  It is always cemented across the water zone and usually extends to surface.
Solids production test accomplished by taking samples of the produced fluids and centrifuging to separate the solids.
In the context of logging, Sxo is water saturation of the flushed zone.
In the context of subsea, STG is a seal test gauge.
The pressure at a datum when the well is not flowing.  The shut in pressure is usually either surface shut-in pressure or bottom hole shut-in pressure.
A blade type centralizer, usually mounted at the connection, which holds the screen off the casing wall to assist in gravel packing and flow.
A wireline set plug with slips and seals much like a small packer.
Statement of requirements.
In the context of a milling tool, a split skirt is a slot in a mill or other tool to assist with alignment, cleaning, or entry.
In the context of logging, Swcor is corrected water saturation of the uninvaded zone.

A measure of spatial dependence (dissimilarity or increasing variability) of a regionalized variable over some distance. The semivariogram also can be calculated with an azimuthal preference. The semivariogram commonly is called the variogram. See also Correlogram .
A sand control method where the sand is held in place with closure pressure, resin or other methods and no screen is run.

Water saturation.S Wave:  secondary wave, shear wave, transverse wave. A seismic body wave that involves particle motion from side to side, perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation.  S-waves are slower than P-waves and cannot travel through liquid.  Typically shown as Sw.
A test of the cement seal at the shoe.
Free grains of sand pulled loose by flow, brittle failure, or formation disaggregation and produced with the hydrocarbon production.
Standard cubic foot per minute.

A shear-wave mode that has its particle-displacement vector oriented in the vertical plane passing through the source and receiver stations.  An SV displacement vector is orthogonal to an SH displacement vector.  See SH.
Sub surface (or subsea) isolation valve.  Often placed in offshore pipelines within a few hundred meters of the facility to give an emergency stop point in the event of a line rupture or fire.
One of several mineral precipitates that crystallize out of waters at or above the saturation of the ions.
Controlled heating of material to predetermined temperature for the purpose of reducing any residual stresses.
Also referred to as Stress Corrosion, this occurs in metal that is subject to both stress and a corrosive environment.  May start at a "stress riser" like a wrench mark or packer slip mark.
The cost of a piece of equipment or a crew to wait when a job is postpones.
An Alternate Path™ for gravel packing slurry that routes the flow around a well bore bridge out during gravel packing.

The variable, usually interrelated, natural agencies that are active in and responsible for the formation of soil. The factors are usually grouped into five major categories parent rock, climate, organisms, topography, and time.

The water level in a well which is in equilibrium with the groundwater flow conditions of the aquifer at the well; that is, when no water is being, or recently has been, taken from the aquifer either by pumping or by free flow. It is generally expressed as the distance from the ground surface (or from measuring a point near the ground surface) to the water level in the well; also, static head.
A group of defined and named taxonomic soil units which typically occur together in a characteristic pattern over a geographic region.
In the context of logging, Swa is water saturation of the univaded zone.
In the context of drilling, steerable motor is a downhole drilling motor with a bent housing that can turn a well's direction in addition to turning the bit.
In value of information problems, the various possible outcomes one is trying to assess.
A section in a downhole tool string than can be actuated by ball or pressure to allow recovery of the pipe string if the tool is stuck.
A smaller well.  Thought to be cheaper to drill, but much more expensive to repair or workover and often limited on fluid flow rate potential.
The solution separated from a soil suspension or from a soil filtration, centrifugation, suction, or pressure. (May or may not be heated before separation.)
A low area, usually the area below the perfs.
In the context of cementing, a stage tool is an alternate path device that allows access into the annulus when shifted.  Used in two stage cementing operations to pump the upper job.

Tukey's method of visualizing data: the stem is an ordered column of the numbers formed by truncating the data by one or two digits, while the leaves are the truncated digits, lined up to the right of their number.
A chemical that prevents scale from forming in scale mineral saturated produced waters.
The pressure on the tubing when the well is shut-in.
Sulfate reducing bacteria.
A profile design that can be used at several places in the same string.  A plug must pass through the profile and be pulled back into the profile to set.
Stress sulfide cracking. Occurs when metal is in tension and exposed to H2S and water. Generates atomic hydrogen.  Hydrogen moves between grains of the metal.  Reduces metal ductility.
A rig supported by attached pontoons.
Shut in drill pipe pressure.
A crystalline metamorphic rock that can be split into think layers because of the bedded mineral arrangements.

A short section with external seals on the end of tubing to stab into a polished bore receptacle and achieve a seal.  The seal assembly may be allowed move in the PBR when tubing temperature and/or pressure changes.
Stock tank barrel.
The weight of a volume per unit of volume.
BOP.
A packer whose seal elements swell in a hydrocarbon, establishing a seal between packer body and casing.
See Slick Line.
A tertiary oil recovery method involving injection of steam into the reservoir to reduce the oil viscosity.

“Shock” waves from an event (explosive, tectonic, impact, etc.) that travel through the earth and reflect off of subsurface structures (rocks) in the same manner as sound echos and water waves and ripples.
A product that chemically dissolves scale.
The pressure at which the separator is operated.  This pressure is a direct backpressure on the well.
A stable system returns to its former position after the removal of the force that disturbed the system. In pipe work, stability is involved with buckling, bending, and straightness of the pipe.
Temporarily discontinue operations.
Dip meter results.

A sonic log measures the interval travel time (delta t) of compression sound waves moving through one foot of a formation (milliseconds/ft). If matrix velocity is known, porosity can be calculated since sound waves travel slower in porous media (travel slower in less dense materials such as fluids).  Sonic logs are used for porosity determination, pressure determination in shale, as a correlation log, and a gas detector.
A substance that will dissolve a solid.  In the oil field, oil based solvents may range from xylene for asphaltenes and sludges, to kerosene and diesel/xylene mixtures for paraffins.
e = delta L / L.
In the context of an elastomer, SBR is a copolymer of stryene and butadiene.
The weight reading when the pipe is entering the well.  Compared to the pick-up weight to estimate the friction.
Small areas in a field that are slick when wet, as a result of a high content of alkali or of exchangeable sodium.
A tubular joint that allows tubing movement.
A record of rock cuttings (and some properties) that is made as the rock is being drilled.
A type of bacteria that forms a slick surface.

-In the context of well control, a stinger is a hollow, tapered rod hooked to the boom of an oil fire fighting crane.  Mud can be pumped through the stinger once it has been stabbed into the remains of a wellhead.
A geologic period of time between 40 and 425 million years ago.
Stimplan™ is a trademarked fracturing design simulator from NSI, Inc.
A downhole safety valve designed to close when the flow rate reaches a preset level as measured by a pressure drop across a valve.
Mineral particles less than 2 mm in equivalent diameter and ranging between specified size limits. The names and sizes (in mm) of separates recognized in the U.S. are as follows
A downhole tool that is used to create a sudden pressure decrease at a spot in the well.
Static bottom hole pressure. May also be called shut-in bottom hole pressure.
Extraneous electrical current in earth. Point of arrival is cathode - departure point is anode.
Short radius drilling.
In the context of drilling, space out joint is the joint of drill pipe used to prevent a tool joint from being in the BOP body (across a ram face).
Gravel packing with a gel.
A set of rocks that are bent downward.
A repeating shape like a sine wave.  May be applied to pipe buckling.
-In the context of completions, a shot hole is a wellbore where an explosive such as nitroglycerin has been exploded.
A well beyond the current boundaries of a known field.

one of various methods of consolidating the grains of an unconsolidated or weakly consolidated formation. Typically resin consolidation (epoxy, furan or phenol-formaldehyde), but may also include sodium silicate, coking, and mineral or metal precipitates.
Use a sonic depth measurement device to find the fluid level in a well.
Gamma ray tool which splits the spectral range into three parts:   uranium, potassium, and thorium.

In the context of seismic, structural model is 2D or 2-1/2D, a gravity or magnetic structural model is a density and/or susceptibility model of given or assumed geology in a system. The modeling can be to represent lithologic layers as equi-density and/or equi-susceptability layers or blocks. The layers are contrast boundaries.   Best fit where high contrasts exist in nature.
-In the context of drilling, SPM is strokes per minute.  A count of pump strokes times pump volume times plunger # times pump efficiency estimates volume pumped.

A shear wave.  It is sometimes called a secondary (S) wave because it arrives later than the primary wave (see P wave).  The term S wave needs to be used carefully because there are several types of shear waves.  S waves include SH and SV modes and, in a complex anisotropic Earth, each of these modes (SH and SV) divides into a fast and slow component.  Converted SV waves (called C waves) that result when P waves arrive at interfaces at nonnormal angles of incidence are another type of S wave.  The term "S wave" spans a large family of distinct wave types.
Sustained casing pressure.
A process to rank the inputs to a model in terms of their impact on a given output.
A device that directs fluids across a downhole pump motor for cooling or directs gas away from the liquid intake.
Gas saturation.  Typically shown as Sg.
A device using an elastomer seal (and sometime oil or grease injection) that provides a pressure barrier around a moving tubular or wireline.
A depositional surface associated with a fixed geologic time.  Geologic time is constant along a stratal surface, but the rock types above and below the surface can vary.
The derating factor applied to a pressure test limit or weight limit to set a maximum operating load condition.
A downhole screen designed to stop sand production before the flow enters the pump or tubing.
A vertical section of the soil extending through all its horizons and into the parent material.
The seal at the top of the BOP around coiled tubing or pipe during snubbing.
Synthetic oil based mud.
Stock tank cubic meter.  Typically shown as StM3.
Removing H2S from a hydrocarbon stream.
A clamp for flush joint pipe. Also any clamp for securing pipe above the rotary table, even when the slips are set.
SCRAMS™ is a tradmarked surface controlled reservoir analysis and management system.
A subsea well.

Reducing the well pressure below the swab tool by rapid upward movement of a tool or equipment in a wellbore.  Swabbing may be intentional using a wireline swab cup tool to lift water or unintentional by fast movement of a pipe or wireline conveyed, large diameter tool such as a packer.

A hollow carrier perforating gun with relief ports drilled part way through the gun body to provide an exit point for the perforation charge and to provide a recess to minimize damage from the burr that forms around the exit hole in the perforating gun.
The exponent, n, in the water saturation term in the equation that relates resistivity to water saturation.
In the context of subsea, SHR is a subsea hybrid riser.
In the context of a PDM motor, a stator is the stationary rubber element of a PDM motor.
In the context of subsea, STV is a seal test valve.
Removal of part of sea bed by current, storm or ice.
Stock tank oil-initially-in-place
Subsea test tree.
The pipe in the derrick that delivers mud to the kelly hose.
A sand restraining device that is a mesh or wire wrapped screen wound over a base pipe with holes.
Supervisory Control And Data Acquisition, a data gathering system.
A device that cuts through paraffin, asphaltenes, etc. inside the pipe.  Run on wireline.
Synthetically prepared natural gas.

Models that represent the first or second order in modeling assumptions. First-order changes represent changes to the input, data, structural model, or stratigraphic model. Second-order changes represent changes to the modeling parameters, such as the variogram sill, range, or random function.
Storage of fluids in a chamber mined or leached out of a salt deposit.
The rock in which hydrocarbons form.
An external or internal crack in steel or other material caused by the environment and/or the loads on the material.
Spectral gamma ray tool.
A fault that effectively seals a compartment.
Vertical to horizontal direction change in <40 ft vertical travel (approximately 2.2o per foot).
The total cost for a rig, crews and all equipment that goes with operation of the rig for that job.
The succession and age relationship of layered rocks.
A joint above a piece of equipment that is designed to fail and allow recovery of the upper string.

The mixture of soil and water which occurs when all soil pores are just filled with water. In undersaturated soil, deionized water is added to a soil sample with minimal mixing until all soil pores are filled with water and there is negligible air in the pores. Mixing is minimized to retain natural pore size distribution as much as possible and to minimize expansion of expandable clay minerals such as smectite and vermiculite. The percent of soil-pore water weight to dry soil weight at this precise moisture content is called the saturation percentage, and this is unique for each different soil due to different types, sizes, and shapes of solid constituents. The saturated paste moisture content is useful as a reference because it represents the actual concentrations and ratios of dissolved constituents which are available for uptake by plant roots.
Allowing a solvent to be in contact with a deposit for a period of time.
Can be either an immature oil phase, often called Kerogen, or actual oil in the crocks of pores of a shale.
Standard workover procedure.

A number that specifies how many seismic field traces are summed to create a final image trace in a 3D seismic volume.  A stacking fold of 20 means that 20 field traces were summed to create one stacked trace.
Oil formed by a chemical process that converts coal or shale to liquids.
A well that is used for purposes other than production.
See Spontaneous Potential Log or SP.
See Sodium adsorption ratio.
A relative number for evaluating the length of slope in the soil-loss equation.
A salt with a range of sized designed to achieve a low permeability filter cake.
Elevating the near wellbore pressure of a formation through leak-off of wellbore fluids during drilling, completion or workover.
Schlumberger.
A dimensionless estimation of obstruction to flow. An undamaged well would have a skin of zero. A damaged well has a positive skin above zero and a stimulated well has a negative skin.
Used for treating cement contamination and calcium contamination in muds.
An injection test, plotted pressure against injection rate, where a curve deflection and change of slope indicates the fracture breakdown pressure.
A soil that contains an exchangeable sodium percentage (ESP) of 15% or more.
See ESP.
Gel or harden as in cement.
-In the context of perforating, shootoff is a comparison of shaped charge performance in surface targets.
In the context of fluid treating, separations are processes related to separation of gas, water and hydrocarbons.
A map that uses contours to show the ratio of sand to shale in a formation. Useful for determining clean sand trends and permeability channels.
Deposit made up of pieces of other rocks.
In the context of casing, a shoe is the end of the casing, usually called a guide shoe than helps insert the casing through the drilled hole.
Seal-Tite™ is a trademarked name of a leak stopping material.
Scanning electron microscope.
To remove a segment of wireline by pulling wire through the system from the reel, removing the wire that is worn or heavily used in normal operation of the wireline system.

Breaking of compact subsoils, without inverting them, with a special knifelike instrument (chisel) that is pulled through the soil at depths usually of 12 to 24 inches with spacings usually of 2 to 5 ft.
The tendency of proppants to segregate in the fluids due to density effects when the fluid velocities drop below turbulence.
An impact or pressure load that shears the pin in a downhole tool and allows another tool function.
The line from the derrickman’s platform to the ground, used in an emergency.  Also called a Geronimo line.
A diagram using contour lines to connect the elevation of similar depth points in a formation.
In the context of drilling, a stationary block is the crown block on a drilling rig.
The difference in potential between the earth and the well. Measured and minimized before explosive operations may proceed. Also a measure of corrosion potential.

Self-excited vibrations occur when the forcing function is a function of the displacement, velocity, or acceleration of the system mass. If the energy gained from the self-excited vibrations is more than the system can absorb, the system will self-destruct.
A nonsodic soil containing sufficient soluble salts to impair its productivity. The conductivity of the saturation extract is greater than 4 mmhos/cm (at 25•C) and the pH is usually less than 8.3.

A kriging method in which the global mean is constant over the entire area of interpolation and is based on all the control points used in a unique neighborhood (or in which the mean is supplied by the user).
Shear out sub.
bbl – the measurement of a barrel (42 gal) of oil originated by Standard Oil Company (their “standard” barrel was pained blue).

A seismic wave that trends along an interface, particularly along the Earth/air interface.  Surface waves do not enter the body of the Earth and image deep targets.  See ground roll, Love wave, and Rayleigh wave.
A pipe section, usually on the bottom of a BHA that is a straight pipe.
A ram in the BOP that shears off the pipe.
A downhole device that isolates a zone, a wellbore or a piece of equipment.
Rock salt or granulated salt sized to construct a filter cake to control fluid loss.

A displacement.  In the reservoir a sweep is displacement of a hydrocarbon fluid from a reservoir rock by a flooding fluid.  In the wellbore, a sweep is a viscous pill circulated around to help clear the wellbore of cuttings or debris.
Using a jet of air or water to stir the contents of a tank.
SAM™ is a trademarked sensor activated module.
A dry acid derivative of sulfuric which is used in very minor acid jobs in the form of acid sticks dropped into the well.
Compaction of a zone (vertical height shrinkage) created by compaction of the matrix after some load supporting fluids have been produced.
A millable retainer for squeeze cementing.
Removal of components (gas, liquids or solids) from the methane achieved by surface equipment (scrubbers).
A collection of values associated with a sample, such as mean or standard devi-ation. Also called descriptive statistics. The formal study of such values.
In the context of perforating, spf is shots per foot.
The fixed position valve at the bottom of a beam lift pump.
A combination of a formation structure feature such as a fault with a sealing mechanism that forms a place where oil accumulates or is “trapped”.
Location of initial seismic signal.
Prediction of where in the wellbore that scale minerals are oversaturated in solution and could form scale.  Not necessarily where scale will form.
In the context of drilling, stabilizers are near gauge diameter joints that stabilize the drilling BHA.

A gulf, basin or sea surrounded by two or more States and connected to another sea or the ocean by a narrow outlet or consisting entirely or primarily of the territorial seas and exclusive economic zones of two or more coastal States. PDF
The braided line on a rig, normally used for lifting and deploying tools. May also be used in some instances downhole.
A pin in a tool (brass, steel or aluminum) that is designed to shear or break at a certain pressure that enables a tool function.
Screen only completion.
A surface on a downhole tool on which an upper tool or piece of equipment will stop.
A well servicing unit that consists of but one steel tube.
A weight stem on a wireline tool assembly.
A perforating gun where the charges are mounted on the strip.  The strip is recovered after firing.
A classification of materials that predicts satisfactory performance in hydrogen sulfide.
A term used interchangeably with Conditional simulation , although not all stochastic-modeling applications use control data.
A visually apparent oil layer on water.  Depending on the hydrocarbon type, sheens can develop with as little as 50 to 100 ppm.

An electronic “Wheatstone-type bridge” element than may form the measurement basis for a load cell or other strain measurement application. The device measures changes in electrical resistance produced by changes in load.
Metamorphic shale rock with fractures or cleavage planes.
Rock fragments greater than 10 inches in diameter, if rounded, and 15 inches along the greater axis, if flat.

The uppermost part of the soil, ordinarily moved tillage, or its equivalent in uncultivated soils; it ranges in depth from 3 to 4 inches to 8 or 10 inches. Frequently designated as the plow layer, the Ap layer, or the Ap horizon.
Standard cubic meter.  Typically displayed as Sm3.
Stock tank oil.
A particle movement method where the particle is carried in a series of short hops along a flow path.

Surfactants that exhibit an effect on water or oil by changing fluid properties at the interface of the fluid.  May be emulsifiers, demulsifiers, surface tension lowering , flocculants, deflocculants, wetting agents, etc.
A reaction of an elastomer seal by absorbing gas or a liquid and increasing its volume.  May or may not be detrimental.
A twin sealing element device with a perforated nipple in between.  It is used to selectively inject fluids into a part of the zone.
Also known as: Soil hydraulic conductivity
Spill response team.
The clearance from casing to the tool face.
Sacks.
A surface vessel in the production line with the specific task or capturing sand before the production goes through a point where the sand may damage equipment.
-In the context of alternates, SCR is a steel catenary riser.
An adjacent field to larger, host, field facilities.
Attached masses of bacterial colonies.
-In the context of flow, surging is opening the well to flow against a significantly underbalanced fluid column.  A perf cleaning technique.
Absence of hydrogen sulfide, H2S.

The upper part of a soil profile, above the C horizon, in which the processes of soil formation are active. The solum in soil consists of the A, E, and B horizons. Generally, the characteristics of the material in these horizons are unlike those of the underlying material. The living roots and plant and animal activities are largely confined to the solum.
In the context of drilling, swivel is the connection between the traveling block and the hook that allows torque release and rotation.
The chipping, fragmentation, separation or disbonding of a surface in response to pressure,  mechanical or chemical influence.
Placement of a scale inhibitor chemical by injecting it into the formation.  The material may absorb, adsorb, or precipitate.
S wave.
(BP) Single point of accountability.
A map showing the distribution of soil types or other soil-mapping units in relation to the prominent physical and cultural features of the earth's surface.
Sodium Carbonate.
A shallow bevel or angle that is not steep.
A term usually referring to a logging instrument.
A marginal productivity well, usually less than about 10 barrels per day in onshore US fields.

Spherically focused resistivity log. Measures the resistivity of the flushed zone (Rxo). In a hydrocarbon zone, the curve may report higher resistivity than deep (ILD) or medium (ILM) induction curves because the flushed zone contains mud filtrate and residual hydrocarbons.
Static spontaneous potential.
A depression in the ground at surface caused by collapse of a cave roof.
A reservoir capable of holding fluids created by decreases in porosity, permeability or disappearance of the reservoir.
A machined profile in a heavy wall short tubing section that allows a plug to be set and the seal on the plug to effectively isolate the well.
A tectonically induced failure of a section of a formation with the result that one block of the formation moves horizontally to the formation.
Common measure of ocean wave conditions, approximately equal to the average of the highest one-third of the waves.
Subsea, umbilicals, riser, flowline.
A spacer designed to pick up and transport particles from the well.
A collection of objects or numbers drawn from a population. Often, a sample is the set of empirical data that we analyze, hoping to infer statistical properties of the population.
The amount to which a reservoir barrel of oil shrinks when gases are removed at surface. Reciprocal of the formation volume factor.

A program starting with data aquisition and analysis utilized to assess the current state of the reservoir, indications of formation damage, zonal and hydrocarbon voidage and the pressures within the completed horizons and blocks, the likely location of various reservoir fluids and fluid contacts, inter-well connectivity and the source and cause of any undersirable fluid influx. The collection of data allows for optimal decision making for specific situations and assists in determining the remaining value.
A loading at a diagonal to the structure.
In deliverability testing, stabilization time is defined as the time when the flowing pressure is no longer changing or is no longer changing significantly.
The aqueous liquid phase of the soil and its solutes that consists of ions dissociated from the surface of the soil particles and of other materials.
A pressure dissolution feature in a layered reservoir, often a vertical permeability barrier.
In the context of brine, salt is specifically sodium chloride, but also may be a generic term for most water soluble salts.
The solution gas-oil ratio (GOR) of the oil as it resides in the reservoir.
Move a well to a close-by locations with minimum rig down of equipment.
A chemical that converts an acid insoluble scale to a acid soluble material.
Shut-in well head pressure.

A shallow zone of (usually) higher strength surrounding a perforation, cavity or the bore hole, caused by explosive effects or other pressure factors and possibly related to the mechanics of work hardening.
Run casing and cement.  General temp that means to start the completion on a well.
Conductor casing string.
A solids separation piece of equipment on a drilling rig that uses vibrating screens to remove solids from the returning mud.
A set of pipe seal and blind rams used in the snubbing operation.
A well path that starts vertical, then is deviated to reach a target before being turned near vertical again to drop through the pay zone.
See Formation Damage.
A downhole piece of equipment in a tubing string that allows flow from annulus to tubing.  Usually opened and closed by wireline.
A surface vessel where solids are allowed to settle out of a produced or circulated fluid stream.

A common sedimentary rock with porosity but little matrix permeability.  Shales are one of the petroleum source rocks. Shales usually consist of particles finer than sand grade (less than 0.0625 mm) and include both silt and clay grade material.
A shale, usually in the wellbore, that increases size (swells) or casts of particles by reacting with brine or water.
A market for short term transactions of specific volumes of product without a long term commitment.
A mixture of a liquid and solids.
A string or solid or hollow tubular that is moved by a pump jack at the surface to operate a rod pump at the bottom of the well.
A slickline tool used to place or remove sand or similar small grains from a wellbore.
A centralizer with a rigid, solid body with straight or curved veins that hold the pipe off the wall and allow flow.  Used in deviated wells and with heavy pipe strings.
The minimum shear stress that will produce permanent deformation of the fluid (gel breaking).
The distance from the tool to the wall of the hole.
Sulfur Oxides.
The heat required to raise one unit mass of a substance by one degree.

Temporarily shut in and re-open well.  Shut-in forces free gas into solution and some liquid back into the formation.  Opening the well allows gas to breakout of liquids and the formation and lift liquids.

A measure of the acidity or alkalinity of a soil expressed in pH values. A soil that tests to pH 7.0 is described as precisely neutral in reaction because it is neither acid nor alkaline. The degrees of acidity and alkalinity (expressed as pH values) are as follows

The relative proportions of sand, silt, and clay particles in a mass of soil. The basic textural classes, in order of increasing proportion of fine particles, are sand, loamy sand, sandy loam, loam, silt loam, silt, sandy clay loam, clay loam, silty clay loam, sandy clay, silty clay, and clay. The sand, loamy sand, and sandy loam classes may be further divided by specifying "coarse," "fine," or "very fine."
A cementing repair technique involving injecting cementing under pressure to fill channels in the primary cementing treatment.
Pulling tubing and stand back in the vertical racks on the rig.

The smallest definable area within a 3D seismic image space.  The number of stacking bins in a 3D seismic volume is the same as the number of seismic traces in that volume.  At the conclusion of 3D data processing, one image trace passes vertically through the center of each stacking bin.  The lateral dimension of a stacking bin is the same as the spacing between adjacent traces in the 3D volume.
A downhole safety valve designed to shut the well in case of surface damage to the wellhead.  Typically abbreviated as SSSV.
Steam assisted gravity drainage.
Cuttings or returning fluids with a hydrocarbon content above normal background level.
A bearing that allows the walking beam to move atop the Sampson post in a beam lift pump.

A measurement of the difficulty of moving a fluid past another fluid (see interfacial tension).  The resistance is created by the cohesion forces between the liquid molecules. The forces make it more difficult to pass fluids past a surface. Surface tension is measured in dyne/cm.  Untreated water is 72.8 dynes/cm at 20oC. Ethyl Alcohol is 22.3 and mercury is 465.
Technically, the B horizon;roughly, the part of the solum below plow depth.
A chain moved by a counterweight or winch to assist in making up drill pipe joints.
Various. Generally used in describing a surface or subsurface safety valve.
The percentage of original oil in place displaced from a formation by a flooding fluid.
Salt water disposal.
In the context of cement, a sack is 94 lbs of dry cement.
Most simply put, the condition in which the data do not exhibit a trend. This implies that a moving-window average shows homogeneity in the mean and variance over the study area.

Wedge-shaped devices (usually containing steel teeth) that hold the pipe. Capable of suspending heavy pipe string loads. Drill collar slips are different in appearance from drill pipe slips. Drill collar slips have multiple hinged wedges (10 or more segments) to better grip heavy drill collars.
The pressure when the well is not flowing. Can be surface static pressure or bottom hole static pressure.
Plugged by scale.
Irreducible water saturation.  Typically shown as Swirr.
In the context of production, sand free rate is the maximum production flow rate that a weakly consolidated pay zone will produce without producing sand.
The act of threading the drilling line through the pulleys or sheaves of the traveling block and the crown block. One line is connected to the derrick and the other to the winch or hoisting drum.
Where two phases travel in the same direction but at different velocities.
The empirical mathematical expression developed as an index of the sodium hazard in soils. The concentrations of sodium, calcium, and magnesium are expressed in meq/L
Ataya, Z. M. 2008. New Technique for Addressing SIMOPS Challenges During Installation of New Offshore Platform. Society of Petroleum Engineers. http://dx.doi.org/doi:10.2118/120796-MS
Water with low calcium and magnesium content.
A mechanical jar, used commonly on wireline.
In the context of cementing, sugar water is a contaminate water that will prevent cement slurry from setting.
The compass direction of a feature such as a flood plane or fault.
Slickline collar locator.
The casing joint containing the cement float.
In the context of flow, sub critical is sub sonic.
H2S containing.
The bottom hole pressure when the well has been shut-in and the well stabilized.

Sequenced cement jobs that are placed through different entry points into the annulus.  Undertaken to place a higher cement column in the annulus when the fracturing gradient of the exposed formations will not tolerate a full column of cement.
-In the context of corrosion, SCC is stress chloride cracking.
To tie up ions into a complex micelle or molecule and prevent or slow precipitation of materials.
A platform and handling system to make up screens without damaging the screens.
In the context of a drier, silica gel is a desiccant for removal of water vapor from gas.
A recovery method, or less frequently, a wire installation method using pipe.
Single point of contact.
The snubbing unit control location.
A gamma ray tool capable of spotting the different isotopes used in tracers.
A mud with the oil component replaced by a lower toxicity oil such as mineral oil.
Standard operating procedures.
A completion that uses a screen without a gravel pack, allowing the formation to cave in around the screen.
A piece of drilling equipment, usually with a vibrating screen, where drill cuttings are removed from the flowing mud.
Clay mineral used in drilling fluid. Like attapulgite, it creates viscosity by mechanical interference with the clay particles rather by electrochemical forces.
S-shaped flow line off wing valve.
An underground cavern, developed usually by solution mining, for storage of gas or liquid products.
A production log that uses a propeller-like spinner to measure changes in fluid velocity in sections of the well.
Flow of distinct volumes of gas and liquid, often signaling unstable behavior.
-In the context of goelogic terms, seal is a rock seal that is sufficiently impermeable to prevent leakage of hydrocarbons from a trap.
-Side wall core.
Pulling the pipe up the hole several stands and returning to bottom. May be used to check for fill or to clear cuttings out of a section of the well.
Water glass, used in sealing permeability channels.
Society of Petrophysicists and Well Log Analysts.
Non intergranular porosity such as fractures, vugs, etc. that may contribute sharply to permeability but may not significantly raise the porosity level.
A smooth faced tool that is used to try to re-round ovaled tubing.
A chemical that is attracted to the surface of a fluid and modifies the properties such as surface tension.
A drive mechanism where a drop in pressure releases gas from the oil that helps drive the oil towards the wellbore.  It is a poor recovery mechanism.
In the context of U.S. land, a section is 640 acres.
A commercial tool that measures the fluid depth in a well by use of a reflecting sound wave.
An inexact term. Any cementing after the primary cement job.  Rarely used.
Split Shot™ is a trademarked linear explosive cutter that is designed to cut linearly through the pin and box connection during pipe recovery.
Shut down.
A standard profile. Can accept a plug or other tools.
A propped hydraulic fracture.
A brief report on well information from drilling through initial completion.
A chisel-like tool run on the rig’s sand line to break up junk or stuck tools downhole.
The physical condition of the soil as related to tillage, seedbed preparation, seedling emergence, and root penetration.
Iron carbonate.
A reactor that removes various components from produced gas.

In the context of seismic, susceptibility is a measure of the degree to which a rock can be magnetized.  It is defined as the ratio (k) of the intensity of magnetization (I) to the magnetic field (H) projected into the rock.
The actions involved with running casing and cementing it in place.
A jacket or armour, often around a logging cable, a gauge cable, or a pump cable.
In the context of logging, Sw/So is a movable hydrocarbon index.
A thick sand body without significant vertical or areal barriers.
That part of the bulk volume of soil not occupied by soil particles.
The depth below the surface to where the reservoir fluids will rise by pore pressure.
Stock tank oil originally in place.
In the context of viscosity, shear stress is the force required to move a given area of fluid. Units are Newtons per sq. meter.
A rating indicating improved performance in erosive environments.

The space between the casing guide shoe and the cement float collar that traps cement contaminated by the top plug displacement which also provides margin to displace additional volume (some percentage of shoe track volume) in case plug does not bump.
Oil saturation.  Typically shown as So.
Small solid wire used for rapid, economic placement and retrieval of small equipment in a well.  Comes in several sizes; 0.072”, 0.082”, 0.092”, 0.108”, 0.125”, etc.
Seal where no motion is present.
Sidetracked.
A material that takes another material out of solution or the flow stream.  Among most common are oxygen and H2S scavengers.
A graph showing the percentage changes in an output of a model corresponding to percentage changes in various inputs. The graph for each input resembles a spider leg, being piecewise linear.
A core sample removed from the open hole bore hole wall by an explosive device or rotary drilled with a small tool.
Spontaneous potential log.
Pressure at which vapor and liquid are in equilibrium.  For oils, equal to the bubble point. For condensates, the dew point.

A mathematical construction of a seismic wavefield.  Synthetic seismograms can be calculated in 1D, 2D, or 3D data space.  Either downgoing wavefields, upgoing wavefields, or both can be included in the calculation.
A cement squeeze involving injecting into a lower perforation, separated by a packer from an upper perforation while trying to fill a channel.
A safety valve controlled from the surface through hydraulic or electrical power.
The shrinking of soil when dry and the swelling when wet. Shrinking and swelling can damage roads, dams, building foundations, and other structures. It can also damage plant roots.
Screened orifice valve.
The systematic examination, description, classification, and mapping of soils in an area. Soil Surveys are classified according to the kind and intensity of field examination.
Metallic foil or multiwire screen mesh that is used to prevent electromagnetic fields from penetrating or exiting a transmission cable.
A device that measures radiation output (Geiger counter).
In the context of pumping, a spacer is a fluid used between two fluids to prevent contamination.

One of the oldest and simplest logs.  Measures voltage between formations and the fluid in the wellbore.  Potential differences arise due to the differences between salinity of the formation and the wellbore fluids.  SP is used for qualitative permeability, reservoir quality evaluation, Rw calculations and zone shaliness estimation.  Typically abbreviated as SP.
Stand alone screen completion.
A safety valve controlled from the surface through hydraulic or electrical power.  Typically abbreviated as ScSSV.
A short, full diameter passage tubing sub with a pocket reachable from the inside where gas lift valves or chemical injection valves can be placed by wireline.
One of various mechanisms for controlling formation sand movement during fluid production from a weakly consolidated sandstone.
A specific geographical basin of sedimentary rocks.

A mapping unit used in detailed Soil Surveys where two or more defined taxonomic units are so intimately intermixed geographically that it is undesirable or impractical, because of the scale being used, to separate them. A more intimate mixing of smaller areas of individual taxonomic units than that described under soil association.
Measure the fluid level in a storage tank.
The distance between well producing in the same reservoir.  The spacing is actually the area they drain (e.g., 320, 160 or 40 acres).
The number of joints of pipe that can be pulled and stood back at one time by the rig, e.g., doubles or triples.
A fluid that when sheared, reduces viscosity.
In the context of perforating, a screw port gun is a reusable, reloadable perforating gun with port plugs over the perforating charges.
A corrosion form generated by high chloride brine contact.

The arrangement of primary soil particles into compound particles or aggregates. The principal forms of soil structure are as follows platy (laminated), prismatic (vertical axis of aggregates longer than horizontal), columnar (prisms with rounded tops), blocky (angular or subangular), and granular. Structureless soils are either single grained (each grain by itself, as in dune sand) or massive (the particles adhering without any regular cleavage, as in many hardpans). ·
The rate of shearing of a fluid during a viscosity measurement. The rate of movement between plates.
The removal of a fairly uniform layer of soil material from the land surface by the action of rainfall and surface runoff.
Static bottom hole temperature.
Acceptable to pass: <900 scf/hr.
A foamer for removing water from a gas well, placed in the form of a solid stick.
Set a seal stack all the way down so the locator shoulder on the stinger contacts the packer.
In the context of wireline, SLD is slick line depth.
A grooved pulley.
A job where the well is workover without killing the well.  Usually accomplished by multiple barriers that seal on the tubulars.
Shut-down for the night.
Soil-pore water containing dissolved constituents which has been removed from a saturated paste for analysis.
Shut in casing pressure.
A ram in the BOP that seals around the pipe.
Granular sedimentary rocks with grain sizes between 0.0625 and 2mm.  The pore space where hydrocarbons may be held is between the grains.
Insert the seal stack or stinger into the polished bore receptacle.
A packer with the seal bore through the body of the packer.
An offshore well that is separate from the main group of wells but in the same field.  May be a subsea well or a single platform well with a flow line tie back.
Placing fluid at a specific place in the wellbore.
In the context of pipe running, snubbing is forcing pipe into a well against the effects of wellhead pressure.
In the context of cementing, scratchers are mechanical methods of physically removing mud cake from the borehole wall.
An important soil constituent composed of silicon and oxygen. The essential material of the mineral quartz.
Self contained breathing apparatus.
Sea water.
Defined in NACE MR-0175/ISO 15156 as exposure to oilfield environments that contain H2S and can cause cracking of materials by the mechanisms addressed by NACE MR-0175/ISO 15156
A relative comparison of the formation to determine if there is a large difference between the size of the largest articles and the size of the smallest particles.
Strain energy is the energy gained by a mass as it is deformed.
Cracking of a metal under the combined action of tensile stress and corrosion in the presence of water and hydrogen sulfide (a form of hydrogen stress cracking) (NACE).
In the context of plastics, shore hardness is a plastics scale.  As hardness increases, abrasion resistance tends to increase for some plastics while impact resistance may decline.

A shear wave mode that has its particle-displacement vector oriented perpendicular to the vertical plane passing through the source and receiver stations.  In a flat-layered isotropic Earth, an SH mode has its particle-displacement vector oriented parallel to horizontal interfaces.  See SV.
Settling of particles in a fluid.
In the context of a reservoir, saturation is the fraction of the effective porosity filled with a specific fluid.
-Size diameter ratio, a common measurement in plastic liner pipe.
In the context of seismic, stack is a composite of traces from different seismic records.
Particle size distribution of a sand sample made by running the sample through a set of screens.
