A mechanical dampener above a perforating gun that attenuates some of the acceleration force created by firing the gun.
A condition characterized by fluctuations in the rotational speed of the BHA.

Water that generally is considered unsuitable for human consumption or for irrigation because of its high content of dissolved solids. Commonly expressed as milligrams per liter (mg/L) of dissolved solids, with 35,000 mg/L defined as equivalent to sea water, slightly saline as 1,000 - 3,000 mg/L, moderately saline as 3,000 - 10,000 mg/L, very saline as 10,000 - 35,000 mg/L, and brine has more than 35,000 mg/L (after USGS, 1984).
The initial loss of fluids from a mud or frac fluid, before the walk cake can be formed.

Sour gas is natural gas or any other gas containing significant amounts of hydrogen sulfide (H2S). Natural gas is usually considered sour if there are more than 5.7 milligrams of H2S per cubic meter of natural gas, which is equivalent to approximately 4 ppm by volume under standard temperature and pressure.
A disturbance in the metal structure caused by impact or a wrench mark or penetration of slips that is a likely location for increased corrosion or some failures such as hardening or local fatigue.
A single bore-hole completion where there are distinct surface-to-zone tubing strings with isolation from each other.
Sliding sleeve.

A measure of the ability of water to conduct an electrical current. It is the reciprocal of the electrical resistance in ohms measured between opposite faces of a centimeter cube of an aqueous solution at a specific temperature. The standard measurement is ex pressed in microSiemens per centimeter at 25°C, abbreviated 1-JS/cm. The old units were micromhos per centimeter at 25°C, abbreviated 1-Jmhos/cm at 25°C. Specific conductance is related to the type and concentration of ions in solution and can be used to approximate the dissolved-solids concentration in water. Estimates of the dissolved-solids concentration (in mg/L) range from 60% to 85% of the specific-conductance value in 1-JS/cm at 25°C. For sulfate­type waters, the estimated range of dissolved solids concentration in mg/L is from 90% to 100% of the specific-conductance value.
Laying a sand plug over the lower perfs to cover and protect them form another operation.
A person that reports on competitor leasing and drilling activity.
Setting off charges downhole to rubblize the formation and create a stimulation.
In the context of dual completion, short string is generally the string leading to the upper completion in a side-by-side dual completion.
Subsea disconnect used during drilling a subsea well in case the floating rig moves to an extreme that begins to threaten the shear resistance of the riser or the drill string.
In the context of a reservoir, spill point is in a trap, the low point under which hydrocarbons will escape when the trap is full.
The natural gas that is dissolved in a crude oil.
A numerical value by soil type for estimating the tendency of a soil to be eroded in the soil-loss equation.
Dehydration of a gelled fluid.
Formations located below a salt layer.
In the context of natural flow, seep is a natural site, generally small, where water or oil percolates slowly to the land surface or into a stream, lake or ocean.
Various, usually a heater.
A fracture treatment designed to bypass skin damage.
In the context of a drill string, a saver sub is a threaded coupling under the kelly to which the joints of drill sting are make up.  Save wear on the kelly threads.
A bottom packer, commonly used to locate the bottom of a screen assembly in a sand control completion.
In the context of fluid powered motors, a stall is a condition in which the motor stops rotating when more force is required to rotate the shaft than the motor can produce.
A sand exclusion device.

A second (or higher) attempt to drill a wellbore after the first wellbore has been junked.  This saves re-drilling the top part of the hole but requires drop back to a smaller wellbore size in the sidetrack. Also can be a second wellbore.
Atmospheric pressure of 14.696 psi and temperature of 60F (16C).
A flow controlled shut-in device to control flow in the event of loss of surface well control.  Must be reset periodically.  Replaced by ScSSVs.
65 lb/ft3 or 8.68 lb/gal (1.04 g/cc).

A casing or tubing repair technique that uses a packer at the top and bottom with a smaller diameter pipe in-between to isolate a breach in the pipe or seal off old perfs.  Also used for a liner set in open hole to isolate an unstable zone or loss zone, rather than to increase the pressure containment capability of the well.
Synthetic crude upgraded from mined hydrocarbon.
The valve at the top of the tree, above the flow cross or flow Tee.  The lubricator for interventions may be attached above this valve or the valve may be removed to fit a larger lubricator.
The processes of absorption and adsorption.
Spiralizer™ is a trademarked brand name of a spiral shaped solid body centralizer for casing and screens.
A perforating gun initiation that can sequentially fire charges at two or more depths on a single gun run.
In the context of wireline, a stem is a weight bar.
In the context of risk, a stretch target is an exceptional outcome that a team will strive for but will probably not achieve.
A pipe fitting made in parts to weld or clamp onto a line to create a junction.
Society of Petroleum Engineers.
In the context of testing, shrimp are mycid shrimp used for toxicity tests.
A round device that holds the slips when supporting a string of drill pipe on a rig.
Surface equipment used for quick access to the wellbore.
A moderate to low energy deposit with permeability streaks where energy was higher.  May be very limited in extent and volume.
The rate that data or samples are taken per unit of time.
To begin drilling.
See velocity string.
A well with the wellhead and significant control mechanisms located on the sea floor.
A solution containing the maximum concentration of a specific ion that it will hold at a certain temperature and pressure without precipitating.
See stand of pipe.
A rating indicating improved performance in erosive environments.
Opening or closing a sliding sleeve.
Materials that slow or prevent the mechanical or chemical disaggregation of shale.  These materials include inorganic salts and some organic compounds.
An usually large movement or intrusion of salt that gradually flows through the rock.  Can create reservoir traps and can create casing collapse problems.
The pressure on the annulus side when the well is shut-in.

A group of soils that have profiles that are almost alike, except for differences in texture of the surface layer or of the underlying material. All the soils of a series have horizons that are similar in composition, thickness, and arrangement.
A device that records vibrations (natural or man-made) in the earth. With interpretation, the data can give information on buried strata.
Slick line measurement.
Introducing very small particles in the liquid that accelerate the development of scale or other precipitates.
A downhole safety valve designed to shut the well in case of surface damage to the wellhead.  Typically abbreviated as SSSV.
In the context of logging, SWI is initial water saturation.
A mill that cuts to the side, opening up windows or cutting out restrictions.

A clay that exhibits water swelling and fines dissociation problems when it occurs in authogenic form and is reactive with the flowing fluid. Smectite clays such as bentonite generate viscosity by forming a colloid suspension in water.
In the context of seismic, space domain is a function where distance is the independent variable and another factor (magnetic, density, amplitude) is the dependent variable.
-Swr in the context of logging is water saturationof the uninvaded zone.
A type of log that measures salinity by use of gamma ray emission measurements from collisions of neutrons with chloride ions.
Shut in tubing pressure.
In the context of circulating, swept volume is the amount of the wellbore that is circulated by fluid (describes the hold-up and upswept volume).
The rock mechanics related study of unconsolidated and poorly consolidated sands.
In the context of logging, stratification is the sequence of unlike formations penetrated by the borehole.
Surface safety valve (subsurface safety valve is SSSV).
A volume of gas or liquids that moves through the well and the production facility.  A well that flows alternating volumes of water and gas is slugging.
Sloughing particles into the well.
A standing wave is a wave that appears to be standing still. There is no discernible beginning or end in time to the wave.
A water base fluid with only a very small amount of a polymer added to give friction reduction benefit.
Using short pieces of pipe to property position the top of the string to hang off while keeping the bottom of the string in the correct position and with the correct tension.
A condition in inventory theory in which the commodity level falls to 0, often causing loss of business or stockout cost.
The uprights on a beam lift (rod) pump jack that hold the bearing housings.
A drill collar with spiraled grooves down its length to improve circulation of fluids in close clearance well bores.
Surface controlled selective flow system.
SNAP™ is a trademarked nodal analysis program.
Standard temperature and pressure.
Shut in.
Shut in tubing head pressure.

A gravel sizing method that takes the 50% intercept of a cumulative percent retained of the formation sand against a log particle size; then multiplies by 6 to get the median gravel size for the pack.
Crude oil that contains more than 1% total sulfur content.  Typically applied as a label to oils with sour smell.
Shut in bottom hole pressure.
A casing joint with regular pattern slots of a specific phasing, width and length.  Used as a simple sand control method.

The planned inclination of the tangent section of a directional well. In a horizontal well if would be 90 deg (+/- 10 deg), in a build and hold or S well it would be the tangent section, in a slant well it would be the inclination throughout.
Methane gas stored in a shale. May be in the pore space, adsorbed to the mineral or rock surfaces, or as free gas in the natural fractures.

A consideration in fluid friction calculations.  A pipe with a polished surface may have 1/10th the friction and flow 10 to 25% more fluid at the same pressure drop (depending on pipe diameter), than a pipe with a corroded or heavily fouled surface.

One to four strands of explosive detonating cord suspended by wireline in a well and exploded to “rattle” the pipe and drop scale and debris from the sides of the pipe.  Used frequently in back-off operations (unscrewing a pipe joint downhole).
To dehydrate a sand slurry to a point where the sand is no longer moveable.

A condition where the liquid is over saturated with incompatible ions or one ion concentration is above the saturation point.  Usually a result of cooling a undersaturated fluid below the saturation point without a sufficient upset to start the precipitation growth.
Strontium Sulfate.  Typically shown as SrSO4.
In the context of processing, strip is removing light hydrocarbons (C2+) from the gas before sale.
A recovery improvement process such as water flooding or gas flooding.
The downhole completion interface.
Milling debris from cutting steel.

A layer of soil or soil material approximately parallel to the land surface and differing from adjacent genetically related layers in physical, chemical, and biological properties or characteristics such as color, structure, texture, consistency, kinds and numbers of organisms present, degree of acidity or alkalinity, etc. The following table lists the designations and properties of the major soil horizons. Very few soils, if any, have all of these horizons well developed, but every soil has some of them.
The agreed-upon price at which a share of stock can be bought or sold by the holder of an option.
One barrel of stabilized or dead oil at the surface after the gas has escaped.
An emulsion, usually breakable only with solvent that is stabilized by silt accumulation at the surface of the bubbles or droplets.
-In the context of rock, sill is horizontal intrusion of igneous rock.
A short section of pipe, used to describe tools or to solve space-out gaps.
Single well chemical tracer (SWCT) test. SWCT is an in-situ approach to measuring fluid saturations in reservoirs.

A metal slug, lower in the electromotive series than steel that is hard wired to the casing and buried in a bed of wet soil or below the surface of the water.  The corrosion cell in the well then transfers the current to the new anode and the steel in the well is protected.  Common offshore.
Narrow strands of sandstone formation, often from stream deposits.
A very viscous, usually solids stabilized emulsion.  Often triggered by ferric iron and an asphaltenic oil after an acid job.
A % by weight distribution of the particle sizes in a sample.
A flow regime in a highly deviated or horizontal well where the fluids are segregated by density.
Various, but generally the gas send to the pipeline after dehydrating, stripping and sweetening.
The non-moving slips in a snubbing stack.
An element of the BOP that grips and holds the pipe in place.
In the context of production, salt water is any non-fresh water flow.  Saturated NaCl brine has a density of 9.9 lb/gal.
Standard cubic foot, a measurement at standard conditions of gas volume.
Stop a well from flowing and close the valves.
A completion with casing set through the interval and cemented.
Number of perforations per unit length.
Securing a well such that the well is not capable of flowing hydrocarbons to surface.
A vertical pipe on the derrick used for routing injected fluid flow.
Very small pipe.
An essentially straight hole with less than 5o total deviation from surface to bottom hole and dogleg severity less than 3o/100 ft.
-19359 mg/l chloride; 2702 mg/l sulfate; 142 mg/l bicarbonate; 11155 mg/l sodium + potassium; 1297 mg/l magnesium; 408 mg/l calcium; TDS = 35169 mg/l; pH = 8.2.

In vibration theory, the wave number is the ratio of the wavelength to 2π. If this ratio is a real number, the wave will be a nondispersing wave (i.e., it will have a constant phase velocity for all its components and will retain its shape). If the wave number is complex, then the wave will be a dispersing wave (i.e., its components will have different phase velocities and it will not retain its shape and will disperse over time). All waves encountered in macroscopic reality are dispersing to some extent.
A string mill, designed to enlarge the hole.
See Wireline Entry Guide.
A fishing tool used to find and catch wireline in preparation for fishing the line.
Wireline Entry Guide
Injecting air and water into a reservoir during a fireflood.

An interest in an oil and natural gas lease that gives the owner of the interest the right to drill for and produce oil and natural gas on the leased acreage and requires the owner to pay a share of the costs of drilling and production operations.
Assets that will lose or are losing their value.
Metal that is formed into a desired shape by rolling, extruding, forging, etc.
Paraffin, C18+ alkane fraction.
A valve located at the tree, above the master valve, on the flow line.
Increase fluid density.
An early time frac failure when the frac width is too small and the fracture proppant bridges off on the fracture.
Usually differential sticking (by overbalance), but may also include effect of friction and mud cake adhesion to the tubing or drill string.

A nonupset pipe with an O.D. close enough to the I.D. of an inner pipe to cause hydraulic diversion.  Used inside a screen during gravel packing to direct flow and gravel to the bottom of the screen and effect a tighter pack. Developing hydraulic diversion benefits with a wash pipe usually requires that the washpipe OD be at least 80% or the outer pipe or screen’s ID.
A channel created by acid reacting along a high permeability streak.
A casing shoe with poor cement support.
An inexperienced worker.
A well in a previously undrilled area. An exploratory well.
Shorter chain hydrocarbon liquids, generally after refining.
Well isolation tool.
A metal deterioration in which the metal becomes progressively harder and more brittle with repeated application of load.
Response of an elastic formation to an acoustic energy impulse.
Also known as mud.  Mud with water as the external phase.  May contain clays, polymers, or even an internal oil phase.
Wire grab.
Wireline measured depth.
A cement squeeze under the fracture pressure, trying to build pressure slowly.  Typical in fracture sealing.
Period of time during which weather conditions favorable for operations will or may exist.
West Texas intermediate crude oil.
Removal of solids, completion fluid, and sand workover fluids by production.
Water shut-off.

Well integrity management system

The well integrity management system WIMS normally covers the following elements:
Using barriers to prevent unwanted flow of hydrocarbons to surface.
Workover.
An inexperienced worker.
Walk around rig inspection.
In vibration theory, the wavelength is the distance covered by one wave period.
In the context of coiled tubing, a weak link is a weak point at the top of the BHA, designed to separate before the tubing fails if the BHA becomes stuck.

The pressure rating that continuous operations may take place at the set conditions and fluids. Examples – e.g., WP set at  80% of rated burst for new pipe, 70% for used pipe, 50% for welded or damaged pipe.
A small fitting on the end of a tubing string that is shaped to allow easier entry of logging tools when pulled back into the tubing from the wellbore below.
Forced circulation of fluid through the perfed interval with the intent of generating communication between perforations or intervals.
In the context of perforating, a WML is a wrapped metal liner.
West of Shetlands.
The drilling and completion steps prior to production.
A weight bar in a wireline tool BHA (bottom hole assembly).
Broken or frayed strands of braided line or E-Line.
Oil with a water content above specification.
The act of producing the well with all the efforts involved in bringing the well on-line, keeping it flowing, and shutting it in.
The after flow, created by wellbore volume, into a wellbore after the surface valve has been closed.
A secondary recovery mechanism which involves the injection of water into the reservoir through injector well(s) to maintain reservoir pressure and drive the oil towards the producing well(s).
In the context of wells, WHE is wellhead equipment.
West Texas sour crude oil.
-In the context of rock strength, WBS is wellbore stability.
In the context of a mineral, weathered describes a chemically altered mineral that has lost some definition of the lattice or crystal shape.  May be more unstable or more reactive.
Well head temperature.
The tested ability of a well to produce hydrocarbons.
The mechanical connection between the tree and the casing.  May house tubular hangers, annular access valves.  It is connected to the casing by welding, threads, hydraulic forming or set screws.
The basket on a snubbing unit where the operator stands.
Tools or equipment retrievable with a wireline trip.
Well pulling hoist.
A string weight measurement device that can report the weight on the string at any time.
Filter cake.
Waiting on orders.
Waiting on weather.
Forged iron.
A diverting agent.
Any practice that increases runoff, such as covering the surface with plastic, applying sealants, paving, etc.
The change in pressure or flow rate in one well caused by production in another.
Weight on bit.
Wing valve on a wellhead.
The amount of water in percent in a produced fluid stream.
A servicing rig designed to run and pull tubing. It usually has some capacity to mill or drill.
The measurement of the wetting phase currently on a formation.  Wetting is driven by the fluid or the surfactants in the fluid in contact with the surface.
Using an overshot tool and circulation to remove debris above and from around a fish and grip the fish with the overshot.
Wire wrapped screen.
Working interest owners.
Waiting on engineering.
Movement of water upward into oil strata in response to production of oil and lower reservoir pressures.  May be localized in areas of high vertical permeability.
Water cut.
All physical and chemical changes produced by atmospheric agents in rocks or other deposits at or near the earth's surface. These changes result in disintegration and de composition of the material.
A well used to inject water into a reservoir to maintain pressure or to drive hydrocarbons towards producing wells.
Well Patroller™ is a trademarked cleanup tool that helps remove debris from a well.
Same as a weight stem, a bar used mainly to add weight in a wireline BHA (bottom hole assembly).
Any surface in contact with the flowing fluids in a well.
World Petroleum Council (formerly World Petroleum Congress)
A fracturing treatment using ungelled water.
A unit used for retrieval of completion strings and accessories. Typically abbreviated as WPH.
Wireline measurement.
Wireline retrievable subsurface safety valve.
The well drilling and completion or repair procedure.

A method of controlling kicks in which the weight of the kill weight mud is calculated by the difference between the difference of casing and tubing pressure and the volume of fluid increase; followed by injection of the kill weight mud to displace the lighter weight mud and the kick in a single circulation.
In the context of a beam lift, a walking beam is the main moving beam in a beam lift pump.

A recovery process in which a larger pipe is used with circulation to surround and capture a pipe stuck in sand or cuttings.  Circulation is critical to washing the sand from around the fish.  Can be used with normal or reverse circulation.
A well where produced water is injected back into a deep, usually depleted zone but one that is not connected to the producing pay zones.

Related to any aspect of logging that employs an electrical cable to lower tools into the borehole and to transmit data. Wireline logging is distinct from measurements-while-drilling (MWD) and mud logging.
The fluid that coats a mineral surface; usually either oil wet or water wet.

-In the context of casing, a window is an exit point of a lateral from a mother bore, generally a hole cut in the side of the casing to allow sidetracking the well. Can also be where the entire section of the casing is removed.
A core as drilled from the reservoir and not separated into smaller cores.
Well integrity operations procedure.
A treatment designed to remove damage or debris from the wellbore and the perforations.
A gravel packing treatment using ungelled water as the carrier fluid.
Solids added to increase density in a fluid.

A sharp, sometimes very high force and pressure load that is created when a valve is closed too rapidly in a flowing stream.  The major force occurs behind the valve.  Most common in a production well when sudden closure (slam closure) of a subsurface safety valve can create a load of over 50,000 lbs force in the tubing tensile/compressive loading. In an injector, the water hammer effects of a rapid shut-in are lower, but some effects may be seen on the formation.
Incident in which a failure of barrier(s) or failure to activate barrier(s), results in an unintentional flow of formation fluid into the well, into another formation or to the external environment.
-In the context of drilling, washout is flow cutting of equipment downhole.
A special, often large string of tubulars that are used during the completion of the well.  Usually higher pressure capacity or allow higher weights than the production tubing.
Water oil contact
Weight percent.
Water bearing with little hydrocarbon.
A hardened steel ramp along which a mill turns as it cuts a hole in the side of the casing to start a sidetrack or lateral wellbore.
See Available water capacity.
The time spent waiting on cement to reach sufficient strength to proceed with operations. Typically abbreviated as WOC.
Water droplets suspended in a continuous oil phase.
Tools specifically designed to operate on wireline conveyance.  May be either for slickline (non electrical signal conducting) or for electric line.
A reservoir drive mechanism where an aquifer provides pressure support and pushes towards the low pressure area around the well, driving the oil ahead of it.
Water.
Well intervention pressure control

In the context of reactions, wet gloss heating value is the total energy transferred as heat in an ideal combustion reaction of a water saturated gas at a standard temperature and pressure in which all water formed appears as a liquid.
Placement of a fluid in the wellbore with coiled tubing where the fluid is spotted at the bottom of the zone and the CT is withdrawn at the same rate the hole is filled.
Wireline formation tester or wireline formation testing.
This abbreviation can have two different meanings.

A relative permeability problem usually occurring in a gas zone. Highest potential formations for water blocks are low pressure gas sands (<;0.25 psi/ft pore pressure), with small pore throats (<10 microns), lower permeability (<;100 md), and when using water that has a surface tension about 50 dyne/cm.
A BOP for wireline operations.
The water initially in vapor phase within a gas that condenses out when gas cools.  Usually 1 to 2 bbls per million scf.
Wellhead flowing pressure.
A measurement of the comparison of large to fine grains.  A well sorted formation has a narrow size range between the smallest and the largest particles.
Wellhead flange.  The flange on the first cemented string of casing to which the BOP is bolted during drilling and on which the well head is built after drilling.
A hydrocarbon gas with heavier ends (C2+).
A pumpable plug with flexible cup-like extensions that seal and isolate the fluid behind the plug from the fluid in front.
WETS™ is a trademarked wellwork evaluation tracking system.
Repairing a well.  Usually implies opening the well and running in with a tubing string. May or may not involve killing the well, and may or may not involve a conventional rig.
In the context of tubing, weight is the weight of a particular tubing size, grade, and weight on a weight per pound basis.  Includes the weight of the coupling.
A section, usually pressurized and capable of being opened, below a coiled tubing injector where larger tool can be added or removed to the CT (coiled tubing) BHA (bottom hole assembly).
Water flood regulation valve.
A sand control screen with a shaped wire wound to achieve a set opening size (within tolerance) around a perforated base pipe.
In drilling, the drilled hole.
A surface condition in which the coating chemicals show an attraction preference for water.
The drawing of the well and its equipment showing depths, sizes, grades, and specific equipment.
Work remotely operated vehicle.
In the context of chemical treating, a wellbore wash is a solvent or acid wash of the wellbore with minimum leakoff into the matrix.
The wave period is the length of time is takes a wave to travel from crest to crest. The wave frequency is the inverse of the wave period.

Values determined during an interpolation or simulation that are multiplied by the control data points in the determination of the final estimated or simulated value at a grid node. For geostatistical applications, the weights λ must sum to unity for a condition of unbiasedness.
A level of water in a string to be used for flowback to generate an initial damping back pressure.
In context to a wireline or CT, a weak point is a designed weak point, usually right about the fishing neck on the tool that is designed to separate when excess tension or axial loads are applied.
A tertiary drive mechanism using alternating injections of water and gas.

A device at the bottom of an overshot for centering the upward looking end of pipe that may be laying against the casing.  The hook may resemble a finger or strip of metal pointing clockwise and used with pipe rotation to surround and center the pipe.
Water based mud.
In the context of sand control, weave screens are screens where the filtration layer is largely layers of woven screenwire.
In the context of a gas lift, a wobble ring is a lock ring that anchors the gas lift valve in the side pocket mandrel.
Well head pressure.
Wireline removable insert valve.
Oil:  brine ratio.
Reactants that oxidize, e.g., bleach and sodium persulfate. Also, a compound that releases oxygen.
Open flow potential.
The oil production or transfer during a specific time period.
Oil country tubular goods.
Out of service.
Payzone, usually produces oil in economic quantities.
Generally used as an addition method of adding materials to the fluid being pumped without recirculation.
A log that detects compounds with oxygen such as water.  Often used to detect channels behind pipe.
On the job training.
Perforating to align the charge penetration direction with a feature like the fracture plane or to miss an adjacent string of pipe.
The maximum potential rate from the well if all back pressure was removed.
OD or O.D.
Electrical unit of resistance. One ohm is the the resistance through which a potential of one volt will maintain a current of one ampere.
Vertical thickness of an oil accumulation  above an oil/water contact.
A mud in which the external, liquid phase is oil.
Spheres of calcium carbonate precipitated from connate water.
A well outside the normal drilling/production pattern.
In the context of a reservoir, oil saturation is the fraction of the porosity of a zone occupied by oil. Represented as So.
An inflatable or other packer that can seal in an open hole environment.
Local boundary between the oil and the bottom water.  OW Contact may vary in the field depending on individual drawdowns and local variations in vertical permeability.
A deposit in the flow path that is chiefly organic in composition – typically paraffin (wax), asphaltene, tar, or other organic material.
ORC System or Organic Rankine Cycle power generation system, based on thermo-dynamic processes of vaporization and condensation of an organic fluid. Reference.
Outer annulus pressure.
An epoch in time from 25 to 28 million years ago.
At or near the top of the structure that forms the reservoir trap or cap rock.
A well that has it’s wellhead location offshore, either on a platform or on the sea floor as a subsea well.
Outside diameter/inside diameter, usually used in reference to pipe dimension, and a factor in pressure stability of the pipe.
Oil water contact.
The fluid that is pumped after the last reactive or active part of a stimulation to displace the stimulation down to (displacement) or into (overflush) the formation.

The formal term for the kriging method discussed in this chapter, in which the local mean varies and is re-estimated on the basis of the control points in the search neighborhood ellipse (moving neighborhood).
The sediment weight pressing down on the formation.

All submerged lands seaward and outside the area of lands beneath navigable waters. Lands beneath navigable waters are interpreted as extending from the coastline 3 nautical miles into the Atlantic Ocean, the Pacific Ocean, the Arctic Ocean, and the Gulf of Mexico excluding the coastal waters off Texas and western Florida. Lands beneath navigable waters are interpreted as extending from the coastline 3 marine leagues into the Gulf of Mexico off Texas and western Florida.
The oil in place at any time in the reservoir.  The original oil in place is OOIP.
In the context of a gas lift, an orifice is a set diameter passage.
Oil: water ratio.
The operating valve (open and flowing) in a gas lift system.
Over production, beyond the allotment or contract volume, that must be accounted for in a contract.
The company responsible for drilling, completing, operating and repairing the well.
Is commonly displayed as Uo.
Outer continental shelf.
Open hole frac pack. Frac packing in an open hole.
A fixed, moored, or dynamically positioned platform for hydrocarbon production or handling operations offshore.
Occupational safety and health administration, US government agency.
Original oil in place.
Breakout of gas from a liquid, normally at the point where the pressure has declined sufficiently to allow solution gas to be released as bubbles.
Ocean bottom seismic.
Operation expenditures.  Generally repair or maintenance expenses.
Where the pressure in the wellbore in higher than the pressure in the reservoir.
The load applied when pulling equipment that is in excess of the actual string weight.
Offshore receiving facility.
Oil jar.
The most widely accepted theory to explain the generation of hydrocarbons. As organic materials are buried, heat and pressure transform them into hydrocarbons over geologic time.
In the context of the North Sea, OOC stands for Offshore Operators Committee.
The section of a concentric liner or casing installation where both strings are cemented.
A period (geologic) of mountain building.
A well drilled next to another. Sometimes refers to neighboring wells of different operators.
Outer casing.
Operations installation manager.

A predominately oil phase drilling mud with trace water (<10%) as an additive or a contaminant.  Oil as the continuous or external phase.  Note:   special cleanup and dispersants are needed before displacing with brine or treating with acids.
A high quality, widely available mined sand used for gravel packing and fracture proppant.
Opening pressure of a gas lift valve at depth.
A common oilfield emulsion where oil droplets (the internal phase) are suspended and surrounded by the water (the continuous or external phase).
The ratio of the pressure required to open the preventer to the pressure under the rams.
Oil in place.
An organic acid such as acetic, formic, etc., that has the characteristic COOH- group.
Offshore Technology Conference.
Part of an orifice metering system.  A plate with a hole through which a single phase flow produces a pressure drop.
The support services involved in constructing, stimulating, producing and repairing a well.
An area of earth shift common to mountainous regions in which strata are shoved upwards creating highly titled reservoirs.
A porous rock reservoir that contains oil.
Hydrocarbons that contain one or more double or triple bonds.
Shooting an open hole section of the well for stimulation.

An external annulus production by surface casing for example, in which the cement behind the production pipe has not been brought up into the casing by casing annulus.  The annulus is open to the formation into which the outer string has been set.
Rock coated with an oil in direct with the rock and attracted by natural surfactant properties.

A cable-based seismic receiver system that is positioned on the seafloor so shear-wave data can be acquired in addition to compressional wave data.  OBC technology usually involves 4C sensors.  Typically abbreviated as OBC.  See 4C.
A sand control completion for high permeability soft sand formations where the small amount of area offered by the perforations is a restriction on what the formation can deliver to the wellbore.
One of a suite of logs commonly run in a well before it is cased.
No longer flowing naturally.
A mudrock or mudstone, composed of a large amount of kerogen or similar deposit, which will yield oil when refined.
Wells used for instrumentation or mechanical observations of a reservoir.
Oil and grease. A measure of hydrocarbon content in soils and water. Usually used in reference to petroleum hydrocarbons.
Where a formation surfaces.
A seal arrangement on top of a wireline lubricator that prevents loss of oil or gas to the atmosphere.
Statistically, data points that fall outside approximately ±2.5 standard deviation of the mean value of the sample population. Outliers can be the result of bad data values or local anomalies.
A royalty interest that may be retained by a third party as payment or investment.  This interest normally bears no part of the drilling and completion expenses of the well.
Original gas in place.
Oil in water.
Soil dried at 105°C until it reaches constant weight.
An eight carbon chain hydrocarbon in the paraffinic oil series.
A single phase flow meter, primarily for gas that measures the pressure drop created by the hole as gas is flowed.
A jarring tool, capable of very large impacts that is cocked and then triggered by oil moving through an orifice.
A circular seal with a circular cross section.
A limit placed on coiled tubing, usually in % ovality, after which the CT may not be used in deep wells or in well operations outside of completion hangoffs.
A change in tube roundness. Ovality in percent = (Dmax-Dmin)/Dnominal x 100.
A completion without casing.
A fishing tool designed to slip over the fish and grasp the outside.
A geologic time period from 425 million to 500 million years ago.
Operating gas lift valve.
Wells for which the operators cannot be located.
Open hole gravel pack.
In the context of logging, OA stands for oxygen activation.
Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. (1983 list:   Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Iran, Iraq, Venezuela, Quatar, Libya, Indonesia, United Arab Republic, Algeria, Nigeria, Ecuador and Gabon).

A type of pressure exerted in living bodies as a result of unequal concentration of salts in both sides of a cell wall or membrane. Water will move from the area that has the lesser salt concentration through the membrane into the area that has the greater salt concentration; it therefore, exerts additional pressure on its side of the membrane.
International Association of Oil and Gas Producers.
Overshot.

Movement of a solvent through a semipermeable membrane (plastic, polymer or living cell) into a solution of higher solute (dissolved salt) concentration that tends to equalize the concentrations of solute on the two sides of the membrane.
A weld technique on diagonal cut strips of steel, superior to the butt weld process for joining flat strips of metal together before rolling into coiled tubing.
The level of adherence of one substance to another.

A rheological model used to describe flow in some fluids. Bingham fluids have a linear shear stress, shear-rate behavior after an initial shear-stress boundary has been crossed.  Plastic viscosity or PV is the slope of the line. Yield Point is the threshold.
Fracture.
A pressure caused by a restriction or fluid head that exerts an opposing pressure to flow.
Seldom used name for a SSSV profile.
A soft metal alloy used in some seals and bearings.
Having two modes, a property ascribed to certain histograms or probability density functions.
A map containing boundaries, locations and survey points.
An oil and gas partnership that has not committed to a specified project at the time of amassing capital.
The equipment or tools at the bottom of the tubing or drill string.  The BHA is changed to achieve a certain result.
Bottom hole temperature.
Baker Oil Tools.
Mixing a specific volume of a treating fluid in a properly sized tank Ð as opposed to mixing-on-the-fly.

The equation is used in the design of chokes and explains the manner in which pressure in the body in the body of the choke, downstream of the first pressure drop, is lower than the eventual recovery pressure at the end of the choke.
A crosslinker for guar based gels.
Clamshell-type rings of anodes that clamp around a pipeline.
Byron Jackson Service Company.
In the context of piplines, a booster pump is a pump located along the length of a pipeline to raise the pressure and overcome friction or elevation losses.
British Thermal Unit.
A fuel oil, normally with high sulfur and high viscosity. API gravity of about 10.5o.
Behind-pipe reserves are expected to be recovered from zones in existing wells, which will require additional completion work or future recompletion prior to the start of production.
An uncontrolled release of fluids from a well.
The solid rock that underlies the soil and other unconsolidated material or that is exposed at the surface.
A subdivision of the classification of a sequence of rocks.  A bed usually has similar lithographic features and is separated from other groupings by recognizable boundaries.
Bottom hole injection pressure.
Benzene, toluene, xylene.
The degree to which material having cation-exchange properties is saturated with exchangeable bases (sum of Ca, Mg, Na, and K), expressed as a percentage of the total cation exchange capacity.
A flat bottom, short steel tool run on wireline to tag the surface of water or solids in the well.  It is nearly the drift diameter of the tubular.

Surface separating layers in a sandstone. Usually bedding planes mark the transition of the particle transport event. An accumulation of minerals or other materials laid down at the time of rock deposition or generated by reworking, that may create significant vertical permeability barriers in a sedimentary rock.
In the context of elastomers, blistering is surface deterioration caused by gas trying to escape too rapidly from a elastomer and tearing the surface of the material.

A traditional crude oil, containing alkanes (straight carbon chains) of C5 to C30+ liquids. Black oils consist of a wide variety of chemical species including large, heavy, nonvolatile molecules. The phase diagram predictably covers a wide temperature range. The critical point is well up the slope of the phase envelope.

A very simple, open hole pay zone completion with a minimum of downhole equipment.  Also called an open hole completion.  The casing is usually run to the top of the pay and is cemented above the pay only.
A log that measures the interval transit time for a compression wave to move a unit of distance, usually one foot.
A measure of the hardness of the material, generally measured by pushing a small ball into the surface and measuring the force used to displace the ball to a set depth.

Contractual agreement between legal parties to account for differences between chart measured quantities and the total confirmed quantities at a measuring point such as a plant. They are used to track over/under production relative to entitlements between producers, over/under deliveries relative to measured volumes between operators of wells, pipelines and LDCs.
The weight of a string or piece of equipment immersed in the wellbore fluid.  It is strongly dependent of the density of the wellbore fluid.
Nipple that can be blocked off from formation pressure and give a false pressure measurement.
Marine vessel without its own propulsion.
In geologic terms, a bar is a mass of sand or other materials deposited in the bed of a stream channel.
Reaching bottom with the plug during a cementing operation or fluid displacement operation.

An oilfield measurement barrel is 42 US gallons or 5.615 ft3 or 6.28 barrels = 1 meters3.  Note that reservoir barrels undergo shrinkage by the reservoir volume factor as gas escapes.  Stock tank barrels are measured after gas escapes.
In the context of design, BOD stands for basis of design.
An irregular intrusion of an igneous rock into another rock.
A welded connection using two pipe ends, cut straight across and welded together with minimum circumferential contact.
Base Kelly bushing.
Array.
A device used to catch debris in the wellbore. Often a part of the string. Also known as basket sub.
In the context of fluid treating, batteries are the separation facilities.
Free gas separating from the liquid at the bottom of the separator.  Generally indicates poor separator performance.
A straight through flow line from the wellhead to a flare pit.  Often used in diverting flow during a well control incident.
A slip for high alloy (hard) casing.
Secure the well or close in.
Bottom hole flowing temperature.
Biotic factors refer to any living organisms present in an ecosystem. These processes are integral to the generation of both natural gas and natural hydrogen in the subsurface.
An artificial lift system, common to low pressure, lower rate oil wells, with a plunger type bottom hole pump operated from the surface by a rod string.
In the context of a beam lift, a bridle is the wire rope attachment of the horses head to the polish rod on a beam lift pump jack.
A quarried sandstone with from 4500 to 9000 psi UCS, used commonly in laboratory flow testing.
The section of the valve housing that covers the stem and protects the seals.
Best in class.
Old term for a large, often wooden wheel, in a cable tool rig.
Gas volume that separates from produced water.
Usually reverse circulation.
Gas anchor or a separator used in front of a pump to deflect most of the free gas to improve pump efficiency.
A depositional environment with several channels that may or may not be connected.
In the context of well plugging, BP stands for bridge plug.
Bottom hole circulating temperature.
Unscrewing a tool or equipment.  In pipe recovery, back-off of a joint precedes recovery of the upper section in a well.  Common in plug and abandonment or sidetrack operations.
In the context of contracts, bonus money is any funds paid to a mineral owner in addition to least of royalties.
In the context of seals, a back-up ring is a ridged ring-like support next to a seal to provide higher pressure or temperature support.

The beating phenomenon occurs when two harmonic waves of slightly different frequencies are impressed on a body. They are a periodic variation in vibration at a frequency that is the difference between to two frequencies.
A flange plate without an opening, normally used as seal-off assurance over an unused line.

A detonating cap between two detonating cords in a series of perforating guns. a.k.a. Booster or Bi-directional booster a device designed to carry forward the explosive energy of the detonator and detonating cord to the next component in an explosive train. Normally used when perforating devices are deployed in sequence, where it is typically deployed in a tandem connector.
The pressure at which gas begins to break out of an under saturated oil and form a free gas phase in the matrix or a gas cap.
The efficient delivery of proved developed reserves through excellence in Reservoir, Well and System management.
A product that kills bacteria in the water or on the surface of the pipe.
A theory of petroleum formation in which the petroleum is thought to have originated from plant and animal material that has undergone transformation from deep burial.
Borehole pressure integrity.
In a logging context, BVI is the proportion of capillary bound fluids occupying effective porosity.
To release gas pressure.  In a reservoir, blow down is often after the oil recovery phase has been complete and the majority of the gas from the gas cap needs to be recovered.
A funnel shaped pipe at the top of the casing that guides tool string entry and may have a side port for fluid pumping.
Benchmark.
A settled plug made of particles or barite or even barite and sand that are placed to seal off a zone or the wellbore.
Valve designed for blocking the fluid in upstream and downstream directions.
A drill bit, commonly either a roller cone, button bit, PDC, diamond or drag bit, used with a rotary string or a mud motor to drill through rock.
-A specific seismic reflection that may indicate gas.

A large area with a general containment and an often thick accumulation of rock. A sedimentary basin is an area of regional settling that can be characterized in space, time, and sedimentary fill .It is a physical depression at the earth's surface which accumulates and preserves sediments. The scale of basins varies greatly, from ocean basins to small ponds.[1]

Backreaming is the practice of pumping and rotating the drillstring while simultaneously pulling out of the hole. When reliable topdrive drilling systems (TDSs) on conventional drilling rigs were introduced more than 25 years ago, the practice of backreaming became a popular technique in the driller's toolbox for tripping out of hole initially in deviated wells.
A type of corrosion found when dissimilar metals are joined.  One part becomes the cathode and the other the anode where accelerated corrosion may be seen.
An estimation of the pumpability of a slurry.  Has no direct correlation to viscosity.
Reverse circulating.
An older perforating method where hardened steel bullets were fired from short barrels and designed to penetrate the casing, cement and formation.
A layer of rock that cannot be detected by seismic.
Beyond the best.
In the context of fluid flow, the beta factor is a correction factor for the Darcy Equation to account for changes in pressure and fluid saturation along a fracture.
By weight of water.
Formation oil volume factor.
A measure of the particle size of a cement.
A section of the wellhead or of a tool what allows slips to be inserted to hold pipe or equipment.
Any portion of the wellhead or tree that contains wellbore pressure.
Base management excellence.
A mature field on decline or in the final stages of productive life.
Ball operated shear sub.
The simultaneous flow of two immiscible fluids.
A common diverter.  It can sublime, or go directly from a solid to a gas.
Balance line.
A shape of a reamer blade that allow milling either up or down.
Bottom hole circulating pressure.
The innermost wrap of coil or cable on a spool or reel.
A chemical or treatment that kills bacteria.
Baker Hughes INTEQ.
When using ball sealers, to effectively shut-off the entire zone and cause pressure to rise sharply.
The annulus above the packer.

Reverse flow of a fluid, usually in a well treatment or injection well, where flow from the reservoir to the wellbore, often at high drawdown, is used to clean fluids and shallow particulate damage from the near-wellbore area.

In the context of fluid flow, broaching is the venting of fluids to surface through channels in cement or behind pipe (well control barrier failure) or unintended fracturing into a adjacent formation.
Sudden backflow of a well, usually to clean the perforations.
An older (actually trademarked name) for the wellhead.
Irregular motion of colloidal sized particles when suspended in a fluid. The effect in simplest terms is caused by thermal driven motions.
Base operations camp.
Separate the emulsion into its components.
The gas required in a storage reservoir to cycle the working gas volume.
A butane derivative used in manufacture of synthetic rubber (elastomers).
A low to moderate strength centralizer formed by arched spring-like straps of metal.

In a drilling context, a bit whirl is the motion that a bit makes when it does not rotate about its center. This may manifest itself in out of round holes and severe bit damage. Generally a poor drilling performance.
The actual minimum burst pressure derated by a safety factor.  The derated burst is used as a maximum when pumping.
In the context of a flare, burner capacity is the maximum BTU's that can be released from a burner while burning with a stable flame and satisfactory combustion. Also known as burner rating.
Radius of curvature of flexible pipe, measured to the pipe centerline.
BPFlux™ is the trademarked name for a flux damage estimating system.
A device with moveable vanes attached to an under water seismic streamer.
To vent or drain of fluids from a pressured well.
The starting fluid for a pill or a treatment. Before additives.
A pipe connection.
Bottom hole televiewer. A sonic caliper tool, not a television.
A heavy plate that can hold the bit in the rotary table to make or break it from the drill string.
To mill a piece of equipment (and often to catch it with an overshot).
Bottom hole static temperature.
A test technique using an injected solution of borax and a detection tool to spot channels.
Agreement between a host and a contract lease holder under which the host pays the contractor an agreed price for all or part of the produced hydrocarbons.
In the context of coal, a butt fracture is a secondary, discontinuous fracture.
A thick walled pressure container of pressure measuring instruments or a sample container.
Fluid loss control material that bridges against the leakoff site.
In the context of coatings, a binder is the nonvolatile portion of a coating.
An abrasion and erosion resistant tube that is run where ever direct sand impingement is a problem.
In the context of perforating, a big hole charge is a perforating charge with the liner shaped to create a large entrance hole but a shallow penetration.  See Deep Penetrating Charge.
Barrels per day.
A short section of a tool or pipe that is formed at an angle or is modified downhole by a motor to assist in entering deviated wellbores or drilling off the path of the wellbore.
Bottom hole flowing pressure.
In the context of flow, a block is an obstruction to flow, either partial or full.
A fracture created with little or no plastic deformation.
A Standard Oil measure of 42 gallons, originally known as a blue barrel and abbreviated bbl. 0.16 m3.
The most common volcanic rock.  Usually fine grained.
A North Sea field with a light crude oil used for cost comparisons.
In the context of density, the baume scale is a density scale used in mineral acid strength measurement.
The ram sections in a BOP that are used to close against each other and isolate the well when no pipe is in the well.
Hanger for bottom-hole pressure recorder (bombs).
A quick opening, low pressure valve, common on large openings through which solids will move, that allows high flow rate when open.
The drilled hole.
In a subsea context, BML stands for below mud line.
A record of bit run, depth, rate of penetration, etc., in a wellbore.
Various. A solid hanger or test cup in a BOP. A retrieval plug attached to drill pipe. An inexperienced worker.
In the context of contracts, a back-in contract is a type of interest in a well or least that becomes active at a specified time or a specified event.
A sonic caliper, developed in the late 1960's, which generated a sonar picture of the wellbore.
Mechanical device activated by pumping a ball of a certain size down the tubing in the injected or circulated fluid.
Base flange.
A device in a perforating gun that signals through a delayed shot or sound that the detonating cord has fired to the bottom of a gun.
Valve that blocks flow into the downstream conduit when in the closed position.
A tool that takes bottom hole samples of fluids or solids.
A seismic wave that propagates in the interior (body) of the Earth.  See surface wave.
A metal-to-metal seal for a flange.
The internal fluid pressure that will cause the onset of pipe yield.
A restriction in a flow path.
A small, usually hand driven pump with a long dip tube used to move chemicals from drums and barrels.
One of the many forms of the barium sulfate mineral.  The BaSO4 material is used in drilling mud as a weighting agent and can produce a slurry of over 20 lb/gal in water.
Barrels water per day.
Flowing slugs of material.
Barrel per minute.

A conditional surface pressure barrier often consisting of a set of hydraulically operated rams containing equipment designed to grip pipe, seal around pipe, shear off pipe or seal an open hole during drilling or a workover. It may also contain an annular preventer.

A two-part theorem relating conditional probability to unconditional (prior) probability, used in value of information problems but also important to acknowledge when estimating probabilities for geologically dependent prospects.
In a drilling context, Bc is Bearden units of consistency.
A specialized viscosimeter.
To close in the end.
Bacteria generated natural gas, found at shallow depths.
An asphaltic or tar based protective surface coating.
Brake horsepower.
A cement squeeze into a area of perforations.  Often done initially over the frac pressure.

In the context of filtration, the beta rating is a conditional ratio requirement on a filtering system that compares the number of particles of a certain size in the unfiltered and filtered fluid. A beta rating of 1000 at 5 microns means that there is one particle of 5 micron or greater size in the filtered fluid for every 1000 particles of 5 micron or greater size in the unfiltered fluid.
Bottom hole shut-in pressure.
Any organic material.
A permeable core from which hydrocarbon escapes without differential pressure application.
Another name for a tapered tap.  Used to screw into boxed of connections.
Back pressure valve.
Locks slips, mandrels or cones in place in a downhole tool.
Blow out preventer.

Estimates for which there is a correlation between the standardized errors and the estimated values (see Cross-validation ) or for which a histogram of the standardized errors is skewed. Either condition suggests a bias in the estimates, so that one area of the map may always show estimates that are higher (or lower) than expected.
To tighten a connection.
In the context of perforating, a bar-vent is a vent in the tubing or treating string open by a drop bar used to fire a perforating gun.
Bottom hole treating pressure.

A method of equating the energy produced by a hydrocarbon gas to a standard oil measurement. One barrel of oil has about the same heat producing capacity as 6,000 ft^3 of gas at standard conditions. Abbreviated BOE.
A device used to reround slightly collapsed tubulars.
A frangible disk designed to release pressure at a specific level.
Water that is trapped in or on the matrix minerals and cannot move.
A four carbon chain alkane, may be a liquid in the reservoir, but vaporizes as pressure is released.  Part of the natural gas liquid components.
Ball sealer.
Ball out mud acid.
Bell guide.
An engineered sequence of choke settings in the start-up of a well to apply stresses in the formation in a manner that will strengthen the formation and avoid failure.
In the context of sedimentary rocks, biogenic sources are rocks such as coal resulting from decomposition of animal or plant deposition.
A cylinder at surface to catch ball sealers before the fluid is routed through the choke.
Barium sulfate.
Usually a flat bottom mill.
A compound containing the HCO3- ion.
Any of several valves that rotate a ball with a flow passage to allow or deny flow.

In the context of drilling, ballooning is the phenomenon in which fluids are lost to the rock during over-pressured operations, such as found in increased pressures from equivalent circulating density operations, and then flow back when pressure is reduced.  This may be confused with a kick.
The female part of the connection.
An unperforated piece of casing or tubing in an otherwise perforated section.  Used for isolation.
Collection of materials, usually from the formation that interlocks at some point in the well, often in the annulus and may stop flow or stick the pipe in place.
A thread for tools and equipment that has three parallel threads per inch (similar to a AW thread). Used in applications greater than 1.75" OD.
Reworking of the sediment by burrowing animals.

Barrels of oil equivalent. A method of equating the energy produced by a hydrocarbon gas to a standard oil measurement. One barrel of oil has about the same heat producing capacity as 6,000 ft of gas at standard conditions.
Barrels of liquid per day.
Remove solids or fluids from a well.
Plates in a separator on which the flow impinges and breaks out gas.
Beyond the best common process.
By weight of the blend.
A blockage in the wellbore caused by a mass of particles that lock together and prevent pipe movement or flow.
Liquefaction or break down of oily waste or clean-up of oil spills by the use of the naturally occurring oil consuming bacteria, chiefly ultramonis and pseudomonis.
Added friction in a deviated well as wireline or coil rubs against the top of the deviated section as the tube or cable is pulled out of a well.

In the context of coiled tubing, a bending cycle is the process of cycling coiled tubing from a yielded position, through a transition region, and back again. Running coiled tubing from the reel into a well and back to the reel involves six bends or three cycles.
Bottom hole assembly.
A viscosimenter use for some fluid measurements, particularly when solid suspension properties are needed.
Fragmented (not wear rounded) grains. Rock along moving faults may have this texture.
Business unit.
In a drilling context, BRT stands for below rotary table.
A clay-based drilling mud gelling agent.
A laboratory measuring scale for expressing mixtures of products used to formulate muds.  One gram of material added to 350 cc of liquid is equivalent to 1 lb of material added to a 42 gallon barrel.
A chemical used to keep the pH in a certain range without extremes of high or low pH.
In a drilling context, a bit weight is the applied downhole axial force component from the string weight.
A permanent or retrievable plug set typically on wireline to isolate a section of the well.
Either static (non circulating, non flowing  and stable), flowing, or circulating temperature at the bottom of the well.
A selected reference point for comparing performance.
The angle of the inclination in the kickoff section when describing a deviated well.

Breaking down alkanes by bacterial action.  Common by psedomonis and ultramonis bacteria and other bacterial strains that digest parts of the crude oil structures. Useful for remediating oil spills or tank bottom residuals.
Applied stress over change in volume. Typically represented by the variable 'K'.
Ball valve.
A sintered aluminum based proppant with very high strength, 3.2 g/cc density and high abrasion characteristics.
Circulating the bottom hole fluid to the top of the well.
In the context of forces on a pipe, the balance point is that point at which forces acting on pipe in a well (usually while running) are equal.
The seal in the annulus between a hanging pipe and the next pipe outward.
In the context of piping, a bypass is a secondary flow path that goes around a repair point or other feature.

In cementing, the first plug pumped in cementing with the two plug system.  It isolates the mud and cement slurry and allows passage of the cement slurry when the plug Òbumps or reaches the float shoe or float collar.  It is hollow with a diaphragm that is ruptured by pressure.
Pyrogeneous, essentially non reactive, hydrocarbon. Most bitumen is not considered as movable through the reservoir under normal conditions of flow.
The device that takes in fluid feed, mixes in sand and then outputs to the pump truck.
Bottoms.
A chemical added to a gel that breaks down the gellant structure.
An initiating or detonating device in an explosive.
An attachment strap to affix cable or capillary tube to the outside of the tubing.
A colloidal clay, generates plastic viscosity due to their size and electrostatic layer.
Unscrewing a joint of pipe of part of a BHA.
Base flange elevation.
Water soluble polymers produced by bacterial action on carbohydrates.
In the context of corrosion, a barrier coating is a coating with a high resistance to permeation of liquids/gasses.
By weight of cement.
In the context of a reaction, a byproduct is a product, sometimes undesirable, of a reaction designed to create something else.
The deformation of pipe in compression as it moves from straight to sinusoidal to helical shapes in the hole.  Usually in the elastic range.

As defined by NORSOK: One of several dependent barrier elements, which are designed to prevent unintentional flow of a formation fluid.  A barrier is an envelope preventing hydrocarbons from flowing unintentionally from the formation, into another formation or, to surface.  Barrier elements that make up the Primary barrier are those elements, which are or might be in direct contact with well pressure during normal operation. These elements provide the initial and inner envelope preventing unintentional flow of reservoir fluid to surface, or another zone. Barrier elements that make up the secondary barrier are those, which are or might be exposed to contact with well pressure should any of the elements described as a Primary barrier fail.  These elements provide an envelope outside the Primary barrier envelope providing a second barrier preventing unintentional flow of reservoir fluid to surface, or another zone.
Petrobras.
Characteristic markings (ridges, tears, risers, etc.) on fracture surfaces after fatigue crack of fracture propagation (also known as clamshell marks, conchoidal marks and arrest marks).
The solids and water entrained in crude oil. Abbreviated BS&W or BSW.
The temperature at which the vapor pressure of the liquid is equal to the pressure exerted on it by the surrounding atmosphere.
An isotope tracer in a bead with the same density of the flowing fluid that is used to track fluid flow rates and therefore fluid entry and exit points along the wellbore.
A bit that, when rotated, drills a hole larger than its diameter.
British Standards Institute.
The tool that keeps the pipe string from rotating while a joint is made up. Also known as a back-up tong.
In the context of screening, blinding is obstructing an aperture or opening by particles or debris.
A restriction in a profile near the bottom of the well that allows some gas expansion and holds a backpressure on the formation.  Rarely used, but considered for hydrate control.
A strong, braided wireline of various sizes used in retrieving tools heavier than slickline can handle. Electrical line is a braided line with a center conductor.
Billions of cubic feet.
A build-up of particles on the upstream side of a filter that improves the filter's ability to remove particles from fluid (will also raise the differential pressure across the filter).
A screw-in plug, normally used at the bottom of a string if no fluid entry is desired.
In a drillng context, a brake is the main device for stopping the travel of the drawworks of a rig when running or pulling a drill string.
Small, rubber-covered, hard centered balls that can seal individual perforations during a chemical treatment.
An aromatic (cyclic or ring structure) compound, present in very minor quantities in many crude oils.
A flow restriction common in downhole chokes, surface chokes and some SSSVs.
The first solid rock under loose sediments.
Breakdown of a heavier oil to a lighter hydrocarbon by bacterial action.

In the context of chemical treating, batch treating is the process of slugging a chemical such as a biocide or a corrosion inhibitor in high concentration to accomplish either placement or super concentrated treating.

The pressure at the bottom of the well.  In a producing well the BHP may be the bottom hole flowing pressure or the bottom hole shut-in pressure.  In a drilling or workover environment, the BHP is exerted by the column of fluid in the hole.
A test measuring the concentration or build-up of potential harmful chemicals in a living organism.

The deviation between 30o and 60o where refluxing (dropout and reverse flow) of particles and heavier liquid occurs in a lower rate well. The area in which gas bubbles may rise through fluid at 4 to 7 times that in a vertical well.
Barrels per day.
In the context of the drill string, breaking down is to separate the stands into single joints.
Reach final drilling depth.
A raised metal lip, e.g. around a perforation.
Bottom hole location.
Start circulating fluid from a static condition.
In the context of gravel packing, a beta wave is the returning wave of gravel after the alpha wave when packing a well over about 55&deg deviation.
Bending strength ratio.
An NMR log that measures bound fluid volume.
A plug run to seal off tubing.
A chemical process that changes the state of a clay or other mineral to make it meet specific performance levels.
Return flow from injection of a fluid into a formation.
In the context of tool operation, a ball is a steel, aluminum, brass or plastic ball pumped or dropped downhole to shift or operate a tool.
Bright Water™ is the trademarked name for a water control product.
A segment of geoscience where fossils are used to date or identify a reservoir.

In the context of scales, a barium sulfate (BaSO4) scale is produced in the well and in facilities as the result of precipitation when incompatible waters (one having Ba ion and the other SO4 ion) are mixed or when the equilibrium of the flowing fluid reduced and a precipitate is triggered by over saturation or a physical upset. May also be associated with radioactivity or NORM scale when a radium or uranium isotope is part of the crystalline lattice structure.
A device that injected balls into the flowing treating fluid downstream of the high pressure pump.
Unproductive rocks, usually igneous or metamorphic, at the bottom of a sedimentary rock sequence.
Bottom hole closed in pressure.
Bottom hole compensated sonic.
A theory of acoustic propagation in porous and elastic media that taken into account fluid behaviors.
An outside annulus, one out from the A annulus, usually production casing x production casing or surface casing.  (Note, there may be regional differences in the A, B, C annulus designations)
A device run in the drill string just above the mill to catch cuttings.

Making a kriging estimate over an area. For example, to estimate the average value at a grid cell, the grid cell is discretized into subcells, a kriging estimate is made for each subcell, and then these are averaged together to produce a single value. This final value is placed at the original grid node.

A cement plug, set with no downhole flow conditions, which allows temporary or permanent shut-off in a well.  It takes into account the densities of all fluid columns, both in the string and in the annulus.
Bottom hole sample.
In the context of perforating, BH abbreviates bigh hole charge.
The amount of weight that is offset by lift from the fluid when the piece of equipment is immersed in the fluid.
A flow control valve that provides some control when running or pulling a string.
Bottom hole gauge.
Bicarbonate of soda, used in acid neutralization operations.

Forcing fluids in the pipe into the formation at a pressure higher than the pore pressure and sometimes higher than the fracturing breakdown pressure.  Used to displace a kick out of the pipe when wellbore and wellhead pressure limits permits.Wells with short open hole sections and zones of high permeability respond better to bullheading than wells with long open hole sections and low permeability zones.
Cutting across surrounding strata.
Usually offshore,  a platform from which wells can be drilled. It may be permanent (with legs grouted into the seafloor to depths of several hundred feet), anchored or dynamically positioned.
A term used to express hardness, usually of rubbers or elastomers.

That quantity of petroleum which is estimated, on a given date, to be contained in known accumulations, plus those quantities already produced therefrom.  Discovered Petroleum-initially-in-place may be subdivided into Commercial and Sub-commercial categories, with the estimated potentially recoverable portion being classified as Reserves and Contingent Resources respectively (SPE).
In the context of risk, deterministic estimate is an estimate using a single number value.  It does not account for ranges in value or probability of occurrence for the parameter.
The process of forming a sedimentary rock from the clastic grains. May also be in conjunction with several geochemical processes such as cementation reactions and chemical dissolution.
Data acquisition system.
Downhole diagnostics.
In the context of perforating, a drop bar is a bar dropped from surface to set off a TCP gun in a near vertical well.

The small chips and fines generated by drilling through a formation with a drill bit.  Most of the cuttings are removed from the mud as the fluid pass through the solids control equipment (e.g., shakers, screens, cyclones, etc.,) at the surface.
Condensate liquid, or natural gasoline.
Crystals of dolomite in the pore space.  May turn loose when acidized and become migrating fines.
A measurement of how completely a flooding fluid displaces the saturated fluid in a reservoir.
A large igneous intrusion that cuts through the sedimentary layers, creating permeability barriers.
Spring loaded blocks on a packer or other tool that contact the pipe wall, producing resistance to movement.  They aid in setting of packers.

In a seismic context, density contrast is the density of one rock relative to another.  The contrast can be positive or negative. Gravity anomalies within sedimentary sections can be analyzed as structural or lithologic anomalies.
An oil capable of conversion from a liquid to a solid in the presence of air.
A pipe where the fluid flow path is down. Fluid return pipe.
Dual laterolog.
Deep water development
The published drift diameter for a pipe that describes the diameter of a tool that can pass through the pipe when the pipe is vertical (no doglegs).
Dummy gas lift valve.
The direction going down the tilt angle of the formation.

A controlled production of a small amount of fluid from an isolated section of the pay zone into the chamber formed by the drill pipe and a downhole valve. Drillstem tests measure pressures, some elements of depletion, and gather samples of the produced fluids. Abbreviated as DST.
Production originating inside a specific country of reference.
A hanger, usually screwed onto the end of the top tubing joint and lowered into the slip bowl of the wellhead.
Drilling through the cement after a primary cement job as the hole is deepened.
The fluid used to drill the pay zone.
The solution gas associated with produced fluids.
Downhole permanent gauge.
Drive down bailer.
A well with an inclination other than zero degrees from vertical.  In practice, deviated wells are usually more than about 10o from vertical.
Seismograph.
Removal of condensed or produced fluids from a low rate gas well.
The slope of the production rate vs. cumulative time or volume measurement.  The decline of a well predicts how fast it is being depleted.
A pump-down fluid separation device.  May also be used to operate tools downhole by hydraulic forces.
A well that does not have or produce commercial deposits of hydrocarbons.
A seismic-derived map showing the geometry of subsurface structure in terms of depth coordinates.  See time-structure map.

Soil in which the clay has dispersed. A dispersed soil consists of discrete soil particles which are not segregated into aggregates or structural peds. The soil macropores become clogged with soil particles and greatly restrict water and air movement into and through the soil.

A procedure to determine the productive capacity, pressure, permeability or extent (or a combination of these) of a hydrocarbon reservoir. While several different proprietary hardware sets are available to accomplish this, the common idea is to isolate the zone of interest with temporary packers. Next, one or more valves are opened to produce the reservoir fluids through the drillpipe and allow the well to flow for a time. Finally, the operator kills the well, closes the valves, removes the packers and trips the tools out of the hole. Depending on the requirements and goals for the test, it may be of short (one hour or less) or long (several days or weeks) duration and there might be more than one flow period and pressure buildup period. Drill Stem Test.
In the context of lift systems, a dead line is that part of a wireline or cable that is attached to a fixed anchor point and does not move through a pulley or other mechanical device.

In the context of risk, a decision tree is a sequence of nodes which are either a decision or an uncertainty, and outcomes associated with each mode. The purpose of a decision tree is to define the set of scenarios and the sequence of events that guide the evaluation of risk and return. It is displayed as a pictorial device, consisting of nodes and branches, that describes two or more courses of action and the resulting uncertainties with probabilities of occurrence, as well as possible subsequent actions and uncertainties. The solution to the tree consists of a preferred course of action or path along the tree, together with the resulting expected value.
US Department Of Energy.
This is the internationally accepted unit of specific conductance (or electrical conductivity) which is numerically equal to mmhos/cm.

An induction log with dual and deep measurements of resistivity. Shallow measurements are indicative of severely invaded zone and the deepest measurements are most reflective of actual formation fluids.
Downhole continuous injection systems
The conditions of sediment transport and deposition at the time the formations were laid down.
The wire rope used to position tools on the floor.  Also used to describe the wire rope on a cable tool rig.
Driller’s measured depth.
A foam breaking chemical.
In a subsea context, DXV stands for direct crossover valve.
A well dispersed, high solids content liquid that has very high apparent viscosity with any applied shear.
See deciSiemens/meter
Dump bailer.
The rock cutting device at the bottom of the drill string.
A secondary well, after a field discovery well, drilled to help determine field extent, volume or potential rate.
May be either downhole TV camera or a televiewer (a sonic caliper tool).
A well that will not flow on its own through natural gas lift or by reservoir pressure.
In a seismic context, depth migration is the data processing used to shift subsurface signals to their proper depth.
Drilling engineer.
Calcium/magnesium carbonate rock.  Dolomite is formed by chemical modification of a limestone.
Damping is the dissipation of energy with time or distance.
Different metals that may form an anode-cathode pair in corrosion cell conditions.
The total change in angle of a wellbore in a given distance.
A section of the BOP that allows side ports for choke and kill lines.

An accounting method under which Net Income includes charges or credits equal to the decreases or increases in current taxes on income, arising from the use of liberalized depreciation or accelerated amortization for tax purposes instead of the straight-line method. The contra entries for such charges to Net Income are suspended in Balance Sheet accounts. In future years, there is a feedback of these suspended amounts to Net Income when increases in the then current taxes on income occur because liberalized depreciation or accelerated amortization was used for tax purposes in prior years (From AGA).
The random scattering of particles due to kinetic energy of the particles. Affected by viscosity, density and temperature.
Working platform for the derrickman on a drilling rig.
Deferred production.
A filler piece used to close a gap in piping or equipment alignment.
Silica particles from Diatom beds.  Used as a filtering media and as an additive to cement.
The recovery stoke downward on a beam pump where the pump is filling with fluid by pushing the open traveling valve through the standing fluid.
In a seismic context, the density-depth function shows that the change in density with increasing depth is often a result of compaction. Age, lithology and porosity modification are also factors.
A reservoir drive mechanism in which dissolved gas from the crude oil breaks out of solution and provides energy to push the hydrocarbons toward the wellbore.
