Refers to the frequency and duration of periods of saturation or partial saturation during soil formation, as opposed to altered drainage, which is commonly the result of artificial drainage or irrigation but may be caused by the sudden deepening of channels or the blocking of drainage outlets. The following seven classes of natural soil drainage are recognized:
Commonly written D&A.

A small fracture treatment, without proppant, pumped into a well to assess fracture breakdown pressure, fracture extension pressure, fluid loss coefficient, frac fluid efficiency and fracture closure time.
In an accounting context, DCF is discounted cash flow.
Drill in fluid.
Drill site.
Drilling.
A wireline or tubing run into a well with a dummy piece of equipment of the same size, shape and stiffness of a valuable or unrecoverable piece of equipment to make sure the equipment can be placed.
A sand particle size distribution obtained by shaking a sample of sand through a series of sieves or screens.
Commonly written DD&A.

In the context of gas effects on seals, decompression damage occurs when pressure is dropped rapidly, gas that has permeated the elastomers and some plastics may rupture the surface of a material when the gas expansion caused by the decompression is faster than the gas can pass through the substance.  Most severe in weak tensile-strength materials.
Fluids with materials added to disperse solids or flocs.
Dipole sonic.

Relating to the energy of the transport mechanism that carries particles into an area of deposition.  Low energy environments may contain large quantities of fines where high energy environments are usually marked by larger and more consistent grain sizes.
A deliberate shut off of a zone by a downhole valve or other method, to prevent cross flow.
Distributed control system.
A flow bean (restriction) set in a profile near the bottom of the well.  Used as a flow regulator and to take part of the pressure drop downhole to reduce the potential of hydrates.
Draw down.
The components below the traveling block to which the elevators are attached.
One of a number of logging techniques that estimate the density of the formation.
Drilling the wellbore in a planned trajectory.
High clay content or higher natural radioactivity signature on the gamma-ray log.
The sonic travel time in microseconds per foot, of a sound wave through the formation.  Denser formations (generally better consolidated and cemented) have lower (faster) delta times.
A full opening valve with threads that match the drill pipe that can be quickly screwed onto the pipe to help control fluid flow up the tubing.
A chemical additive, usually a surfactant, that helps break emulsions.
Crude oil without gas.  May have been degassed mechanically or by gas breakout during storage.
In the context of fluidflow, drag is the force on a solid surface exerted by a fluid flowing past it.
Downhole safety valve.
Diameter to thickness ratio, a common comparison value in steel pipe.
In a depth context, DC is depth correction.
In a seismic context, DMO stands for dip movement offset. The difference in arrival times at various sensors due to the dip of the surface off of which the signals are reflecting.
A common method of pipe sticking where the overbalance pressure in the wellbore pushes the tubing against the side of the wellbore in a permeable formation.
The outer limit to which a logging tool can measure properties with a give accuracy.

A collective term for the sum of proved and indicated reserves. Proved reserves are estimated with reasonable certainty to be recovered under current economic conditions. Indicated reserves are economic reserves in known productive reservoirs in existing fields expected to respond to improved recovery techniques where (1) an improved technique has been installed but its effect cannot yet be fully evaluated, or (2) an improved technique has not been installed but knowledge of reservoir characteristics and the results of a known technique installed in a similar situation are available for use in the estimating procedure. (American Petroleum Institute)
The mass per volume of a substance. Density of fresh water is 8.33 pounds per gallon or 1 gram/cc.
In the context of cementing, a dropper is the housing with valves and bails that controls the position and dropping of the plugs used in cementing.

The term applied to a petroleum accumulation/reservoir whose existence has been determined by its actual penetration by a well, which has also clearly demonstrated the existence of moveable petroleum by flow to the surface or at least some recovery of a sample of petroleum.  Log and/or core data may suffice for proof of existence of moveable petroleum if an analogous reservoir is available for comparison. (See also "Known Accumulation" - Petroleum quantities that are discovered are in "known accumulations" or "known reservoirs").
A damped natural frequency is a natural frequency with friction.
Drilling, recompletion and repair data base.

In the context of production, dry gas is a gas stream without condensate.  Note:   even dry gas at bottom hole conditions may have up to two barrels of water vapor per million standard cubic ft of gas.  Dry gas on the process side has all liquids removed.
Drilling Information Management System.
A relative comparison point, such as the Kelly bushing, sea level or mud line.
A type of pump with two, dual acting pistons.
Remove from service.
The release of materials that have been absorbed or adsorbed in or onto a formation.
The porosity formed by chemical and bacterial modification after the initial sediments were laid down.
A diesel fuel, C10-C14+ typically.  #1 Diesel has paraffins removed for cleaner operation or cold weather use.
Removal of salts from saline soil, usually by leaching.

Two successive plugs, each capable of holding maximum pressure, with a vent between them capable of bleeding off all pressure between the plugs.  Also – a valve with two seating surfaces which, in the closed position, blocks flow from both valve ends when the cavity between the seating surfaces is vented through a bleed connection on the body cavity. Commonly written DB&B.
A crew or records shack at a lease or on a rig.
Dynamic oil recovery
Separation of liquids and solids in the general sense. Also removing water from hydrocarbon streams.
A formation sizing criteria that shows impact of fines.
Downhole tools and equipment that can be broken up by the bit.
An offshore well with the wellhead and access to the well at the surface.
Explosive wrapped with elastomer in the shape of a cord.  Used to link and detonate charges in perforating guns.
The temperature at which liquids begin to condense from the vapor phase in a gas stream. (see also bubble point).
Separation of groups of data from either other or from a norm.
A deposit of sand produced by wind or running water.  The dune may be massive, but usually lower energy and permeability varies.
A plug that is commonly set in the tubing hanger above the tubing or in tubing immediately below the wellhead for wellhead isolation.
All material which passes through a filter having a pore size of 0.45 iJm.
A geological time between 365 million and 405 million years ago.
Any of a variety of downhole cameras, including full motion video, recording memory camera, sequence sending cameras, etc.  Used to get a better picture of the wellbore or a fish.
A sudden increase in the ROP (rate of penetration) while drilling. May indicate a higher pressure formation, a change in lithology, a naturally fractured zone, or a poorly consolidated zone.
A tube from the intake of a pump that extends further into the liquid column of the well, to keep gas out of the pump.
A shaped bit body with diamonds for abrasive cutting of the formation. Also called a diamond mill.
Det Norske Veritas a classification and qualification setting business.
The angle that the structural surface or bedding plane or fault surface makes with the horizontal.  Measured perpendicular to the strike and in the vertical plane.
Corrosion occurring under or around a deposit on a surface.
Actual term is inclination -  the angle from vertical in a section of a well.
The internal phase in an emulsion – i.e., the droplets or bubbles.
A perforating charge with a liner shape designed to create a long penetration into the formation, but a smaller entrance hole in the pipe.  See also Big Hole Charge.

A measurement of permeability (ability of fluids to flow through the rock). The relationship is an empirical law which states that the velocity of flow through porous media is directly proportional to the hydraulic gradient, assuming that the flow is laminar and inertia can be neglected.
Any substance that aids in breaking up a mass of individual particles, bubbles or droplets.
Diaminopropanoltetraacetic acid, a calcium scale remover and solvent.
The primary process for Life of Field resource management. The Depletion plan sets out the framework of how Resource Management underpins efficient exploration of the resource.
A recording of the stresses in a rod string of a beam pumping unit.
Drilling, milling and under-reaming.
The elevated section of a rig that rises above the substructure and houses the crown block and draw works.
A seal in a system where motion is expected in the seal or the seal area.
A device used for reading the density of a flowing fluid or slurry.
To remove rough edges, flares, burrs, etc. from a piece of equipment prior to fishing.
A grain of a sedimentary formation that was transported from its origin and deposited as a whole grain in the matrix of the rock.
Devices that typically use centrifugal flow paths to spin solids out of a drilling or circulating fluid. Also known as desilter.
A device in the line filled with gas that may reduce the surges of pressure pulsation or flow slugging. Also spelled dampener.
Reducing the fluid content of a formation by production of that fluid.
Limited aerial sands.
Burning, decomposition or low order detonation of explosive.

An accounting procedure under which current Net Income reflects decreases or increases in current taxes on income, arising from the use of liberalized depreciation or accelerated amortization for tax purposes instead of the straightline method. See Depreciation, Normalized (From AGA).
A section of pipeline that is not in use.
In the context of pipes, doubles are two joints screwed together.
The action of placing a hole to a depth and location.
Selective corrosion of one metal in an alloy.

A method of computing depreciation under which equal annual amounts are set aside for the ultimate retirement of the property at the end of its service life. For a property with an assumed 25-year life, the annual charge would be 4% per year, usually applied to the cost of the property less estimated net salvage (From AGA).
The transport, refining and product making part of the oil business.
An atom that results from the radioactive decay of a parent atom.
A material that does not conduct electricity or has only a low electrical conductivity compared to a metal.
The vertical displacement of a fault along the dip plane.
A method of depreciation whereby the asset is depreciated over an estimated life expressed in units of output rather than over an estimated life expressed as a period of time (From AGA).
In a cementing context, a DV tool is a stage tool.
The API gravity.
A salt or other column that pierces upper layers and may form traps of obstructions to flow.
The rate at which a population of radioactive atoms decays into stable daughter atoms. Rate expressed in half-life of the parent isotope.
A formation that comes apart or disaggregates or separation of grains.
In the context of a gas lift, DPC stands for sasing pressure at depth – the true gas weight at depth.
In a seismic context, DZO stands for demigration to zero offset. An improvement in seismic processing over dip movement offset where signal velocity varies significantly with depth.

This refers to certain approved methods of computing depreciation allowance for federal and/or state income tax purposes. These methods permit relatively larger depreciation charges during the earlier years, in contrast to the straight-line method, under which the annual charges are the same for each year. This is sometimes referred to as accelerated depreciation (From AGA).
A model for which every input variable, and hence each output variable as well, is given exactly one value, in contrast to a probabilistic model.
A change in the formation that may have been caused by ancient erosional forces. Accounts for variances in formation tops in near-by offset wells in a formation with no pay inclination.
A type of lock used in a profile.
Deep draft caisson vessel.
In the context of an offshore rig, DP stands for dynamically positioned.
A record of the deviation angle and the departure usually on a depth unit basis.
The equipment at the surface used to lift and run the drilling string, provide the rotation and pump fluids down the string.
Natural gasoline or low carbon chain liquids, condensed from the rich gas from a well.
A dry hole.
A sorting criteria useful in screen selection.

One of the liberalized methods of computing depreciation, normally used for tax purposes. Under this method, the annual deduction is derived by multiplying the cost of the property less estimated net salvage, by the estimated number of years of service life remaining, and dividing the resultant product by the sum of all the digits would be 25+24+23+22+ etc. +5+4+3+2+1 or 325. A simple way to compute this figure would be to multiply the number of years by the number of years plus one and divide by 2, i.e., (25 X 26)/2 = 325. The first year's full depreciation deduction would be 25/325ths,  the second year's would be 24/325ths, etc., of the cost of the property (From AGA).
In the context of a pipe gauge, drift is the minimum id of tubing through which a standard drift tool will pass.
A corrosion resistant alloy with chrome and nickel as common components.
Applied to a random variable, having either a finite or a countably infinite range of possible values, such as the binomial or Poisson variables.
The fluid added to a concentrated mixture to reduce the concentration of an internal phase or reduce its viscosity.
A hollow tube with a flapper or other opening valve at the bottom, run on wireline to place cement or sand in a well.
Deep mater production.

Converting a continuous distribution to a discrete distribution by subdividing the X -range. The discrete variable has values equal to the means of the subranges and probabilities equal to the chance that the variable would fall into that subrange.
A program, typically in surface facilities and lines, to remove pressure drop causing flow restrictions.
The initial well in the field that tests hydrocarbons. (NOTE:   there is a difference between a discovery and an exploratory well. The first well which reaches the oil is the "discovery".
Downhole flow control.
See Depreciation, Liberalized.
Non steady state flow or flow with changing conditions.

A rock with a higher permeability along a given plane, usually created by natural fracture development, water flow that leaches the pores, depositional environment or localized reworking of the sediments.
The ratio of the weight of any constituent of a soil to the oven-dry weight of the soil (constant weight at 105°C).
A heavy wall tubing used for drilling.
Deep water, usually inaccessible by a fixed (non floating) platform.
Any device that helps remove gas from circulated fluid.
Removal of a part of the water downhole followed by injection of the water into a disposal zone.
Typically, rotating components in a drill string.

One of the liberalized methods of computing depreciation (normally used for tax purposes). Under this method, the depreciation rate is stated as a fixed percentage per year and the annual charge is derived by applying the rate to the net plant balance, which is determined by subtracting the accumulated depreciation reserve (From AGA).

A system of tax depreciation which enables a corporation to choose any life falling within 20% of the designated class life for determining its annual depreciation charge. ADR requires an annual election and all depreciation records must be maintained by vintage year (From AGA).
A solid body (non flowable) gas lift valve that “dummies off” a gas lift mandrel to seal the GLM or pocket.
A mixture of an internal phase of solids, droplets or bubbles that stay relatively suspended in a continuous fluid.
A measurement of the well path that records the inclination and azimuth of the wellbore using a compass or other device.

In the context of reservoirs, developed reserves are expected to be recovered from existing wells including reserves behind pipe. Improved recovery reserves are considered developed only after the necessary equipment has been installed, or when the costs to do so are relatively minor. Developed reserves may be sub-categorized as producing or non-producing (SPE).
In the context of a packer, a double grip is slips that prevent either upward or downward movement.
Daily drilling report.

In a seismic context, deconvolution is an automated profile-based depth estimation method derived from analysis of magnetic anomalies in sheet-like bodies.  Polynomials can be simultaneously solved to estimate the depth, dip, horizontal location and susceptibility (magnetic) of the surface or structure. Basically undoing the effects of a filter. (Using Werner)
The distance from the kelly bushing horizontally to the end of the well.
A blasting cap.
The difference in pressure between upstream and downstream of a measurement point.
The tested and proved ability of a well to produce.
Drill well on paper exercise.
Dog leg severity.

A term that expresses the quantity of dissolved material in a sample of water, either the residue on evaporation, dried at 180°C, or, for many waters that contain more than about 1,000 ppm, the sum of determined constituents, generally reported in mg/L.
A safety system designed to automatically shut in the wellbore in the event of a simultaneous absence of hydraulic supply and control of both subsea control pods.
De Militarised Zone (computer network).
Dual induction log.
Hoisting mechanism on a drilling rig.
A symmeatrical upfold of the layers of rock in which the beds dip in all directions more or less equally from a common point,  any deformation characterized by a circular local uplift.
To sharpen a bit or replace components of a tool.
In the context of flow, DRA stands for drag reduction agent.
A type of grease having some extra material like Zn or Pb. Dope is used to lubricate and seal the threaded connection.
The lower limit of analysis for a test of a piece of equipment for a specified measurement.
A very heavy wall pipe used to add weight over the bit during drilling.
In a governmental context, D.O.T. is the Department of Transportation – a US government agency.
All the equipment in a drilling BHA plus the drill pipe.
Diesel.
The separation of a compound or molecule into pieces, ions, or atoms.
Commonly written D&C.
A log of temperature along the entire length of the interval, well or flow path.
A sudden change in the direction of the wellbore. Generally based on degrees per 100 ft.
Distributed temperature sensor or survey.
Downhole power unit.
When the formation breaks into grains.
A log that measures the inclination of the formation beds.
Dispersing a clump or a gathering or “flocculated” of particles.  Usually accomplished by dispersants or solvent thinners.
Devices used to separate gasses from liquids.
Deep propagation log.
Mouth of river deposits, usually fan shaped with significant variation in composition, sorting and thickness. Quality of the reservoir rock may vary widely.
Two pay zones in the same well that produce up independent flow paths in the same well.
A range of manufactured products from the refining processes, includes kerosene, diesel, bunker C oil, fuel oil, heating oil, etc.
A log that measures the resistivity of the formation.
Surface reading, downhole located gauges capable of measuring pressure, temperature and/or flow rate.
A treating vessel designed to remove water from a process stream.
Hydrocarbon production that is delayed due to any of several reasons, specifically well repairs, restrictions that curtail production, regulations, etc.

A connector with shallow holes into the body and threads on the other for attaching a BHA to coiled tubing.  The end with shallow holes is slipped into the coiled tubing and a clamp-on device with set screws is used to deform the coiled tubing wall into the dimple.
Diagnostic fracture injection test
Wells that are drilled after the discovery and appraisal wells to develop the hydrocarbon production potential of the field.
A term used to describe a surface or a seismic reflection that cuts across geologic time (dia=across, chrono=time).  See chronostratigraphic and stratal surface.
Dual porosity CNL.
Various – usually allowing water to gravity feed into the annulus (without packer) or the tubing and into the formation.
A mechanical level that pushes a tool against the side of the well.
A well into which fluids such as produced water and some liquid wastes can be injected.  It is in a non hydrocarbon, non-fresh water sand and is not connected to the hydrocarbon bearing formation.
Where rock changes produces a reservoir rock under a sealing rock.
Downhole controller.
In the context of acidizing, a diverter is a material that forces acid to enter another zone by having a higher viscosity or building a filter cake.
The ability of a rock to expand through micro-fractures in consolidated rocks or grain position shifts in unconsolidated rocks.
Fluid flow effects in spooled tubing.
The daily report on activities, results, and shows of the past 24 hours.
In the context of perforating, DUB stands for dynamic underbalance perforating.
The fluid, water, oil or gas based, that is used to establish well control, transport cuttings to the surface, provides fluid loss control, lubricates the string and cools the bottom hole assembly.
Often massive deposits of coccolith fragments.  Usually very high porosity and limited permeability unless fractured.
In the context of propellant fracturing, a dynamic event is an event such pressure surge or fracturing that occur over a few hundred milliseconds.
DHV is a downhole video.
The difference between two pressures.  Completion drawdown is the pressure differential from the formation near the wellbore to the wellbore.
In the context of produced fluids, dynamic viscosity is the viscosity of the fluid in the reservoir at the reservoir conditions. Note – associated gas reduces the viscosity of most oils.
A list of interest owners and their share of revenues.
In the context of a horizontal well, displacement is the distance between the wellhead and the top of a vertical line from the bottom hole location to the wellhead elevation at the surface.
A general term commonly referring to an obstruction in the flow path.
The total energy transferred as heat in an ideal combustion reaction at standard temperature and pressure in which all water formed appears as a liquid.
Natural gasoline or low carbon chain liquids, condensed from the rich gas from a well.
A collection of numbers, each called a statistic, such as mean, median, standard deviation, and skewness, that describes a set of data; also the process of calculating these numbers.
A pipe connection with a smaller I.D. than the pipe but a consistent O.D. Abbreviated IU.
A special truck equipped with a small pump and an inhibitor checmical tank used to treat wells on a scheduled basis.
An emulsion that has swapped the internal phase to the external phase.
Corrosion along the grain boundaries of a metal.
A fluid diversion technique using density of the fluid to place fluids or other materials at a specific location in the well.
Iron carbonate, iron sulfide and other forms of scale deposits containing iron.
Interfacial tension.
A multi-rate drawdown and build-up test with different drawdowns of the same duration but buildups reaching stabilization.
International Organization for Standardization, a network of national standards institutes of 146 countries, based in Geneva, Switzerland.
Adding new wells in an existing field within the original well patterns to accelerate recovery or to test recovery methods.

A map created by post-processing conditional simulations that shows the value of the regionalized variable at a constant probability threshold, e.g., at the 10th, 50th (median), or 90th percentile. Isoprobability maps provide a level of confidence in the mapped results.
Filtration control by particles smaller than the pore bridging size that invade the pores and bridge within the pore throats.  Often very difficult to remove.
Invert emulsion mud.
A downhole valve in an injection well designed to prevent backflow if the injection is stopped.
IRIS™ is the trademarked name for an intelligent remote implementation system.
Medium induction log.
Integrated asset modeling.
In place or inside the formation.
A perforating gun effect in which the firing of charges overlap slightly with the effect of one charge affecting the development of a jet in another with the result of reduced penetration.
Inner annulus pressure.
That part of the drilling and completion expenses that have no practical salvage value.

Coiled tubing handling device that provides pulling and injection power.  Usually powered by two to four motors that transmit the forces to the coil through chains equipped with specially shaped couplers.
Inner annulus to outer annulus.

The phase of a complex seismic trace at a specified time coordinate along that trace.  Instantaneous phase is the inverse tangent of the ratio: real part of the complex trace divided by imaginary part of the complex trace.  See complex seismic trace.
Injection choke model.  A model that helps identify critical junctures in injection support.
Water-in-oil emulsion muds. There may be as much as 50% brine in the liquid.

A pipe connection device that sits on the rig floor or is suspended just above the floor.  It combines lead and backup tongs with a integral spinning table to spin the top joint during make-up or break-out.
Injection gas lift ratio.
International safety rating system.
A downhole recording or log that shows where fluids are leaving the well bore. It is used to establish injection profile and to check for leaks and crossflow.
Isopropyl alcohol.
At the same time.
A constant heat loss/gain applied to a calculation and a temperature or pressure can be adjusted to meet this new heat content (around fluid equilibrium considerations).

The average rate of water entering the soil under irrigation. Most soils have a fast initial rate; the rate decreases with application time. Therefore, intake rate for design purposes is not constant but is a variable depending on the net irrigation application. The rate of water intake (in inches per hour) is expressed as follows
The downward entry of water into the soil.
A mechanical, chemical or explosive device capable of severing the pipe from the inside.
In a seismic context, IGRF stands for International Geomagnetic Reference Field.
A map that shows points of similar pressure in a field.
Absorption and adsorption of fluids into the pores of the rock.

Principally goethite (FeOOH) and hematite (Fe203) in soils. A very small amount of goethite gives soil a yellow color and a very small amount of hematite gives soil a red color. These minerals are common in most soils and are abundant in highly weathered soils in the tropics. Both goethite and hematite have pH dependent charges. At high pH they have a negative charge and a cation exchange capacity. At low pH they have a positive charge and an an ion exchange capacity. In most soils, iron oxides help to stabilize soil aggregates. Red soils are indicative of a high degree of oxidation. Yellow soils are also oxidized but less intensively than red soils. Red and yellow mottles (spots) in a soil are often indicative of a fluctuating water table. In water logged soils the iron in goethite and hematite has become soluble and leached out of the soil leaving a chalky gray color. If these soils are drained, any remaining iron rapidly oxidizes and forms oxides exhibited by new yellow or red coloring.

A soft lead flat end or cone bottom on a steel tool.  The impression block can give ideas on what it is set down upon.  Usually run via slickline and set down once to get an imprint. Also derisively called a confusion block.
A reservoir that acts during a short term test as if it had no boundaries.
A pressure multiplier device use to assist pumping in high pressure well work.
A map that shows contours between points of equal formation thickness. It may also show depth of the zone.
Inflow performance relationship.  The relationship that shows inflow as a function of drawdown.  Changes with time.
A piece of downhole equipment from which gauges and instruments can be suspended.

The relationship between reservoir or pore pressure, flowing bottom hole pressure, and production rate. Can be calculated from reservoir properties (reservoir pressure, permeability, skin) or can be a curve fitted to experimental data from the well.
A clay type of varying form and composition. Rarely water sensitive.  May occur in unusual cases as a fiberous deposit that can act as a particle trap.
A theoretical gas that perfectly obeys PV=RT/m, where V is the specific volume, T is the absolute temperature, R is the universal gas constant, and m is the molecular weight.
Burning a small part of the hydrocarbon to provide heat to reduce the viscosity of thermally crack the heavier ends. See Fire Flood.
Inflatable bridge plug.
-Total opposition (resistance, capacitance and inductance), expressed in Ohms, to the flow of current.
All phases of management of the well pressure seal integrity as a principal, critical objective.
A modeling technique for 2D or 3D seismic where density, susceptibility or geologic data is calculated or matched to an observed gravity or magnetic field.
Ion exchange (cation or anion) where scaling or water hardening minerals such as calcium and magnesium are removed by substitution for sodium.
Water within the pores.
International Coiled Tubing Operators Association.
Open-hole log that measures resistance difference between formation and wellbore fluids to various depths in the formation.
A chemical that slows a reaction between a reactive fluid and a material.  Specifically, acid corrosion inhibitors slow the reaction of acids on steels.
Injection subsurface safety valve.
No variation in properties with direction.
Map showing equal points of a specific fluid saturation.
The direction in which receiver lines are deployed.  See crossline.

Any of various methods, chiefly reservoir drive mechanisms and enhanced recover techniques, designed to improve the flow of hydrocarbons from the reservoir to the wellbore or to recover more oil after the primary and secondary methods (water and gas floods) are uneconomic. Abbreviated IOR.
The measurement of a wells deviation from vertical.  When used with fluids, a positive number indicates upflow and a negative number may represent downflow.
Fossils specific to a certain geologic time.

The fraction of the pore space occupied by water when the hydrocarbon content is at maximum.  This level of water can only be reduced by flow of very dry gas that evaporates the water.  Typically shown as Swirr.
A device with metal slats or cords woven around a rubber bladder with an elastomer cover designed to inflate in the wellbore and provide isolation.
An activation log.
Infinitely variable internal control valve.
Slope of inflow performance relationship for injection.  Bbl/psi or m3/bar.
In the context of completion, ICV stands for internal control valve.
The amplitude of a complex seismic trace at a specified time coordinate along that trace.  Instantaneous amplitude is not the same as trace amplitude.  See complex seismic trace.
The stresses on the formation imposed by the overlying overburden and tectonic forces. The stresses are at least partially offset by the fluids in the pores of the formation.

In thermodynamics and phase behavior, intensive properties are those that are independent of the amount of the phases (e.g., phase density, pressure and temperature).  Intensive properties can be determined as the ratio of two extensive properties  (e.g., molar density is the number of moles divided by total volume).

The average rate of water entering the soil under irrigation. Most soils have a fast initial rate; the rate decreases with application time. Therefore, intake rate for design purposes is not constant but is a variable depending on the net irrigation application. The rate of water intake (in inches per hour) is expressed as follows:
The manner in which water is artificially applied to an area. The methods and the manner of applying the water are as follows
A condition of a rock or soil hardened or consolidated by pressure, cementation, or heat.
Young crude or crude that has not been thermally “processed” by heat to generate lighter ends (short carbon chains) and gas.
Integrity management standard.

Gas lift valves where injection gas enters the valve and acts on the effective bellows area, overcoming the precharge in the valve and opening the valve (the retracting bellows lifts the needle off the seat) to allow gas lift gas flow from the gas filled annulus through the seat and the reverse flow check valve, and into the tubing.
A time cycle controller that controls gas injection to improve lift.
Inner annulus.
Integrated field planning.
The part of the rock next to the wellbore into which wellbore fluid has leaked.
The pore pressure in a reservoir at the time of discovery.
The rotating pump component that drives the fluid in a centrifugal pump.
Isopropyl alcohol.
A firm that operates in both the upstream and downstream areas of the energy industry.
Inside casing gravel pack where no gravel is placed into the perforations.
Interval pressure transient test.
An incident wave is a wave going into a geometric or material discontinuity.
In a subsea context, IWOCS stands for integrated workover control system.
An indurated soil horizon in which iron oxide is the principle cementing agent.
A valve installed inside the drill stem to prevent flow up the inside of the pipe.
A flange with plastic gasket and bolt isolation devices to stop electrical conductance.

A well either specifically drilled, or, more likely, a poor producer that is converted to inject fluids to stabilize the decline of pressure in a productive zone.  An injector is required to have a pressure connection to the pay and to a producing well.  Water is typically injected at the base of the pay or, in a gas well, or gas is injected into the gas cap.
Flow rate, often from a short test, measured during a test at or just before completion.
The frequency of a complex seismic trace at a specified time coordinate along that trace.  Instantaneous frequency is the time derivative of instantaneous phase.  See complex seismic trace.
A pump run on a sucker rod string and set in a pump barrel, then powered with the sucker rod pump.
Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers.
Gasification of an underground coal seam by injection of air.
A tool that operates by pipe rotation or reciprocation.
Gas injected into the reservoir to maintain pressure.
The ratio of the rate of injection to rate of production.  A target may be as high as 1.0, although it is seldom achieved.
Intermediate strength proppant.
Inflow.
A brown, gelatinous precipitate that comes out of a spent acid solution when the acid spends completely or when the Ferrous Iron (+2) in solution at pH >1.8 oxidizes to Ferric iron (+3).
The pump pressure required when a shut-in well that has taken a kick is circulated after initially opening the well.
International Association of Drilling Contractors.
Instantaneous underbalance device.
Integrated porosity logging.
In the context of an injection well, II stands for injectivity index.
An early failure; often related to poor design, candidate selection or installation problems.
The maximum reading from a direct reading viscometer (e.g., Fann VG meter), after the fluid has set for ten seconds.
Corrosion along the grain boundaries of a metal.
Initial circulating pressure.

In risk analysis, impact (or consequence) is the effect on conditions or people if the hazard is realized (occurs) in practice and probability is the likelihood that the impact will occur. Risk is a function of probability and impact (consequence).
A soil through which water, air, or roots penetrate slowly or not at all. No soil is absolutely impervious to air and water all the time.
In the context of field capacity, IPC is installed production capacity including injectivity.
In the context of facilities, an IP is an intermediate pressure separator or separator train.
A general term meaning non-reactive with the materials with which it contacts.
One of several tubing configurations designed to reduce heat loss from the produced fluids.

An inflatable packer with a soft rubber shell.  It is inflated in an interval and then deflated; the rubber shell is a reverse cast of the imperfections in the well.  Used to confirm split pipe or perforation density.
In a drilling or workover context, invasion is the movement of one fluid into a permeable zone.
Deep induction log.
Chemicals that control the precipitation of iron from solution.
Independent Petroleum Association of America.
Inside diameter.
Often a casing string or liner run to isolate a zone between the surface casing and the final production casing.
In a chemical context, an indicator is a chemical in a titration reaction that changes color at a certain pH.
IGA or also called The International Geothermal Association.
A corrosion control mechanism in which a small charge is used to oppose the electrical current generated by a corrosion cell.  The current reduces metal loss at the anode.
Instrument Society of America.
Taking place at constant temperature.
Waters, which, when mixed, may cause a precipitate.
A chemical that assists the corrosion inhibitor in slowing corrosion in harsh conditions.
Initial shut-in pressure.  Used to isolate the formation fracturing or injection effect from the friction effects.
Gas lift where gas is periodically injected into the fluid column. Also called intermittent flow.
ISIS™ is the trademarked name for an integrated subsurface information surveillance.
Typically a non-integrated oil or natural gas company, usually active in a few sectors of the industry.
Oils with API gravity between 25 and 30.
In a well work sense, usually a non-rig well entry using wireline or CT intervention where the well head remains attached. Rigs may be used.  Compare to workover.
In the context of corrosion, inclusion is a nonmetallic phase such as an oxide, sulfide, or silicate particle in a metal.
The OD of the drift that will pass through the tube of a pipe.
Intermediate manifold facilities.
Inner casing.

A chemical that helps reduce the valiance state of iron from iron+3 (ferric) to iron +2 (ferrous) in non sour applications.  Helps prevent sludges that are triggered by iron and asphaltic crude in combination with salt water or acid.  May also help prevent iron precipitation in sweet wells.
Solidified molten rock. Specifically granites, etc.

Rock with passages so small that no effective flow can take place.  Note:   all manmade and natural substances have some permeability, given high pressure, time, enough surface area and a low permeability fluid.
Redirect to:
-In the context of a drilling point, yield point is the resistance to initial flow of a fluid or stress required to start fluid moving.
Also Youngs Modulus (E), is stress over strain. A measure of stiffness or Modulus of Elasticity. Rocks are ½ to 12 x 106 psi and mild steel is 30 x 106 psi.
Year end.

In the context of metal, yield strength is the stress at which a material exhibits a specified deviation from the proportionality of stress to strain.  The deviation is expressed in terms of strain by either the offset method (usually at a strain of 0.2%) or the total-extension-under-load method (usually at a strain of 0.5%).
Yield point, the point at which a fluid shears.
In the context of drilling fluid, yield is a measurement applied to clay dealing with the number of barrels of a set viscosity fluid that can be made from a given quantity of clay.
Universal transverse mercator. An orienting/origin defining system used in surveys.
Ultraviolet.

Undeveloped reserves are expected to be recovered:   (1) from new wells on undrilled acreage, (2) from deepening existing wells to a different reservoir, or (3) where a relatively large expenditure is required to (a) recomplete an existing well or (b) install production or transportation facilities for primary or improved recovery projects (SPE).
Lightening of a fluid column, usually by adding gas, until the fluid flows out of the well.
The base fluid without added salts or solids.
Form an operating unit with a operating company from a group of wells in the same field.
Water jetting at pressures over 25,000 psi.
IADC-UBO term.  Well capable of natural flow to surface, but conventional well kill methods are enabled, and limited consequences are possible in case of catastrophic equipment failure.
Under-reamer.

Unproved reserves are based on geologic and/or engineering data similar to that used in estimates of proved reserves; but technical, contractual, economic, or regulatory uncertainties preclude such reserves being classified as proved. Unproved reserves may be further classified as probable reserves and possible reserves. Unproved reserves may be estimated assuming future economic conditions different from those prevailing at the time of the estimate. The effect of possible future improvements in economic conditions and technological developments can be expressed by allocating appropriate quantities of reserves to the probable and possible classifications (SPE).

A pipe connection with thicker wall area at the coupling.  An external upset is thicker to the outside with a consistent I.D. with the pipe and is called an EU or EUE.  A connection upset to the inside (smaller ID but consistent O.D.) is an IU.
U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service, formerly known as Soil Conservation Service (USDA-SCS)
IADC-UBO term. Performance enhancement only; no zones containing hydrocarbons.
Underbalance drilling.

U238, one of the natural isotopes that as a trace element may incorporate into the matrix of naturally forming barium or strontium sulfate scale and make it a very low level radioactive material (NORM scale).
The maximum stress that a material can withstand.
A valve at the top of the kelly that can be closed in the event of a inside tubing kick or high pressures.
The oil producing end of the business.
In a decision tree, a node the emanating branches of which represent the various possible outcomes of some event with their values and probabilities of occurrence.
IADC-UBO term.  Hydrocarbon production. Maximum shut-in pressures are less than UBD equipment's operating pressure rating. Catastrophic failure has immediate, serious consequences.
Hydrocarbons from unconventional and more difficult to produce resources such as shale gas, shale oil, tight gas, and tight oil, coal seam gas/coalbed methane and hydrates.
Enlarge an existing borehole by a special bit that opens to a diameter larger than running diameter by hydraulic or mechanical method, or by use of a bi-center bit.
IADC-UBO term. Well incapable of flow to surface.
The oil company identified as the operator in a unitized field.
A brand name for ultrasonic inspection tool, a corrosion damage monitoring device.
Generally a downhole valve that, when opened, permits circulation.
U.S. Department of Agriculture, Soil Conservation Service, currently known as Natural Resources Conservation Service (USDA-NRCS).
Underbalance.
Under production, short of the allotment or contract volume, that must be accounted for in a contract.
In an upward direction in a tilting formation.
Upper master valve.
Groundwater that has a free water table and is not overlain by a confining bed.
USI™ is a trademarked ultrasonic imager.
In the fluid path before the point of interest.
A process using ultraviolet (UV) light to kill bacteria and viruses.
Very high frequency sonic signals used in measuring distance, surface imperfections or even metal thicknesses.
Vertical movement of a formation to a shallower depth than when it was deposited.
Ultrasonic borehole imager.
A neighborhood search ellipse that uses all available data control points. The practical limit is 100 control points. A unique neighborhood is used with simple kriging.
Drilling with a pressure in the wellbore that is lower than the pressure in the formation.
Gas that occurs without association to oil.
Underbalance operations.
A well path that rises and falls over its length.
The thickness of material between the land surface and the water table.
-The amount of possible inaccuracy.
When the travel of the rod string at the pump (bottom of the well), is less than the surface rod travel.
The part of the completion above the packer.
Unconfined compressive strength, a measure of the formation strength form compressive tests on core.
That quantity of hydrocarbons estimated yet to be discovered.
Non constant, in fluid flow a condition marked by changing flow properties.

A fluid flow path that has a low spot.  In a well, the U-tube is represented by the tubing and the annulus with the bottom of tubing as the low spot.  Where two different density fluids are involved, the effect is that the lower density fluid will be pushed higher on its side by the higher density fluid on the other side.
Where the zone still has the natural connate fluids.
IADC-UBO term.  Maximum projected surface pressures exceed UBO equipment's operating pressure rating, but are below BOP stack rating. Catastrophic failure has immediate, serious consequences.
A relationship that assigns a unique value in a normalized (0,1) range to each possible value of some monetary range, to account for levels of risk aversion.
Any part of a wellbore drilled with a worn bit.
See "descriptive statistics."
In the context of subsea, a crown plug is a plug that fits in the bore of a subsea tree to serve as the secondary barrier against reservoir pressure.
A well located higher in the structure.
A geologic aged erosional removal from the top of a formation. Reservoir rocks below this surface may contain hydrocarbon deposits if the unconformity acts as a seal.
A tool with downhole deployable arms and cutters that allow a larger hole to be drilled below a smaller opening.
Formations with insufficient cementing agents between the grains to stop movement of individual grains when fluid flows through the formation. Usually less than 2 to 10 psi compressive strength.
Oil Viscosity.
A control line attached to a remove piece of equipment, usually a subsea wellhead, to provide hydraulic or electrical control, or inject small amounts of chemicals.
Lease acreage on which wells have not been completed to a point of testing or allowing production.
-In the context of chemical, in a produced fluid stream, an upset is when chemical or physical reactions create precipitates or emulsions.
When the pressure exerted by the column of fluid in the wellbore is less than the pore pressure in the formation.
An oil with less gas than its solubility capacity.
United States Geololgical Survey, a US government agency.
Perforating the well when the pressure in the wellbore is less than the pressure in the formation.
An uncontrolled and unintentional flow of fluids from one formation to another, generally when one or more well barriers have been breached.
IADC-UBO term.  Geothermal and non-hydrocarbon production. Maximum shut-in pressures are less than UBD equipment's operating pressure rating. Catastrophic failure has immediate, serious consequences.

A map created by post-processing conditional simulations. A threshold value is selected (e.g., 8% porosity), and the uncertainty map shows at each grid node the probability that porosity is either above or below the chosen threshold.

In the context of risk, uncertainty assessment is the process of combining uncertainties, as with a Monte Carlo Simulation, to generate output parameters that are represented by probability distributions.  No involvement of risk is implied. Example:   multiplying ranges of length and width to arrive at a range of resulting areas.
Ultra-large crude carrier:   >500,000 dwt of crude oil.
The pressure needed to initiate a fracture.
Iron carbonate scale.

In a seismic context, frequency domain is where the independent variable is distance and the dependent variables are strength of the signal and frequency of the signal.  (A domain is a mathematical function with dependent and independent variables.)
Failure to hold in nipple/sidepocket.
See Free Water Knockout.
Injection of gas or water into a reservoir to drive oil towards a producing well or set of wells.
Flexible hydraulic hoses connected to control systems in a subsea tree.
A depositional surface marking the transgression of a flooding event across an area.  Deeper-water fauna occur above a flooding surface; shallower-water fauna exist below that surface.

A method of stimulating production by increasing the permeability of the producing formation. Under extremely high hydraulic pressure, A fluid (as water, oil, alcohol, dilute hydrochloric acid, liquefied petroleum gas, or foam) is pumped downward through tubing or drill pipe and forced into the perforations in the casing. The fluid enters the formation and parts or fractures it. Sand grains, aluminum pellets, glass beads, or similar materials are carried in suspension by the fluid into the fractures. These are called propping agents or proppants. When the pressure is released at the surface, the fracturing fluid returns to the well, and the fractures partially close on the proppants, leaving channels for oil to flow through them to the well. This process is often called a frac job.
Money paid or costs at the start of a project (engineering, legal, contracts, etc.), before on-site activities begin.
Flapper valve.
A different part of the rock strata indicating a change in mineral content or deposition mechanics.
The silicate replaced replica of an animal or plant.
Failure to release from nipple/sidepocket.
What the flow looks like across the cross-section of the pipe.
In thermodynamics, fugacity is a property of a gas, related to its partial pressure, that expresses its tendency to escape or expand. Also called: escaping tendency.
Formation density compensated neutron log.
One of two basic types (puts and calls) of financial instruments entitling the owner to sell (put) or buy (call) one share of a commodity for a specified price on or before a specified date.
In the context of pipe movement, freeze point is the depth at which the pipe is stuck.
Initiating a fracture in the formation.
In the context of drilling or completions, FL stands for fluid loss.
In a completions context, FLC stands for fluid loss control.
Flowing wellhead pressure.

The early, higher rate production that comes from the larger pores, fractures and vugs that empty quickly.  Delivers a small, high rate flow every time the well is shut-in (recharges) and is brought back on line.
Materials that reduce the fluid loss from a wellbore fluid.  May include Bentonite clays, lignite, CMC, etc.
The thickness of a pay zone or formation, usually the gross (total) thickness.
The analysis of formation character or properties, usually by remote logs.
A thicker body piece of tubing above and sometimes below a tubing profile or other tool to control erosion by fluid flow.
A focused resistivity log that uses a pad contact with the borehole wall.
The tendency of a formation to react with fluids, usually filtrates from injected fluids.
Failure mode and effects analysis.
End of a braided drilling line affixed to the draw works.
One of several low damage, low toxicity, normally high cost brine for special applications.  May be one of several formation compounds.
A common, high pressure wellhead connection, using bolt attached flange plates and metal-to-metal seals.
Fluorocarbon. A aromatic resistant seal material.
Corrosion occurring under a coating in a pattern of filaments.  May resemble threads.
A technique for estimating the highest free point in a string of stuck pipe.  It is based on a differential stretch calculation with amount of pull and the free point constant (FPC).
Flowing bottom hole pressure.
Failure to set in nipple/sidepocket.
A cement slurry, foamed with between 40 and 60% nitrogen gas. Has a slurry density of about 7.5 to 10 lb/gal (0.9 to 1.2 g/cc).
Perfluoroelastomers (Kalrez™, Chemraz™, etc.).
A pressure relief valve that opens when temperatures increases sufficiently to melt an activation linkage.
A flow restriction common in downhole chokes, surface chokes and some SSSVs.
Formation factor.
Facility engineer.
Vaporization of water or light ends as pressure is released during production or processing.
A viscosity measurement based on the number of seconds that it takes for 1 liter of fluid to flow through a Marsh funnel.
A variety of chert.
Water with less than about 600 ppm total dissolved solids.  Suitable for drinking.
The rate of loss of liquids to the formations from the fluid being circulated through the wellbore.
Depth of the contact point in a specific well between immiscible phases.
The porosity attributed to the natural fractures, commonly less than 2 to 4%.
The length of one wind of a fracture from the wellbore to the tip.
Materials used to increase visicosity.  They cause colloidal particles to group into bunches or flocs.
The excess water that separates from a cement slurry on standing.
Fracture capacity – a comparison of the conductivity of the fracture to the capacity of the formation.
The pressure necessary to start a fracture from the wellbore.
A test of the fracture initiation pressure.
A device on the entrance to a screen to route the incoming flow more evenly across the face of the screen.
An obstruction to flow.  Usually a reduction of permeability.
The resistance to an object’s passage through a fluid (or a fluid’s passage past a stationary object). Affected by viscous resistance, density, wall contact (vessel radii).
Body centered cubic crystalline phases common to iron based alloys.
Part of the rock that has been flushed with a sweep fluid. The area may have little hydrocarbons remaining.
The initial part of the fracture fluid that creates the fracture width and controls the initial fluid loss but contains no proppant.
Influx into the well bore.
The liquid that leaks off into the formation during fluid loss.
To aggregate or clump together individual tiny soil particles, especially fine clay, into small groups or granules. The opposite of deflocculate or disperse.
A lost piece of equipment in the well.
Water content of a soil after it has been saturated and allowed to drain freely, usually expressed as a percentage of its oven-dry weight or volume.
One of several materials that reduce the stability of the bubble skin in a foam and cause the foam to break.
The mass per volume density of a fluid.
In the context of contracts, fee land is land where mineral and surface rights are controlled.  Usually private lands, rather than public or government.
Lithification of rock fragments.
Fishing neck.

Tubes with a diameter slightly larger than the braded wireline or slick line that are used in the “stuffing box” on a wireline intervention to isolate the well pressure and fluid from the atmosphere.  They work in combination with oil or wireline grease injection to form a hydraulic seal.
Any piece of a tool or the well that is wetted by the produced fluid flow.
A rapid, usually unplanned, thickening of cement.
In the context of SSSV, FTO is fail to open on command.
The fractional or percent amount of pore space which a specific fluid occupies.
Marking the pipe or wireline with a paint stripe.
Final report until change of status.
Flow condition (e.g., mist, slug, churn, etc.) of a multiphase process stream.
See Free Point Constant. Used in stuck pipe depth calculations.
Full opening.
Movement of small particles (usually <5 microns) through the rock pores.
Formation control valve.
A gas in liquid emulsion.  Common as a low density cleanout fluid or a frac fluid with reduced water content.

A burner on a remote line used for disposal of hydrocarbons during clean-up, emergency shut downs and for disposal of small volume waste streams of mixed gasses that cannot easily or safely be separated.
Iron hydroxide gel (a precipitate after acid spends).
A multi-functional test that can be used to determine fracturing pressure or if the well is fractured.
Valence state +3 iron in solution.  A very common catalyst in oil field emulsion and sludge formation. Precipitates at iron hydroxide when the pH exceeds 1.8 to 2.2 (depending on sour conditions).
Floating production, storage and offloading. An alternative to pipelines.

The layer of solids stranded on the face of permeable formations by liquids driven into the rock by pressure differential towards the formation.  When sized correctly the filter cake may completely stop losses.
A device that uses a black light for identifying hydrocarbons on cuttings.
The connate water.
Any process designed to minimize movement of otherwise mobile fines, typical size <44 microns.
Completed.
A four-way connection.  In a wellhead, a flow cross connects the master valve and the swab valve with two, normally horizontal, connections to the wing valves.
The pipe connection between the well and the separators or tank battery.
A high performance elastomer for seal assemblies.
Pressuring and depressuring the tubing (ballooning) to remove plugs or knock scale and other debris loose from the tubing wall.
Very simply, movement of a fluid.
A process during which a problem is described in sufficient detail for the group involved to agree that the description is unambiguous.
A magnet, usually run on wireline, used to recover lighter metal components from the well.
A silicate mineral, often modified and sometimes part of the movable particles in a formation.
A drag bit with no moving parts, rotated like a conventional metal drilling bit.
Where rock splits or ruptures with associated movement occurs on either side.
Normally the propped part of the fracture that will support improved flow.
The maximum stress that can be sustained for a specified number of cycles without failure.
Allowing a flat, usually polished, face to deform an elastomer and create a seal.
Fracture closure stress.
The subsurface course that fluids would follow as they move in a reservoir or between reservoirs.
Free point indicator tool.
A upward turning horizontal well – usually over 90o.
Floating production unit.
Drill pipe pressure required to circulate at the selected kill rate.

A forcing function is an external force that is acting on a vibrating system. This has the effect of modifying the vibrations that are experienced in the system, sometimes significantly. For example, in a rotating-drillstring system, the drill bit will impart a forcing vibration to the lower end of the string.
A material, usually a polymer that reduces the friction of flowing fluid in a conduit.
The tools that can capture a lost item (a fish) in a well.
A formation that contains oil or gas that is held in place by a displaced, non permeable rock mass.
Ash from the burning of coal.  Used as an extender in several cements and as a plug component.
A frequency spectrum is a band of frequencies.
The best part of a reservoir.  Commonly used in coal pays.
Formation pressure while drilling.
An ignition temperature (given in oF) that liquid will put off enough vapors to be ignited.
Gauges with a high sampling rate.
In the context of coiled tubing, friction lock is a state where the wall drag or friction is high enough to prevent further movement of the pipe.
Creating a fracture in a carbonate and etching the face of the fracture to preserve flow capacity down the fracture.
Liquid filled.
Reservoirs that occur along ancient rivers where the rivers overflowed. Deposits are mostly silt and mud.
Gas that is not dissolved in the liquid.
A three-way connection.  In a wellhead, a flow cross connects the master valve and the swab valve with the wing valve. Also called a tee.
A science field dealing with prevention of scales, hydrates, asphaltene and paraffin deposits and other problems that could stop flow of fluid from the subsurface, wellhead or pipeline.
The portion of a seismic propagation medium that is a distance of at least 3 or 4 wavelengths away from a source station.
Capital costs from acquisition, exploration, drilling and completion costs of proved reserves.
The ability to resist breakup.  Often taken as the fracturing point.
The texture exhibited by clay, sandy clay, silty clay, clay loam, and silty clay loam soils. A soil containing large quantities of these textural classes.
In the context of brine, FCTA stands for first crystal to appear.
Flowing a well back after a treatment.
Final circulating pressure.
A seal with good resistance to aromatic fluids but susceptible to sour gas.
A foam with very high internal gas volume, usually 90%+ gas.  High viscosity and often very stable.
A concession owner selling a percentage of a lease to an outside operator for drilling a well.
Formation density log.
Lumps of undispersed polymer in suspension in the pill.
A weld repair made in the field.  Usually derates the equipment pressure or tensile rating.
Fracture gradient.
The breakdown (fracturing) pressure of a formation.
Flowing tubing pressure.

One or more reservoirs grouped by or related to the same general geologic structural feature or stratigraphic condition. There may be two or more reservoirs in a field which are separated vertically by intervening impervious strata, or laterally by local geologic barriers, or by both.”
Failure mode and criticality effects analysis
FrontSim™ is the trademarked name for a 3D streamline model.
Water having less than 1,000 mg/L dissolved material. Friable A consistency term pertaining to the ease of crumbling of soils.
Any distinct, mapable layer.

A technique for isolating multiple fracs using a short downhole settable ring or restriction and dropping a hard rubber ball between frac jobs.  Two or more ring/ball sets can be used to stage frac a long zone.
Usually a DE filter.
The plane or direction along which fault movement has occurred.
The spacing and production rules in a field or unit.
Accumulation of deposits on a surface.
Ideal drawdown / actual drawdown.
The pressure of the fluid in the formation.  The initial reservoir pressure is the pressure at discovery.
When the designed function can not longer be met.
A common viscometer for oil-field fluids.
The generally statement of the largest size particles in a fluid after passing through a filter.
A well placement pattern that looks like the 5-spot side on a dice cube.
A dimensionless value expressing the roughness of the pipe.
A sand with an unconfined compressive strength of 300 to 1000 psi.  Crushable with forceps.
One of many refined petroleum oils such as heating oil, diesel, etc.
Purposely breakable valve, usually a flapper in a fluid loss device.
Formation GLR.
A standard profile. Can accept a plug or other tools.
One of several forms of iron sulfide.
Bacteria that can survive either with or without oxygen.
Or rod pound – a beam lift term where the pump is filled with gas from pump-off or too fast of an operating speed (rod speed).
In the context of a control line, FMJ stands for ferrule metal junction.
An organic resin, formed by polymerization reaction of furfuryl, used in consolidation, zone shut-off and water control.
In a logging context, F is formation factor.
Formation micro image, a common fracture detection tool.
Feet per hour.
In a drilling context, a finger board is steel fingers mounted to the derrick into which the derrick man stores pipe that is standing in the derrick.
In a logging context, FFI is the proportion of moveable fluids occupying the effective porosity.
The ability of an organization to operate a facility in a safe and efficient manner.
Flowing wellhead temperature.
Attraction, gellation and drop out of suspended particles from a liquid.
A calculation used in the stuck pipe calculation to correct for pipe wall thickness and diameter.
The groupings of fractures, possibly interconnected, that form a enhanced flow unit.
The act of lifting off part of the mud filter cake, at the most permeable sections of the rock, in response to flow produced by draw down.
Quantity of gas measured at standard conditions dissolved in one stock tank barrel of oil at current reservoir pressure and temperature.
Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (US gov. agency).
The gradient needed to initiate a fracture.
Corrosion that is accelerated by the effects of erosion removing the initial corrosion films.
The inward differential pressure difference that will result in part of the filter cake being removed from the face of the formation (usually over the most permeable and higher pressured sections).
Fresh water.
In the context of SSSV, FTC is fail to close on demand.
A multipoint flow test measuring skin at each flow rate.  When plotted, the intersection of the best fit line with the y-axis (skin) at zero flow rate yields the mechanical skin.
The pressure at some datum (usually surface, FSP, or bottom hole, FBHP, measured while the well is flowing.
The number of barrels of reservoir oil that shrinks to one stock tank (surface) barrel after gas breakout and light end vaporization. Abbreviated FVF.
A one-way, flow actuated valve common in safety valves, coiled tubing and fluid loss devices.
Field operations center.
Formation water.
The side of the fault that protrudes underneath the upper formation.
A non adjustable choke that uses a flow bean for regulation.
A metal failure based on weakening by flexing or cycling.  The material often work hardens.
Same function as a float collar but run on the end of the casing.
The loading of proppant per square foot after the fracture has been placed.  Commonly between 4 and 16 lb/ft2 of fracture face.
A piece of equipment on most downhole tools that is designed for simple, non-rotating attachment when retrieving.
In the context of fracturing, FIT stands for frac isolation tools.
The fluid used in a fracturing treatment, may include pre and post treatment fluids.
The process of separating natural gas into component parts or fractions such as propane, butane, ethane, etc.
An assay method for organics in rock by pyrolysis (burning).
Flowing tubing head pressure.
A flow test in which the flow rate is measured at four drawdowns to estimate how skin changes at each rate.  Useful for identifying non Darcy skin or turbulent skin.

The primary, bottom hole valve in the float collar or shoe that allow the casing to self fill while running and allows the cement to pass into the annulus but helps prevent cementing U-tubing after the job.  Drillable and subject to erosion wear.
The weld seam on or in a welded pipe.
The earth stresses acting to try to close a hydraulic fracture offset by the pore pressure.

Valence state +2 iron in solution.  In oil field operations, most solution iron is ferrous until oxygen is encountered.  Precipitates at iron hydroxide when the pH exceeds 7 or when oxidized to ferric by contact with oxygen.
An outside party paying a concession owner all or a percentage of the drilling costs of a well in order to obtain a working interest in the land or well.
Failure to release packer.
A measurement of fluid loss expressed in cc/min1/2
A measurement, derived from a data frac, of the efficiency of a particular fluid in creating fracture area on a particular formation at a set of conditions.
In a completions context, FSV stands for formation saver valve.  A check valve that prevents fluids from reaching the formation.
Cement with small hair like fibers that build strength or help control fluid loss.
Field development plan.
Fluoroelastomers (Aflas™, etc.).
An older biocide, now rarely used.
Fracture Finder™ Log is the trademarked name for an acoustic log that helps determine if fractures are present.
A Non Upset connection in most cases.
The flow connection from the wellhead to the separation facility, pipeline or storage unit.
An organic acid used in higher temperature wells for shallow damage removal.
A test loop of pipe in which flow characteristics are measured.
Deterioration at interfaces of two metals accelerated by their relative motion.
Free Point analysis followed by downhole unscrewing of a pipe coupling above the stuck point.
Full field model.
The first stage of separation in a crude that contains a large amount of water.
Fire retardant clothing.
Flowing gas oil ratio.

The pressure necessary to extend the fracture once initiated.  The fracture extension pressure may rise slightly with increasing fracture length and/or height because of friction pressure drop down the length of the fracture.
A tool with strain gauges that is run on wireline and moved along the stuck pipe with successive pipe pulls until the stuck point is located.
Coal, natural gas or oil.
A steep slope.
Fluoro-elastomers (Viton™, Fluorel™, etc.).
Failure to set packer.
A bend-like disruption in a rock strata such that the angle of the formation is significantly changed.
An emergency shutdown device activated by fire or thermal overload. (Note:   fusible links below the ignition point in a wellhead may not be activated (melted)). Also called a fusible link.
Add sufficient fluid in an unconsolidated sand matrix to break cohesive bonds and lubricate grain by grain movement of sands.

A tertiary recovery method involving injection of air into the formation and igniting the oil.  Under the right  conditions, the heat produced from combustion of the heavy ends that are trapped on the sand grains lowers the oil viscosity and liberates light ends.
Movement of one fluid through another.
A flow test designed to prove that hydrocarbon exists in the reservoir and will flow to surface. May also indicate productivity or other characteristics such as interference or boundaries.
A measurement of the electrical resistivity of a formation. The measurement will be significantly affected by the type of fluid and the salinity of water based fluids within the pores of the rock.

A short piece of casing run one to two joints above the end of casing.  The collar contains a backpressure or check valve which stops cement from reentering the well after displacement into the annulus.  It is useful to prevent channels in the cement until the cement is set.
Formation Volume Factor.
The width of a fracture at the wellbore.  Hydraulic frac width is generated by frac fluid viscosity and/or pump rate (i.e., horsepower).
The material used to make up a filter bed.  Common filter media are DE, sand, various fibers, etc.

In vibration theory, frequency is the number of repeats per unit of time. This also is called a cyclic frequency. An angular frequency (sometimes called circular frequency) (ω) is  measured in radians per unit time. Angular frequency is the product of 2π and the cyclic frequency.
The distance outward from the wellbore to the leading edge of the lost fluids.  Varies with the permeability of the zone.
A well that flows to the surface by produced gas expansion and does not use any method of artificial lift.
A coupling with threads on the inside.
Formation isolation valve.  A downhole valve that is operated by pressure cycling or other remote method.
A measurement in the well of the pressure vs. depth. Useful for spotting liquid levels, leaks, fluid entries, etc.
A sudden pressure drop that causes hydrocarbon light ends to go from a liquid to a gas.
The first part of the cement slurry injected – often contaminated during the flow by mixing with mud from the walls of the pipe or the formation.
Collection of rock composition and type(s); limestone, sandstone, etc.
A mechanism to hold a plug in a profile.
Mud with a low suspended solids quantity.  It may be formulated with a brine with high density created by dissolved salt.
Last crystal to dissolve.

The designation of soil units for showing their suitability for specific uses, such as cropping, grazing, woodland, wildlife, or others, usually divided into eight classes. The classes range from Group I for soils which are very productive, easy to work with, and have few if any limitations for most uses to Group VIII for soils or land conditions which are minimally productive, extremely difficult to work, with and have very severe limitations. Lower case letters represent subclasses such as "e" for highly erodible; "w" for excess wetness; "s" for droughty, or stoney; and "c" for prolonged coldness.

Is a surface wave that propagates along the Earth/air interface and creates a particle displacement that is tangent to the Earth surface and also perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation.  A Love wave does not propagate in the interior of the Earth.  See body wave, ground roll, Rayleigh wave, and surface wave.
Very young coal.  Moderate to low energy yield.
The fluid lost from the well expressed in volume per time.

Intermediate in texture and properties between fine-textured and coarse-textured soils. Includes all textural classes with the words loam or loamy as a part of the class name, such as clay loam or loamy sand.

A technique using a suite of logs that are part of the drilling BHA.  The formation properties are measured while drilling (although 40 to 60 feet back from the bit) and the information is pulsed to the surface. Abbreviated LWD.

A production or injection well logging technique where the zones is logged for water saturation, oil saturation or temperature, followed by fluid injection, followed by another logging pass. Data available include changes in saturations, quantitative/qualitative determination of injection location and amount of temperature charge, etc.
Same as lost circulation control materials. Abbreviated LCM.
Sandstone deposits in layers, often with very different permeabilities and frequently found with barriers to vertical flow.
Molten rock.
A chart of the physical properties of the formations; specifically rock composition, texture, porosity and type, etc.
Cleaning at less than 5,000 psi water pressure.
Lower explosive limit.
The information section at the top of a printed well log.
Low density polyethylene.
The depth in a well where the standing or percolating level is located.
Lost time accident.
Hydrocarbon liquids with lower boiling points that may flash off when pressure is released.
In the context of casing, a liner is a partial string of pipe that does not run back to surface.  Liners may or may not be cemented.
Also known as: Land treatment
A solution obtained by leaching, such as water that has percolated through soil containing soluble substances and which contains certain amounts of these substances in the solution.
LOT, a drilling test. A LOT is intended to determine the point of leak-off. Compare to FIT.
Lb/s or Pounds of water per second.
Material transported and deposited by wind and consisting of predominantly silt-sized particles.
The removal of materials in solution from the soil.
Loss of production.
In the context of a pipeline, lead lines are the lines from a well to a battery.  Also called gathering lines.
A device in a coiled tubing reel control that aids in controlling spooling of the CT.
Loss of returning fluid during circulation of a well.
Long term reservoir management.
In the context of transportation, LDC stands for long distance carrier.

Fluid flowing at a lower rate with elements of the fluid flowing in fixed streamlines. Laminar friction is a function of NRe (Reynolds number). For laminar flow, the Fanning fracition factor = 16/NRe.
A % by volume distribution of the particle sizes in a sample.
Litho-Density™ Log is the trademarked name for a device that measures the bulk density of the formation.  Useful to estimate lithology.
Process of changes that produce rock from sediments.
Liquid, no flow test, inside annulus.
The part of the completion below the packer.
A near dry gas, containing only a trace of condensate.
Materials that reduce torque and drag.  May be oil, synthetic (polymer) liquids, graphite, glycols, glycerines, etc.
Shallow laterlog resistivity.
An easily suspended colloid.  Having an affinity for the suspending medium.
A cement with a slurry density less than the normal approximate density of 16 lb/gal (1.92 g/cc) density.  Normally in the range of 11 to 14 lb/gal (1.32 to 1.68 g/cc).
During circulation, when less fluid returns to the surface than was injected into the well.  Severe lost circulation is the loss of all returns.
A legal document granting the right to prospect, drill, complete and produce hydrocarbons on an areal tract.
A cement squeeze technique with a final squeeze pressure below the formation fracturing pressure.
Deep laterlog resistivity.
A packer-like hanger with slips suitable for hanging liner weights.  May or may not incorporate a seal.
A string of casing, usually of the same size, used tie a set liner back to surface.
Leakoff test, a drilling test. A LOT is intended to determine the point of leak-off. Compare to FIT.
The top of a liner, specifically the interval between the liner top and the shoe of the previous casing.
Total depth or measured depth.
A workover done without killing the well (with wellhead pressure and proper barriers).
In a side-by-side dual completion, the tubing string that connects the deeper zone to the surface.
Leakoff control acid.
Liquid level leak test.
L/s or Litres of water per second.
Lay down.
Low toxicity oil based mud.
Agricultural - A soil amendment consisting principally of calcium carbonate, but including magnesium carbonate; used to furnish calcium and magnesium and to neutralize soil acidity.
Overburden pressure of rocks at a depth.
In the context of a wellhead, LDS stands for lock down screws.
Lubricator.
An electrical log. Formation resistivity measurement with specific conductive muds.
The differential pressure across the mud cake from formation towards the wellbore that will cause some of the mud filter cake to lift off the face of the formation and to re-establish permeability.
In the context of facilities, an LP is a low pressure separator or separator train.

A form of mathematical programming in which the objective function is a linear combination of the independent variables. The solution technique is called the simple method because it can be viewed as a search along the edges of a hypercube.
Regionally extensive deposits along the shores of ancient seas. Permeability varies with energy of deposition (amount of residual silt).
A device on which the CT injector may sit that can be hydraulically raised to allow access to the BHA below the CT connector.  Takes the place of a crane.
Penetrating or perforating only part of the pay zone.  Usually done to control water or gas entry or to assist in ball sealer action in selective treatments.
Lateral torsional buckling.
Lower workover riser package.
A pressurized shell, mounted above the BOP or master valve, which houses the tool string when entering a live well.
