A device based on strain gauge technology that helps measure the surface weight of coiled tubing.
Long term shut-in.
Laser particle size analysis.
Minimum principal stress. Hydraulic fractures form perpendicular to this stress.
Produced oil before removal of associated gas.
A connection description. Often written LT&C.
Laser particle size distribution.
When gas is slipping by the liquids, emptying only a part of the liquids in the well and leaving a portion of the liquid in the wellbore.

One of several a downhole coupling mechanisms that hold the string to a predetermined load before releasing.  Useful for confirming depth and attachment when the string is snapped into or out of a latch.
Tubing performance curve.
Lead impression block.
The short pipe section that screws into the top of the tubing hanger and is then latched onto by the elevators to manipulate the tubing string.
Lay down for night.
In the context of a downhole gauge, an LPT is a loss of pressure and temperature signal.
Using a line of injectors to drive fluid preferentially along a given path.
A plug that fits in the bore of a subsea tree, usually below the tubing hanger, to serve as the primary barrier against reservoir pressure.
A near full-opening valve installed just below the kelly.  It has the same outside diameter as the tool joints.
Low sulfur fuel oil.
In the context of a load, lateral is a sideways load.
Low pressure separator.
A systematic recording of data from a well.
Low solids oil base mud.
A high permeability zone that takes fluids from the wellbore and the conventional filter cake building materials have no effect on fluid losses.
In the context of reservoir fluid, LO stands for live oil.
Steel with less than about 5% alloying additives.
Lower Marine Riser Package.
Lost circulation material.
To connect the elevators to the tubing.
A distance parameter used during computation of the experimental covariance model. The lag distance typically has a tolerance of plus or minus one-half the initial lag distance.
Steel with less than 0.30% carbon and no other alloys.
In the context of a hydrocarbon movement, the law of capture is a legal concept, valid in some places, that since oil (and gas) are mobile fluids, that they are not owned until they are produced.
To disassemble the drill string into individual joints and lay it down on the pipe racks.
Any of a number of materials that control the loss of fluids to the formation.  Abbreviated LCA. See Filter Cake.
A person who negotiates with the land or mineral rights owner to secure a lease to drill.
Liner tie back sleeve.
The operating expenses of producing fluids to the surface.
A nipple profile that contains a specific profile with a lock and a polished bore for sealing.
A calculated saturation index for calcium carbonate, useful in scaling predictions.
Lower riser package.
The cost of lifting or flowing fluids from a well to the facilities. Often used as a benchmark for efficiency.
Low specific activity scale. Low radioactivity scale.
Varying definition, typically an API gravity of 30o or 33o up to 40o.
Light ends, usually C3 and C4 gasses liquefied for storage and transport. Abbreviated LPG.
Installing casing to the casing set point.
Log-inject-log.
Where the top of the liner comes up inside the upper casing string.
A distinct segment in a vertical stack of formation sequences.  Often with areal extent.
Lbs/hr or Pounds of water per hour.
Light with a narrow spectral width. Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation.
Low temperature separation.
A permeable, often small sedimentary deposit bordered by impermeable rock.
Methane that has been compressed and cooled to the liquefaction point for shipping. Abbreviated LNG.
Leakage in closed position.
In a geological context, a low energy system is a depositional environment where to deposited sediments are poorly sorted and can have a large proportion of very fine particles.
Outer layer of the earth including the crust and the uppermost mantle.
The fluid that is injected into a well.
A person that acquires leases and resells them to a drilling company.
A map of subsurface changes in formation physical properties.
In the context of computers, LAN stands for local area network.
A organic cement additive that provides some strength in set cement and fluid loss control in the slurry.
Lease automatic custody transfer unit.  A calibrated measurement device used as an official sales point for crude oil transfer into a second party pipeline.
The time it takes for drill cuttings to be carried to surface from the bottom of the well.
An uncrosslinked polymer gel. Typical polymers are guar, HPG, CMC, HEC, etc.
An asymmetrical accumulation of sediment and strata occurring during a period of lower sea level.
Low sulfur.
Localized and subsurface corrosion in zones often parallel to the surface that result in leaving thin layers of uncorroded metal resembling the pages of a book.
Low dosage hydrate inhibitor.
The Darcy equation describing linear movement of fluids in laminar flow through a porous media.
A description of well deviation change at about 2o to 6o per 100 ft.
A Zeta Hammer™ is a brand name tool used to deliver rapid impact stokes to a small BHA downhole. Operated by fluid flow. Usually run on CT.
Zinc chloride.
In the context of production logging, Z is acoustic impedance.
A brine made of salts of zinc, usually very dense.
The compressibility correction index used in the ideal gas law.  Z = Vactual / V ideal.
Scales that may occur after use of zinc brines where sulfate water is found.
A reactive class of minerals often associated with clay damage.
A section of a formation.
A shaped nozzle.
Release gas pressure.
A function of the value of the asset and how it is projected to change, the exercise price, the strike date, and the risk free interest rate.
See Semivariogram.
In the context of subsea, VXT is a vertical subsea tree.
Valve
A seismic survey where the energy is generated by vibrators attached to large truck-mounted plates at the surface.

(VSP) data are required with an energy source on the Earth's surface and a vertical array of closely spaced receiver stations in a well.  VSP receiver stations are positioned vertically at increments of approximately 50 ft (15 m).  This small spatial sampling allows all wave modes (downgoing, upgoing, shear, compressional) to be separated from the raw data.
A dynamic force. Most common is suddenly stopping a traveling casing string. May cause a pipe joint to separate.
Vacuum insulated tubing.
Very large crude carrier:   200,000 to 350,000 dwt of crude oil.
The combining capacity or electrical charge of atoms or groups of atoms. Sodium (Na+) and bicarbonate (HC03-) are monovalent, while calcium (Ca++) and sulfate (S04-2) are divalent.
A long tube used in well fire fighting operations to move all the fluids and the fire up above the damaged wellhead.  May also be used to put out the fire in some cases.
A seal stack of chevron type seals.
The pore pressure at discovery.

A valve specially dressed for a particular well and kept current with maximum flow potential that can shut in the well if surface control is lost.  Also called a storm choke – an early subsurface safety valve.
Any of several valves:   plug, gate, butterfly, needle, etc., used in oil field operations.
Volume percent.
A mechanism that allows the motor speed and power to optimally match the requirements of a pump.
Viton™ is a trademarked brand name of a common fluorocarbon elastomer common in seals.  Aromatic fluid resistant.
Viscosity.  Also abbreviated as VIS.
A large open pore feature.  May be associated with chemical dissolution of part of the matrix over geologic time.
A measure of shale maturity based on whether it has generated hydrocarbons. The value is in units of reflectance, in % Ro with values of 0 to >3.
Holes, blanks spots or empty areas.

Attraction created by the weak electrostatic forces of distributed charge in a polar molecule. Even though the water molecule as a whole is neutral, the polarity or the molecule leads to attraction between individual molecules from slight negative and positive centers. This enters into effects of viscosity and surface tension.
A reservoir drive mechanism provided by the expansion of solution gas in the oil.
The pressure exerted by the gas phase (vaporized liquid) in equilibrium with the system conditions.
In the context of subsea, a vertical tree is a subsea tree with the master valve above the tubing hanger.
Von Mises Equivalent.
Any material that increases the viscosity of a fluid.

A popular onshore seismic energy source.  Vibrators are large vehicles weighing 60,000 lbs or more.  They transmit seismic energy into the Earth through a heavy baseplate that is pressed to the ground and then vibrated over a prescribed frequency range.
The opening in the rig framework that allows pipe to be pulled upright from the catwalk.
A length of tubing with a screen at each end, intended to be installed through tubing and half of the assembly covered with gravel.  A common repair for a breached screen.  Generally low rate.
Viscosity.  Also abbreviated as VISC.
Vapor assisted petroleum extraction.
The evaporation or changing of a substance from liquid to vapor.
VIP™ is a trademarked finite difference reservoir simulator that replaced CCOMPV™.

-In the context of seismic, velocity gradient is usually the vertical velocity gradient, i.e., the rate of change of velocity of sound traveling through rock with depth. Normally, it refers to seismic velocity at seismic frequencies, i.e., smoothly varying (rather than rapidly varying, as with a sonic log).
Variable speed drive.
Easily evaporated oil, usually above a gravity of 40o API.

A small diameter tubing string, often coiled tubing that is suspended inside the existing production tubing.  By occupying part of the flow path space, the velocity of the produced fluid is increased and the potential to lift water from the well is increased.
Vertical seismic profile. Run in a single wellbore. Helps correlate logs with seismic data.
Tool surface operational check.
In the context of subsea, VASPS is the vertical annular separation production system.
In the context of a riser, VIV is velocity induced vibration.
Fann viscosimeter.
Vapor recovery unit.
A method using decision trees to place a value on the acquisition of some form of predicting information, such as a well test, a pilot study, or a 3D seismic interpretation.
A device that removes mists and vapors from gas in a tank or enclosure.
Volatile organic carbon.
In the context of marine, vortex shedding is a form of hydrodynamic loading of deep water structures that may lock into a structure’s natural vibration frequency. May include loop currents.
A measurement of the internal resistance of a fluid to flow against itself. Expressed as the ratio of shear stress to shear rate.
Variable-Bore Ram
A ram element in a BOP that will fit more than one size of pipe.  Commonly a ram element that can seal around the pipe body or the coupling.

One of several metrics pertaining to risk. While this is not well defined, it usually represents the difference between some base case (perhaps a budget value) and an almost-worst-case scenario (perhaps P5).  Abbreviated VAR.
No-observed-effect level.
The amount of money received per barrel of oil equivalent produced after subtracting operating and administrative costs, and royalties.
Non-productive time.
A well that can flow to the surface unassisted.
Methane, CH4.
Norsk Sokkels Konkurranseposisjon.

Bringing a well on with nitrogen lift to get the initial flow rate or to get it to steady state flow.  Commonly used after workovers to jet back heavy brines until the hydrocarbons with associated gas flow into the well and begin natural production.
NORM scale, usually barium or strontium sulfate scale with very low level radiation from atoms of uranium, thorium and potassium in the matrix of the scale.
Sodium chloride salt.  Halite.
Oil with API gravity of less than 25.
No flow test.
Sodium hydroxide.
A simulation method that does not use the control data during the simulation process and that frequently is used to observe the behavior of a spatial model and neighborhood design.

A pipe connection with consistent I.D. and O.D. with the pipe.  The connection walls are thin and weaker than EU or IU connections.  Used in flush joint liners and wash pipes. Also called an NU connection.
A fluid with a viscosity that does not produce a linear shear stress-shear stress rate.
Damage to the permeability occurring within the first few feet away from the wellbore.
An old stimulation process that involved lowering nitroglycerine canisters into a well and detonating.
An adjustable common choke for clean (no solids) production flow.
A cushion of nitrogen gas placed on top of a liquid column to reduce the downhole pressure.  Also use in the annulus for an expansion cushion in the event of annular fluid expansion.
The natural frequency of a system is the frequency at which the system vibrates when free of any friction or forcing functions.
Crude oil from the Brent field often quoted as a price benchmark.
A linear combination of two or more variogram (correlogram) models (e.g., a short-range exponential model combined with a longer-range spherical model).
Special slips for make up tongs that do not mark 13Cr pipe.
Non destructive testing.
Natural gas, not initially dissolved in oil, produced from a reservoir.
An aromatic solvent with highly-variable quality.
A common diverter.  It can sublime, or go directly from a solid to a gas.
Nipple down.  Disassemble.
A shaped orifice for directing fluid flow.
Natural gas liquids.
A fracture that is driven in a direction other than perpendicular to the least principle stress. Common in explosive fracturing events.
The most productive part of the pay zone.
Naphtha.
A fluid without thinners or dispersants.
A profile ring in the tubing with a very small opening that allows flow but stops any equipment or tool from passing through the restriction.  May be small I.D. or pinned.
A profile cannot pass another plug.  Usually only one non-selective profile is used – at the bottom of a well.
No returns, mud logging term.
A common seal materials with good resistance for oil but poor resistance to aromatics.
No-toxic-effect level.
A formation with a pore pressure the same as a sea water gradient (0.46 psi/ft).
A rod pump surface unit – pump jack.
A dimensionless measure of time often used in analyzing pressure behavior during the hydraulic fracturing process.
In a logging context, N is the saturation exponent.
A completion that is not stimulated.
Cement slurry without additives.
The portion of the natual gas compounds that liquify at surface conditions.
The theoretical point in pipe length that accounts for the effects of buoyancy.
Gas in unusual reservoirs, e.g., hydrates, coal beds, low permeability, etc.

In a seismic context, nanoteslas are the units in which magnetic survey maps are contoured. 1 nanotesla = 10-9 tesla.  1 nanotesla = 10-9 weber/m2. 1 nanotesla = 10-1 lines/m2. 1 nanotesla = 10-5 lines/cm2. 1 nanotesla = 10-5 gauss, 1 nanotesla = 1 gamma.
The specific shape of the nipple, usually an accepted profile such as an F, X, J, S, etc.
Nitrilotriacetic acid, a chelant.
A surfactant with no preferential charge.
A naturally occurring hydrocarbon seep to surface.  (There are over 1100 known seeps in North America.
In the context of repairs, NU stands for nipple up, meaning to put back together.
Condensate liquids.
Non rig workover.

A sound recording downhole.  Best performance of noise logs is with gas flow. Gas flow can be heard to about 10 actual ft3/D (Note – not standard ft3/day).  At very low gas flow rates (q<400 actual ft3/D), gas flow can be estimated from millivolts of noise between the 200-Hz and 600-Hz frequencies:   q = 0.35 (N200 - N600). Where q is the actual gas flow in ft3 and N = noise log cut at that frequency.
See Naturally occurring radioactive material.
Nitrile butadiene rubber. The most widely used elastomers in the oil field.
A pressure drop vs. flow study, using a computer program that compares flow performance at various “nodes” along the flow path.

A feature of the covariance model by which the experimental points that define the model do not appear to intersect at the origin. The nugget model shows constant variance at all ranges, but often is modeled as zero-variance at the control point (well location).
A short piece of pipe, usually with a profile shape in the ID. Nipple profiles are used in tubular strings to provide places to set plugs.
Usually oil base or an oil external mud which will not conduct electrical charge.  Many logs cannot be run in these muds.
The total of the company’s fractional interest in the gross acreage position.
Near infared.
A log-log plot that is very useful in predicting when the fracture is in tip-screen-out mode and whether the fracture is being widened or height growth is occurring.
A fault with mostly vertical movement.
That part of the proceeds less royalty payments.

Reserves subcategorized as non-producing include shut-in and behind-pipe reserves. Shut-in reserves are expected to be recovered from (1) completion intervals which are open at the time of the estimate, but which have not started producing, (2) wells which were shut-in for market conditions or pipeline connections, or (3) wells not capable of production for mechanical reasons.
Circulation down the tubing and up the annulus.
A flow regime departing from the laminar flow region where Darcy flow is measurable.  Generally turbulence.
Construct or put together a piece of equipment such as a wellhead.
A fluid whose shear force and response is directly proportional to shear rate.  Yield point is zero.
A stimulation fluid with dispersed nitrogen gas, usually at several hundred cubit feet per barrel.
The ratio of the net pay to the gross pay.
A metal surface treatment that improves abrasion and wear resistance.
The lower level to the permeability, porosity or saturation in what is considered net pay.

Nephelometric turbidity unit, a unit used in measuring water quality. An instrument called a nephelometer (from a Greek word meaning "cloudy") measures turbidity directly by comparing the amount of light transmitted straight through a water sample with the amount scattered at an angle of 90° to one side, the ratio determines the turbidity in NTU's.  NTU measurements can be confused by the base color of the water from stains that may not create damage in the rock.
In the context of a flow line, NRV stands for non return valve.
The company’s share of the production after royalties and partners shares are removed.
Short term use of nitrogen to kick a well off, i.e., establish flow.
In a seismic context, NMO is normal moveout offset. Difference in arrival times of reflected signals at different detectors caused by source variance and detector separations.
Neutron lifetime log.
Neoprene.  A ball covering and seal type.

A pipe connection with consistent I.D. and O.D. with the pipe.  The connection walls are thin and weaker than EU or IU connections.  Used in flush joint liners and wash pipes. Also called an NU connection.
National electric code (US).
A reference point in the well.
A measurement in which a target, either a formation of an injected fluid adsorbs natural or generated neutrons.
One billionth of a meter.

A log whose source emits neutrons into the formation.  Neutrons interact with hydrogen nuclei resulting in an energy loss that is converted to neutron porosity.  All hydrocarbons and water  contain hydrogen, but the formation usually does not. The amount of hydrogen in the gas affects the reading, so gas filled porosity shows a lower log porosity than oil or water filled porosity.
National Association of Corrosion Engineers.
Norwegian Petroleum Directorate.
A fracture in the rock created by geologic events such as uplift.

An approximation of a filter’s ability to remove particles of a certain size or larger.  Often does not perform at this level until a filter bed of particles builds up on the upstream side of the filter.
Nuclear magnetic resonance log.  Can show the difference in water, oil and gas movable fluids.
Nitrile.
Nm3.
Take apart or tear down a piece of a equipment such as a wellhead.

Heating a steel pipe to a temperature above the alloy transformation temperature range and holding at the temperature for long enough to remove stored stressed from handling, forming or other fabrication.
Nitrogen oxides.
A material, usually a surfactant that prevents emulsions.
A low volume, small orifice, high pressure bleed valve.
A sleeve that fits inside of a profile to protect the polished bore and the latch recess.
A polyamide material.
Commonly written IDn.
Natural gas vehicle.
A core preserved as close as possible to reservoir conditions with effort made to keep all hydrocarbons in place.
Marine zone- the environment between low tide and the continental shelf.
In the context of processing, neutralization is the process of neutralizing acid production (sour gas) with sweetening agents, etc.
A share of the production as calculated from the net profits of the operation.
A display of the input data in a stacking process designed to show all the seismic traces corresponding to the same depth.
Uncured cement.
A sand control completion that uses a larger gravel to stop the formation sand and a screen to stop the gravel.
The contacting blocks on a coiled tubing injector that grip and move the coiled tubing.
The amount of gravel above the top perf, after the job, in a well with deviation less than about 50o.
An asphaltic drilling fluid loss additive.
Gravel pack replacement.
A section of pipe used in the tubing into which a gas lift valve can be inserted.  The mandrel will allow communication with the annulus gas lift supply through the valve.
Gas injection valve.
A difference in porosities caused by the compressibility of gas in porosities estimated by the formation density log and the neutron density log.
Gigajoule; 1,000,000,000 joules.
Thread damage from lack of lubrication or mismatched metals.
GLAD™ is the trademarked name for the software package gas lift assisted design.
In the context of facilities, a gas lock is a gas retention device that permits gauging the tank without loosing gas to the atmosphere.
The number of standard cubic feet of gas contained in a barrel of oil.
Gas / oil contact.
Gas / oil ratio.  May refer to a solution GOR or total GOR.
Giga standard cubic meters (one billion standard cubic meters).
Cement (or some clays) and diesel oil dispersion that thickens when water is contacted.
A technology that ensures each vibrator in an array of vibrators generates the same source wavelet regardless of variations in soil conditions beneath the vibrator base plates.
A hydrate inhibitor or freeze-up preventer.
An unexpected and unwanted entry of gas into the wellbore during drilling or well operations.
A downhole tool that houses gauges.
Gas lift chemical injection
The heat of the earth, usually from produced natural steam, heat recovered from circulated water or direct heat-to-energy conversion (on-going research).
Gas lift valve.
Ratio of the gas density to the density of air.  Equal to the ratio of molecular weight of gas to that of air (28.97).
Water that moves into, though, or out of the soil under the influence of gravity.
A device that measures the local gravitational pull. Gravimeters are useful for determining small changes in the gravity. Very useful for detecting salt domes.
Flooding a oil reservoir from the top of the reservoir or an updip location, to push the oil towards a producing well.
Perforating gun.
A natural polymer from the guar plant. Common in fracturing fluid gellation.
The density of the rock components, without the effect of porosity.
The total acres in which the company owns an interest.

Gibbsite [AI(OH)3] is the most common soil oxide of aluminum. It forms in weathered soils, primarily in the temperate and especially in tropical regions. Gibbsite is relatively stable once formed and contributes to soil aggregate stability. Gibbsite strongly adsorbs anions and its anion exchange capacity increases with decreasing pH.
Immense deposits of natural gas tied up in clathrate structures with water.  Found extensively. See also hydrate.
Any of several replaceable seals in equipment or tools.

Soil structure on which the individual grains are grouped into spherical aggregates with indistinct sides. Highly porous granules are commonly called crumbs. A well granulated soil has the best structure for most ordinary crop plants.
Device that records the specific gravity of a fluid.
The changing contact of the gas cap and the oil below in the rock.
A survey of a wellbore that measures its position and trajectory.
Sacrificial anode.
Gate valve.
A small opening in the top of a tank, allowing gaging of the contents.
A test of the sensitivity of the perforating charge to firing from a detonating cord. May be used to spot changes in charge explosive or differences in loading.
A fault that is created in an actively forming basin.  It is often parallel to the shore line when created.
Commonly written G&G.
In the context of fluid loss additives, grain is literally grain or animal feed that is circulated with mud to act as a identifiable marker.
In the context of a rig, a gang is the crew.
Usually a professional involved with application of physics to geology, e.g., seismic interpreter.
In the context of well logging, a gradiomanometer is a device that measures the density of fluids along a fluid column.
A sandstone, characterized by angular-shaped grains of quartz and feldspar set in a matrix of fine grains.  May have high hardness.
In a subsea context, GLL is guidelineless.
In a drilling context, a gauge is the diameter of the bit of the hole drilled by the bit when there are no washouts.
Gas / liquid ratio.
A gas separation device, usually a perforated pipe section, in a beam lift well that helps break gas out of the liquids, preventing gas entry and resultant gas lock of the pump.

A pressure control method for forming a pressure seal around braded line and electric line.  Grease is injected between special tubes in a high pressure housing.  The tubes are slightly larger than the line and grease seals the remaining area.
A sandstone with a large percent of weathered granite grains.
The branch of chemistry dealing with the specialized reactions of downhole fluids and formations.
In the context of datum, GL stands for ground level.
Gas water contact.

A zone of free gas above an oil deposit.  The gas cap occurs where the oil is oversaturated with gas (past the solubility limit). When a gas cap is not present at discovery, the oil is above the bubble point.
Adding gas to an injected fluid or treatment to reduce the injected water volume and provide energy for flowing the well back after the treatment.

Gas to liquids.  A conversion of gas to a liquefied state by compression and cooling.  Also, a conversion of gas by chemical methods to an easily transportable liquid hydrocarbon of a more stable, longer chain.

Uses a scintillation crystal and a photomultiplier tube to measure naturally occurring and artificially induced gamma-ray radiation.  The gamma-ray radiation is a signature of the formations in a well – very useful in depth control. Used in open hole or pipe and also used to spot changes in radiation (NORM scale) and radioactive tracers. Abbreviated GR.
Uses porosity, density and/or tracer tools to determine presence of gravel and placement of gravel type between the screen and the hole or casing.
Gallons per minute.
The gradient reflecting the amount of temperature rise as the well depth increases. Normally about 1.1 to 1.8o F per 100 ft of true vertical depth increase.
Various. A wireline cutter. A cleanout pig. A sleeve, etc.
The production of gas from liquid or solid fuels.
A type of gas lift mandrel that allows full bore passage.  The valve “pocket” is on the side of the pipe.
Often a rupture disk to allow a well to flow after it is broken by a dropped bar.
Water subject to recharge from surface water accumulation.
Sticky, reactive shale formation.
Soil that formed under poor drainage, resulting in the reduction of iron and other elements in the profile and in gray colors and mottles.
Global positioning system.
In the context of a rig, a geronimo line is a safety slide or a line from the derrickman’s platform to the ground, used in an emergency.
In the context of coiled tubing, a gooseneck is the CT guide arch over the injection head.
Vertical cross section (vertical is depth and horizontal is lateral distance) between two points through a rock section.
Large, well sorted and consistently sized sand used to hold back a soft formation.
Change in pressure or temperature per unit depth.
Equipment for removal of water from natural gas.
Glass reinforced plastic.
A short section of casing with a rounded nose of a drillable material and a port through the center to allow circulation.
The movements in a reservoir driven by gravity.
In the context of a contract, a gathering agreement is an agreement detailing the conditions for entry of the producer's gas into the gathering system.
Using the formation data generated by a measurement while drilling system to assist in drilling a wellbore to a specific target in the formation.

A well drilled into a high pressure formation that results in an immediate surge towards the surface.  In the days of cable tools with minimum fluid (hydrostatic) head, the formation fluids often flowed to surface when the pay zone was penetrated.
Gas shut-off.
Gas production facility.
A short, wireline-run tool that checks the id of a well bore.
In the context of well testing, GTS stands for gas to surface.
An instrument that detects vibrations passing through the earth’s crust.
A support wire or cable used to stabilize a mast on a rig or other structure.
Gamma ray log.
Overpresured zone.
Grains per gallon.
A computer database management system, which includes remote sensing, mapping, cartography, and photogrammetry for conducting spatial searches and making map overlays.
Gamma ray neutron.
A common form of calcium sulfate precipitate or scale. CaSO4-H2O. Abbreviated gyp.
Polymer gellants.
An often high permeability limestone where large grains are in contact. Only high perm if fines are absent.
Liquids with free gas.  Usually refers to drilling or completion liquids.  May indicate a kick if the gas is present in large enough quantities.
A protective cylinder or ring to guide downhole tools past casing obstructions.
The flow line from the well to the separator or tank battery.
Gas Research Institute.
A solid body insert that replaces and blanks-off a gas lift mandrel pocket designed for a valve.
Gas no-flow test.
Gas control valve.
GAP™ is the trademarked name for general allocation program.
An older well design process of using a single joint of the heaviest wall casing in the well just below the wellhead. (Note – this restricts access of fullbore tools to all points below the joint.)
The technique of injecting gas into a reservoir.  It may be done for pressure maintenance, oil viscosity reduction, light end stripping or storage.
A drilled hole with no washouts; the same diameter as the bit.
Gas lift mandrel.
Radioactive measuring device.
Subsurface water that fills available openings in rock or soil materials to the extent that they are considered water saturated.
A vertical separator vessel.
The liquids, generally straight chain alkanes in the C2 to C6+ range, than can condense from gas when the temperature and pressure drop sufficiently low.
The science of the physical properties of the earth.
Gulf of Suez.

Is a robust, high-amplitude wave produced by onshore seismic sources that travels along the Earth/air interface.  A ground-roll wave does not propogate in the interior (body) of the Earth.  See Rayleigh wave.
Gas to wire.  Generally converting the gas from a small field to electricity at the well site and transporting the power by the electrical grid.
The OD of a bit or tool used downhole.
A device that helps knock out gas from circulated well fluid.

One of the artificial lift methods that uses gas injected down the annulus and interspersed into the flowing fluids in the tubing to lessen the density and to assist in vertical flow by gas expansion.
A exploration method that uses an instrument to measure the intensity of the earth’s gravity.  Areas with unusual readings may indicate traps or structures that could contain hydrocarbons.
Gravity drainage.
Mix the pits.
A type of metric used to quantify how close a density function approximates a histogram.
The process of cooling gas to -162oC, reducing its volume by 600 fold over the gas volume at standard conditions.

In a seismic context, a gradiometer is a device that measures an electric field at multiple points at the same time. The gradient is the difference in measured values per unit of distance between the measuring points.
A fluid with a higher than normal viscosity created by a gallant material such as polymer.

Total production.  Has been used as total fluids produced.  Has also been used as cumulative hydrocarbon production.Total production.  Has been used as total fluids produced.  Has also been used as cumulative hydrocarbon production.
Lead sulfide, PbS. A mud weighting additive for high mud weights.
The volume of reservoir gas resulting in one standard cubic foot.

In vibration theory, the group speed is the response of a wave’s group of sinusoidal components, and is different from phase velocity. Group speed is important; the interaction of all the wave components in terms of wave number, amplitude, and frequency causes the appearance of a carrier wave of some wave number, amplitude, and frequency. This carrier wave is modulated by group waves that propagate at group speeds. In a nondispersing wave, the group speeds are the same as the phase velocity of the wave components. In a dispersing wave, however, these group speeds can be different. If the group speeds are greater than the phase velocities, it will appear that a carrier wave originates at the back of the wave, propagates forward until it reaches the front of the wave, vanishes, and reappears at the back of the wave. If the group speeds are less than the phase velocities, it will appear that a carrier wave originates at the front of  the wave, propagates backward until it reaches the back of the wave, vanishes, and reappears at the front of the wave. This can be visualized by thinking of a caterpillar’s motion. The caterpillar’s ripples appear to move backward, yet the caterpillar moves forward. This is one reason the analysis of dispersing waves can be very complicated.
Any indication of gas in the drilling fluid or cuttings that indicates gas production from a reservoir that has been drilled.
A common inside fishing neck design.  Also a series of running tools.
Normally C7-C10 fuel, with a flash point of -40.
The acceleration of gravity measured in ft/s2 or m/s2. (1G = 32 f/s2 or 9.8 m/s2.
A valve with a sliding bar – common in the oilfield as tree valves.
The specific gravity of a fluid in API units, where fresh water is 10. Lighter gravity crude has higher API numbers.
A coarse, metamorphic rock with some parallel alignment of granular minerals and alternate bands of flaky or elongate minerals.
GTE or also known as Geothermal Energy.

A pressure operated valve, placed in a gas lift mandrels at designed points in the well.  The gas lift supply gas is routed through the valves into the tubing.  The top valves close and the lower valves open as the static liquid level drops in the well (the well is unloaded).
A block of the formation that has slid downward between two faults.
Invasion of gas into a solid, usually an elastomer, but sometimes referring to a metal.
Common igneous rock.  No effective permeability.
A shake out of solids, centrifuged or otherwise separated from the produced or circulated fluids.
A package of stratigraphic units that are genetically related.  Genetic sequences are bounded by erosional surfaces, flooding surfaces, or maximum flooding surfaces.
Pressure read by a gauge that is set to zero at atmospheric pressure.
Gas cap injection.
The science that deals with the study of the planet earth.
The wells that produce geothermal energy (heat).
The ability of a fluid to suspend solids.
The fraction of the porosity in a zone that is occupied by free gas.
Gas initially in place.
In a seismic context, gamma is a unit of magnetic survey map. 1 gamma = 1 nanotesla or 1 gamma = 10-5 gauss.

A channel resulting from erosion and caused by the concentrated but intermittent flow of water, usually during and immediately following heavy rains. Deep enough to interface with, and not be obliterated by, normal tillage operations.
Gathering center.
A reservoir drive mechanism in which gas expansion in the gas cap pushes the oil towards the formation.
A device that measures gravity changes over a specific area.
The total thickness of the pay zone, whether or not it is productive.
A ranking of metals from the easiest corrodible (magnesium) to the most difficult.

Corrosion between two dissimilar metals - couplings, centralizers, pumps, packers, profiles – usually severe  metal loss on one metal near contact point.  May see galvanic loss on a single metal with current.
The statistics of spatially (or temporally) correlated data.
Dimensionless function used in shut-in time normalized to pumping time. It is used to analyze pressure-dependant leakoff.
In a seismic context, a gravity unit is an acceleration unit (gu) used in gravity measurement.  1 milligal = 10 gu.
Anodes buried in the earth to supply cathodic protection to equipment.
In the context of a rig, a gang pusher is a supervisor.

A spring like device, resembling a interlocking finger puzzle that allows a round work piece to slide through the ID when in compression, but grips the work piece (or fish) when a tension load is applied.  Common in overshot fishing devices.
A seal around a moving rod.
Gravity of a fluid expressed as a ratio of a standard fluid.  For liquids, the standard is fresh water.  For gases, the standard is air.
Gas from a fee gas cap that goes downward toward the top perforations in response to a drawdown.
In a subsea context, GP is a guide post guide line. Also called a GL.
Products that increase the temperature stability of a material, usually a drilling or workover fluid above its normal expected range.
Loss of water vapor from the leaves and stems of living plants to the atmosphere.
Plastic or metal storage couplings that are screwed onto a stored tubing string, protecting the threads from impact and sometimes corrosion.
A gas lift valve controlled by pressure in the tubing.

An operating philosophy and sometimes a requirement that calls for having two barriers to flow from a well.  Most appropriate for active drilling, workover, or intervention.  May not be appropriate for all production wells, but is appropriate for wells with a higher risk factors concerning safety or environmental.
A pattern template for identifying a specific thread type.  Also referred to as "Thread Form".
Non specific term meaning lower permeability.
A short lived state.  Generally used describing reservoirs during production as pressure is progressively drawn down near the wellbore and slowly permeates the rock outward.
Trip out of hole.
Temporarily suspended (abandoned).  Also abbreviated as T/A.
A spear-like fishing device with threads to engage ID threaded fish.
To separate the drill string during rotation, usually from excess torque.
In the context of analysis, trace element is an element found only in minor amounts (usually less than 1.0 mg/l).
Trip out of the hole.
Tubing retrievable surface controlled subsurface safety valve.  May also be referred to as a ScSSV or DHSV.
Any equipment pulled with the tubing string.
A fault's vertical displacement.
A cement repair job done by running a tube down an annulus and cementing to surface.
Tubing end locator.
A wireline device that indicates when the end of tubing is reached.
An old drilling term.  A triple, or three joints of pipe screwed together.
A slickline tester used to spot slickline fatigue and embrittlement before the run.
A perforating gun small enough to be run and recovered through the tubing.
Tubing integrity fluid level.
36 sections of land, usually laid out as a square. Along with the section number and the Range, the Township is a way of describing the location of a well.
TIW™ is a the trademarked Texas Iron Works (manufacturer)
Tubing Head Pressure.
Total dynamic head.

A fracture treatment, common where high fracture flow conductivity is needed.  Very high pressures and very high proppant loadings are applied near the end of a fracture treatment where the tip of the fracture has stopped growing due to bridging of proppant at the fracture dip because of dehydration (frac fluid leakoff).
Gas that enters the wellbore during a trip of the drilling string.  May be due to swabbing and/or lowering the mud equivalent circulating density during pump shutdowns.
A winch line or other device that can pull equipment into place.
A wrench, hand or power, suspended above the rig floor to make or break pipe connections.
A smaller separator than the main production separator, used for regular production tests to measure oil, gas and water rates on a well.
A geologic period 2 million to 65 million years ago.
The far end of a highly deviated well.

A measurement of fluid clarity. Suspended solids and color in water reduces light transmission. Turbidity is a comparison of the amount of light that passes through a trial fluid compared to a clear sample.
Running pipe into the well.
Fluid property of being a semi-solid gel at rest and liquid when pumped. Thixotropic fluids decrease in viscosity with time at shear.
Expansion of the volume (length & diameter) of an object as it is heated.  In tubing, heat increases lengthen the tube or increase axial stress.
Pulling all pipe from the well and rerunning the pipe to bottom.
In the context of subsea, THD is tubing hanger.
Conversion of a logging tool measurement to a signal suitable for transmission to the surface.
An enhanced recovery process that goes beyond water or gas flooding.  It may involve steam, fire, chemicals, miscible gases, bacteria or other techniques.
The maximum depth of a well measured along the wellbore.
Cutting of threads in a hole.
An indefinite term normally used to identify a producing formation over a large area of production.
A beam lift pump where the barrel of the pump is attached to the tubing.
A packer set by pulling and holding tension in the tubing.
To connect a downhole liner to the surface with a casing of similar size.
Tubing pressure.
A flanged spool containing the tubing bowl where the tubing hanger will set and seal.
Total base number, a reserve alkalinity number.
Total depth measurement or pipe length to the depth.  Used for displacement calculations.
To remove a sample from a tank for analysis.
Trip gas.  This is a mud logging term.
Trip in hole.
See:Total petroleum hydrocarbons (TPH)
Typically the smaller, inner string of pipe in a well that is primarily used for a fluid flow path.
In the context of risk, target is a preferred outcome from an activity.
Thermal enhanced oil recovery.
-Top of cement.
GOR that includes solution and free gas from the reservoir.
-Time
In the context of tubing, tangential stress are stresses around the body of the tubing (Hoop Stresses).

A tubing string with more than one tubing size. Normally the smallest pipe is on bottom with larger sizes toward the top.  The sizes are set to minimize flowing friction and keep the velocity above the critical level to lift fluid.
Pull a string of tubing or drill pipe out of the hole.
Materials that change the relationship between solids and viscosity of a fluid to lower the gel strength, yield point, yield strength or viscosity as it affected by solids.
The movement of water in a soil that is not filled to capacity with water.
A mill with a gradual concave or convex taper designed to enlarge the wellbore.
A recording of one measurement from a log.
Through tubing rotary drilling.
Tubing Seal Bore Receptacle: A type of polished bore receptacle where the receptacle is on the tubing and the stinger is looking up.
Tubing-anchors catchers
The act of laying down a rod string when pulling a sucker rod pumped well.
Residue gas, as from a sulfur recovery unit.

Popular products produced by crosswell seismic profiling.  A CSP velocity tomogram shows the spatial distribution of seismic propagation velocities in the interwell space between a source well and a receiver well.
A fatty acid drilling additive.
A magnet in the return trough from wellhead to shaker that removes suspended metal particles from the fluid.
Equations for deliquification of a well at operating pressures greater than 1000 psi.
A geologic map showing the structure of the earth’s crust.
An aromatic or ring compound with 7 carbons and 3 triple bonds.  A very powerful solvent for oil, tar and asphaltenes.
A fluid that separates two incompatible fluids during well cleanout and prepares the wellbore for the next fluid.
The rate of increase of temperature per unit of depth. Varies in the world with geothermal activity.  Usually between 1.1 and 2.2+ oF/100 ft.
-In the context of core, TWC is thick walled cylinder.

A limit flow velocity for a specific fluid, either minimum or maximum,  that would accomplish a task.  Threshold Velocities are usually minimums to promote liquid lift in a gas well, or a minimum velocity to keep a pipe surface clean.
In the context of drilling, tangible costs are items of well construction that have salvage value, ordinarily capitalized on taxes.
The last of the cement slurry, generally the highest strength cement designed to be left across the casing shoe.
A separate lease to a shallower part of the strata.
A resistivity log plot showing the different investigation results based on depth of fluid invasion.
See:Total dissolved solids (TDS)
Terminal particle settling velocity.
A high permeability streak that serve as a loss site for wellbore fluids.
Tank.
A blind flange over a valve at the top of the tree.

Th232, one of the natural isotopes that as a trace element may incorporate into the matrix of naturally forming barium or strontium sulfate scale and make it a very low level radioactive material (NORM scale).
Through the flow line, a mechanism for well service where the tools are pumped downhole through the flow lines.
Through tubing.
Total acid number.  Measurement of natural organic acidity in a compound such as oil.
A small rope attached to a load being lifted by a crane that allows a person on the ground to help guide or place the load.
A motor spun by injected fluid moving past vanes affixed to the rotor.
In a value-of-information decision-tree problem, the various forms the information can take, such as "it will rain today" or "the structure appears to be closed."
The pressure on the tubing during either flow or shut-in.
Tubing by inside annulus.
The fluids used in a kill, stimulation, cleanout, etc.
A smaller tank that holds the fluids form running or pulling a string of pipe.  Because of its smaller volume, it is used to quickly spot incoming kicks or fluid losses.
An enhanced oil recovery process that uses heat to reduce oil viscosity.
Conductivity test of ions in the water.  Typically abbreviated as TDS.
Toe to heel air injection.
A measure of heat content, where one therm = 100,000 btus.

Mineral material suspended or dissolved in solution which passes a standard glass filter and 0.45 1-1m filter and does not evaporate below 180° C. TDS is generally used as a gross indicator of the mass of dissolved salts in a solution, but the analytical method is subject to interferences from colloidal material.
-In the context of gas lift, TCF is temperature correlation factor.

A map identifying the seismic image times at which subsurface structure is located.  Time-structure maps can be converted into depth-structure maps if seismic propagation velocity can be defined throughout 3D seismic image space.  See depth-structure maps.
-In the context of fluid movement, a tracer log is a log that uses radioactive tracer to monitor fluid movement in the wellbore or measure losses from the wellbore.
The holder for the slips on a rig.  Suspends the tubing during connection make-up.
The stretching of a material in pure tension.

A dynamic kill procedure, used in low pressure wells, good for a short period of time.  A typical top kill is to pump 5 bbl of fluid in the tubing, offsetting the tubing pressure as the fluid falls.  The well must be monitored for pressure or flow and the pump truck usually stays connected in the event that another fluid pill is necessary.
A portable mast composed of sections nestled inside one another and raised with a winch or a hydraulic cylinder.
A rig with the pipe rotation mechanism in the traveling block section.  Usually does not use a Kelly.

A bar graph ranking the impact of various inputs of a model on a specific output. The classical tornado chart is obtained by fixing all but one input at some base value and letting the one input vary from its minimum to maximum. A similar graph is used in Monte Carlo simulation software, in which the bar widths represent either rank correlation coefficients or stepwise linear regression coefficients.
The amount of a material that moves through a plant in a set time.
Time to first workover.
In the context of injectors, tracers are chemicals placed in the flow stream of an injector to determine that the water takes from an injector to the producing wells.
In the context of a wellhead, a tubing bonnet is the spool or hanger receiver in the wellhead, above which the master valve is the primary control.
-In the context of flow lines, twinning is adding an extra flow line with the same path to increase capacity.
Threshold hydrate inhibitor.
Resistance to rotation of a string.
Total suspended solids in a quantity of liquid.
-In the context of lift, TPC is the tubing performance curve.  A tubing specific relationship that is plotted with the IPR curve to select the tubing size for the well.

Tubing-anchors catchers (TAC) or tubing anchors are used to prevent movement of the tubing during the pumping operations with Rod or Progressive Cavity Pumps (PCPs). The catcher component being double acting slips that prevent a broken tubing string from falling down the hole.
A measure of the conductivity of the formation corrected for the viscosity of the flowing fluid.  kh/mu.
Platform equipment – facilities.
Tubing nipple locator.
Low permeability formation.
Breaking down by thermal destruction of the molecule.
Total gas lift ratio.
Pulling pipe from the well.
A deposit of very long carbon chain alkanes. May be associated with asphaltenes.
Tubing hanger setting.
On-site rig manager. Often there is a rig manager that looks after the rig (office position usually) and between 2 and 4 tool pushers)
A packer-like device without seals that keeps the tubing from moving.  Common in rod pumped wells.

In the context of drilling, a turnkey is a type of a drilling contract.  Once it meant the entire job, beginning to end, and often to ready-to-produce for a set price, however, the term has numerous meanings as defined by individual contracts.
A well where operations are suspended; i.e., shut-in while awaiting repairs, pipe line engineering analysis, etc., but not permanently abandoned.
Three dimensional display of seismic velocity in a well or area.
In the context of a ship, tender is a support barge, boat, or ship that supplies support to a rig or production facility.
Natural thermal cracking of sedimentary organic material to oil and gas.
Through tubing gravel packing.
In the context of geologic information, TST is true stratagraphic thickness.
A storage and separation location for oil.
The connection joining the electric line logging cable and the electrical bridle at the reel.

A measurement of temperatures along the wellbore.  Useful for determining temperatures at any point, static and circulating temperature and tops of cement column.  May also be used to locate the top of a fracture if run soon after the frac.
Tension leg platform.
In the context of pipe and connection, TPI is threads per inch.
The pressure, exerted by packing or a fluid column above an explosive charge that helps contain or focus the energy of the explosive or propellant.
The ability to trace the components of a product through out the supply and manufacturing system from raw material to finished and installed product.
A method of analysis of well behavior by matching the problem curve to curves draw from known conditions.
A description of the hindrance caused to flowing fluids as they attempt to enter the wellbore from a fracture or the formation. Also used to describe the deviation of the wellbore from a smooth path.
-to touch the top of a tool, fill, water, etc., with wireline, tubing, or CT tool.

In cementing, the last plug pumped in cementing with the two plug system.  It isolates the displacement fluid and cement slurry. It helps keep the heavy cement slurry from reversing or U-tubing back into the wellbore while the cement slurry is still unset.
True crystallization temperature.
Tubing head temperature.
Thermal decay time log.

Seismic maps that show detail in three directions. A network or grid of values that models a geologic surface or structure as a surface of density contrast (gravity), or susceptibility (magnetic). Also referred to as "3-D Seismic".
Total measured depth.
-In the context of perforating, a TTP is through tubing perforating.
A series of temperature log runs before, during and a sequence of temperature logs to spot channels, and differences in temperature heat up or cool down.
True vertical depth from the rotary table.

-The use of tubing, drillpipe or coiled tubing to convey perforating guns to the required depth. Initially, the technique was developed as a means for conveying the gun string on the production tubing, with the guns remaining in the well until they are removed during the first workover. The subsequent popularity of highly deviated and horizontal wells increased the requirement for tubing-conveyed perforating as the only means of gaining access to the perforating depth. The term is often abbreviated as TCP. Tubing conveyed perforating.
A container used on logging tools to give temporary protection from the downhole temperature.
-Total, Final, Elf.
Technical Advancement of Multi-Laterals.  An industry group that has defined multi-lateral junction levels and terminology.
A turbine motor for drilling.
See Tip Screenout.
Entering a well for a completion or repair by entering the well without removing the wellhead or the tubing string.  Usually done under pressure.
A section of the formation, forcibly impregnated with epoxy and sliced thin enough to examine with a light from the opposite side.
Top down reservoir modeling/modeling.

An embankment or ridge constructed on the contour or at a slight angle to the contour across sloping soils. The terrace intercepts surface runoff so that water soaks into the soil or flows slowly to a prepared outlet.
In the context of flow, transition zone is a zone where the flow type changes due to gas breakout, gas expansion, shear or turbulance.
Tubing kill valve.
A hard, abrasion resistant compound used in cutting tools such as mills and bits.
In the context of flow measurement, TSTM is too small to measure.
A precipitate of sulfate minerals following acidizing with strong hydrochloric acid.
A tour is a shift worked by the crew. (often pronounced as tower)
Run in the hole with tubing or drill pipe.
Through tubing drilling.
The vertical depth from the surface to the depth of interest.  Used for formation comparison and calculation of hydraulic pressures.  Typically abbreviated as TVD.
A group of supply or storage tanks.
Axial, radial, and tangential stress testing.
End of tubing.
Through tubing retrievable.
Trans Alaska pipeline system.
Movement of any tool via the tubing string.
A benchmarking comparison to determine how much better a process or a piece of equipment can be improved.
Turn over to production.
Threshold limit value.
A horizontal slice through a 3D seismic data volume.  Seismic image time is constant across a time slice, but geologic time is not, unless the stratigraphy is perfectly flat.
Non laminar flow, usually above a Reynolds number of about 3000. The Blasius equation estimates the friction factor for NRe values less than 100,000 as fB = 0.0791 / NRe0.25.
Any mud density over the amount needed to balance the formation with a static mud column.  Related  to overbalance.
A geologic time from 200 million to 250 million years ago.
A type of reverse fault in which the inclination of the plane of the fault is not highly deviated.
A transmitted wave is the portion of a wave that passes through a geometric or material discontinuity.
Tubing isolation valve.
In the context of gravel packing, a tell tale is an upper or lower screen in a gel packing gravel pack.  Used to spot annular fill up by pressure rise.
Controlling flow with a reduced orifice.
A completion with the casing set and cemented above the pay. Usually an open hole pay zone.
The near solid or highly viscous residuals at the bottom of an oil storage tank, generally composed of a large amount of paraffins, silt, heavy ends, etc.
Three joints of pipe screwed together.
A separator vessel.

A sedimentary layer with a thickness less than one-fourth of the length of the dominant wavelength in the illuminating seismic wavefield.  Typical dominant wavelengths can be 200 to 300 ft (~65 to 100 m); therefore, many thin beds have thicknesses of 50 to 75 ft (~15 to 22 m).  The top and base of a thin bed cannot be resolved in a seismic image.
Temporary surface piping rigged up for a stimulation or well kill operation.
The greatest lengthwise stress that a substance can bear without failure.
An electrically or hydraulically powered downhole tool with driven wheels or slip and hydraulic extension capability that can pull a tool string along a highly deviated well.
Terajoules. 1,000,000,000,000 joules. 1 kilojoule = 0.9478 BTU.
An exploration well or other project where information is not released to the public.
Concrete, plastic, or ceramic pipe placed at suitable depths and spacings in the soil or subsoil to provide water outlets from the soil.
The block of sheaves or pulleys that moves with the pipe during running or pulling.
A completion or repair technique that depends on pumping the tools or equipment into a flow line and down the well.  Typically abbreviated as TFL.

A low cost completion or multiple completion in which the tubing strings are cemented directly in the hole.  There is no outer casing.  Due to the small tubing diameters, potential to repair or re-enter the well for repairs is limited.
A restricted place in the bore hole, caused by wall cake, dog leg, deviation change or other factor.
True Vertical Depth.
In the context of casing string, TOL is the top of liner.
An S wave.
Tubing retrievable subsurface safety valve.
The tubing below the packer.
Measuring and recording the length of all pipe and downhole equipment.
A slip set or donut that suspends and holds the top of the tubing in the wellhead.
Short screens used at the top and bottom of older gravel packing assemblies to help determine where the gravel is within the screen by casing annulus during packing.
A surface elevation map.
Repeated, regular measurement of temperatures along a unit of depth in a well.
A pipe connection.
A pump with three cylinders.
The valve at the top of the pump in a beam pump.
Ten threads per inch.
An equation that predicts the minimum gas flow to lift liquids in wells above 1000 psi flowing pressure.
A transient wave is a wave that has a definite beginning and eventually dies out.
Triethylene glycol.
An isolation device commonly used in fracturing to protect the tree from pressure and proppant erosion.
A deposit of heavy oil, usually with API gravity less than about 18o.  May have sand content of 50%.
Tight gas sands.
The time that a cement slurry will remain pumpable at temperature and pressure.
A section in a part of the wellhead that accommodates the tubing hanger.
A pattern template for identifying a specific thread type.  Also referred to as "Thread Gauge".
A specialized seal shape.
A structure, bed or identifiable rock feature that allows correlation of depth control in an area.
Usually an unmanned diving vehicle that performs repairs or maintenance on a subsea well.
A percent interest paid to the mineral owner on the value of fluids produced from a lease.
Really overbalanced perforating, see EOP or extreme overbalanced perforating.

Unproved reserves are based on geologic and/or engineering data similar to that used in estimates of proved reserves; but technical, contractual, economic, or regulatory uncertainties preclude such reserves being classified as proved. Unproved reserves may be further classified as probable reserves and possible reserves. Unproved reserves may be estimated assuming future economic conditions different from those prevailing at the time of the estimate. The effect of possible future improvements in economic conditions and technological developments can be expressed by allocating appropriate quantities of reserves to the probable and possible classifications (SPE).
The study of mechanical rock behaviors under changing loads and stresses.

A function that describes the spatial behavior of a regionalized variable. The random function has two components: (1) a regional structure manifesting some degree of spatial autocorrelation and lack of independence in the proximal values of zi; and (2) a local, random component.
Gas as it is produced from the reservoir.  Raw gas may contain methane, heavier hydrocarbons and other nonhydrocarbon gasses such as CO2, H2S, nitrogen or helium.
In the context of logging, Rxo is a shallow formation resistivity, usually of the flushed zone, from a very shallow reading device.
The mineral owners share of production, taken in oil rather than in cash.
or RFT is a tool that isolates small sections of the pay and removes fluid samples and takes pressures.
The string of sucker rods used in beam pumping a well.
A retrievable plug set in a non-profile segment of the downhole pipe string.
In the context of logging, Rt is true formation resistivity.
The choice node in a decision tree from which all branches emanate. The node the value of which is calculated when the tree is solved.
A low power radioactive isotope used to tag water or other fluid for tracing the path of fluid in the reservoir or in a well.

Result of impacting one or more potential outcomes from an uncertainty assessment with risk. Risks might take the form of specific losses (i.e., costs), the impact of the failure (failure to achieve a goal), or other representation. Risk weighting is expressed in a risk-weighted value such as Net Risk-Weighted Value, and Economic Risk-Weighted-Resource Value,  other number of risk weighted parameters,  and/or by impacting the Y-axis (probability) intercept of a cumulative-frequency curve on a cumulative frequency plot.
Disassemble the equipment that was placed around a well for a specific work operation.
In the context of coiled tubing, runaway is an uncontrolled run-in of coiled tubing into a wellbore.
Force exerted by a centralizer against the casing to keep it away from the wellbore wall.
One of the hydraulically actuated rams in a blow out preventer (blind, shear, pipe or slip).
Reciprocate.
A drift dropped through tubulars on the rig floor before joint make up.
Properties that describe the physical state of a rock; porosity, permeability, UCS, density, etc.
A deviation drilling method where the BHA is turned through a steerable component at the bottom of the well that directs the path of the bit.
Materials (boards, rocks, etc.) arranged to mark a walkway or a barrier.
The drive bushing on the rotary table that turns the kelly.
Commonly written Krw.
Perforating charge explosive. Cyclotrimethaylenetrinitramine.
An exploratory well drilled in a basin where no other wells (or too few wells to define the basin) have been drilled. (Some areas use a specific distance between wells).
The gas lift gas produced from a well that is transferred into the pipeline.
Proved, probable plus possible reserves.
Without a drilling or workover rig (may involve a wireline unit, snubbing unit, or coiled tubing unit).
A piston pump.
The Darcy equation describing radial movement of fluids in laminar flow through a porous media.
In the context of drilling, RSS is a rotary steerable system.
Reservoir barrels.
The female coupling on sucker rods.

In the context of seismic, residual gravity field is a short wavelength component of field density variations within high density basement and/or low density overburden.  Anomalies in the residual field are usually of interest in general exploration.
A measurement of roughness of the surface of a passage.
-In general terms, risk premium is the difference between the certainty equivalent (from a decision tree using a utility function) and the expected value of the original (value laden) tree.
A tool used to run and set a plug or other device.

Possible reserves are those unproved reserves which analysis of geological and engineering data suggests are less likely to be recoverable than probable reserves. In this context, when probabilistic methods are used, there should be at least a 10% probability that the quantities actually recovered will equal or exceed the sum of estimated proved, plus probable, plus possible reserves.  In general, possible reserves may include (1) reserves which, based on geological interpretations, could possibly exist beyond areas classified as probable, (2) reserves in formations that appear to be petroleum bearing, based on log and core analysis but may not be productive at commercial rates, (3) incremental reserves attributed to infill drilling that are subject to technical uncertainty, (4) reserves attributed to improved recovery methods when (a) a project or pilot is planned, but not in operation and (b) rock, fluid, and reservoir characteristics are such that a reasonable doubt exists that the project will be commercial, and (5) reserves in an area of the formation that appears to be separated from the proved area by faulting and geological interpretation indicates the subject area is structurally lower than the proved area. Often referred to as P3 (SPE).
Restoring land to its pre-development condition.
A circulating connection that allows pipe rotation.  Used in cementing with non top-drive rigs.
In the context of a pipe inspection, radiographic inspection is an x-ray inspection.
The percent of the initial in-place hydrocarbon that can be recovered in the project.
Rig up.
The distance at which the variogram reaches the sill or the correlogram reaches zero correlation. Also known as the correlation range or the correlation scale.
Re-enterable through tubing gravel pack system.
Retrievable bridge plug.

Proved reserves are those quantities of petroleum which, by analysis of geological and engineering data, can be estimated with reasonable certainty to be commercially recoverable, from a given date forward, from known reservoirs and under current economic conditions, operating methods, and government regulations. Proved reserves can be categorized as development or undeveloped. If deterministic methods are used, the term reasonable certainty is intended to express a high degree of confidence that the quantities will be recovered. If probabilistic methods are used, there should be at least a 90% probability that the quantities actually recovered will equal or exceed the estimate. Often referred to as P1, sometimes referred to as “proven” (Reserve definitions are from SPE).
To fracture a zone after the initial attempt.  Refracs may be to correct a problem during the initial frac or to expose new pay after stresses in the rock have been modified by production.
A record of the oil moved from a storage tank or through a pipeline to custody of another company.
-In the context of asphaltene micelle, resin is a cyclic material that, along with maltenes, helps keep asphaltenes tied up a micelles in suspension.
Resin coated sand.

Any added reserves to an already described reservoir, due to drilling, testing, production, etc., that establishes new data on reserves or production limits outside the previously known limits of the reservoir(s).
String RPM.
A diverter that is used in acids.  Best for high permeability and fractures.

Behind-pipe reserves are expected to be recovered from zones in existing wells, which will require additional completion work or future re-completion prior to the start of production (SPE). Proximity Log:   pad contact tool that measures resistivity.
A take up real for hose, coiled tubing or cable.
A non-permanent packer meant to be retrieved.
A centralizer with ribs that do not bow or flex.
Tank or pit for used/discarded mud, or a secondary mud supply.
In the context of being tubular, radial stress stresses inward and outward along the tubing radius.

Developed reserves are expected to be recovered from existing wells, including reserves behind pipe.  Improved recovery reserves are considered developed only after the necessary equipment has been installed, or when the costs to do so are relatively minor.  Developed reserves may be sub-categorized as producing or non-producing. (SPE).
General laborer in the field.
An independent hydrocarbon holding rock.
A fractional interest in a project retained by a previous owner.
-Relative permeability modifier.
-In the context of a drilling rig, a rat hole is the hole through the rig floor where the kelly can be stored when it has to be disconnected.
To move a pipe up and down. Usually done to help remove mud or cuttings during well cleanup or placement of cement.
In the context of subsea, RAPPS is a riser annulus pressure protection system.

The correct name for a ground-roll wave.  A Rayleigh wave is a surface wave that propagates along the Earth/air interface, not in the body of the Earth.  A Rayleigh wave creates an elliptical motion of Earth particles along its propagation path.  The horizontal particle displacement associated with this ellipse is oriented in the direction of wave propagation.  The horizontal displacements associated with Love waves and Rayleigh waves are orthogonal to each other.
Go into the hole.

Reserves subcategorized as producing are expected to be recovered from completion intervals which are open and producing at the time of the estimate.  Improved recovery reserves are considered producing only after the improved recovery project is in operation. (SPE).
Rate of penetration.
Heat transfer without convection or conduction.  Sunshine is radiant heat.
In the context of rigging, a reeve is a string wire or cable through a pulley.
Wellbore radius.  Typically shown as Rw.
Thermodynamic comparison (k = cp/cv) of the ratio of a specific heat (k) at a constant pressure (cp) to a specific heat at a constant volume (cv).  The ratio range for most gasses is 1.2 to 1.4.
Reservoir drainage radius.  Typically shown as Re.
Return on investment.
A wireline-run, round, rough file like device useful for scraping hard deposits on tubing walls.
Typically a well drilling or service unit capable of pulling and running joined tubing.
Ring tool joint or ring tool joint flange.
Resistive thermal device, used for temperature measurement.
Request for Information: similar to a contracts tender, but has less strict legal constraints.
An upper tree connection profile that allows remote connection of a tree running tool.

A parameter that defines the amplitude of the wave that reflects from an interface.  The magnitude of a reflection coefficient at an interface is linearly proportional to the difference in seismic impedance across that interface.  The algebraic sign of a reflection coefficient defines the polarity of the reflection event.
Proved plus probable reserves.
A company involved in upgrading hydrocarbons to saleable products.
To move the primary completion from one zone to another.  May involve reperforating, running other tubulars or setting a new packer.
A skin value that increases with flow rate.  Generally recognized as a turbulence induced skin.
The connection from the mud pump to the stand pipe. Also called the mud hose or kelly hose.

Proved Developed Reserves are those Proved Reserves that can be expected to be recovered through existing wells and facilities and by existing operating methods. Improved recovery reserves can be considered as Proved Developed Reserves only after an improved recovery project has been installed and favorable response has occurred or is expected with a reasonable degree of certainty. (See Developed Reserves) (SPE)

The products generated from conditional simulation. Realizations are equally probable, and they preserve the variance expressed by the regionalized variable. The sum of many realizations approaches the kriged solution.

A semipermeable membrane that will allow water to pass but not salt.  Salt water is pressured into the face of the membrane, the water passes through but the salt cannot pass.  The filter has to be backwashed regularly to remove the accumulated salt. The process is relatively slow.
Reserves consistent with the cost recovery plus profit hydrocarbons that are recoverable under the terms of the contract or lease are typically reported by the upstream contractor (SPE).

The probability of an event happening times the impact of its occurrence on operations. (Impact is the effect on conditions or people if the hazard is realized (occurs) in practice and potential is the likelihood that the impact will occur.)
Resin coated proppant.
Fluids and solids flowing out of a well during circulating.
Request for quote.
A hole enlargement tool to open up a open hole or a window through the casing.
A frangible seal that can isolate a section of a well while the tubing is isolated and then be broken to bring in the well.

Proved Undeveloped Reserves are those Proved Reserves that are expected to be recovered from future wells and facilities, including future improved recovery projects which are anticipated with a high degree of certainty in reservoirs which have previously shown favorable response to improved recovery projects. (See Undeveloped) (SPE).
A term describing a resistance to flow that increases exponentially with flow and may disappear when the flow rate is dropped.
Root cause failure analysis.
A not re-usable, metal-to-metal seal. Used between spools of a wellhead and in other equipment such as flanges.

Pressuring up with supply gas and then opening the well. This works for wells without packers where the annulus can be used as a pressure charge chamber.  When a well has a packer, the effect may also work if the liquids are pushed into the formation and then brough back with the extra gas for lift.
A log device that emits a burst of tracer and tracks its movement.  May “see” a foot or so outside casing in good circumstances.  Normal for injection wells.
One of various logs that measure some component of resistivity.

A description of a large volume water frac (ungelled water) where proppant sand is pumped at ¼ to ½ lb/gal.  Normally at very high rates (25 to 50+ bpm).  For very low permeability, non water sensitive formations.
Ready to service; time for a service company to be on location.
An electronic device which receives, amplifies and transmits the signal.
Chemicals that attempt to change the permeability of a pore if another fluid tries to flow.  A common approach in water control but with very mixed results.
Pulling a string of pipe from a well and returning to bottom.
A layer of dense (sealing) rock above a permeable strata.
The comparison of permeability after testing with the additive compared to initial permeability.
An unstable form of an element that emits nuclear radiation through radioactive decay.
In the context of chemical, a reduction is a gain of electrons in a reaction.
Rig down.
To re-equip a tool to be run back into the well.
The interior surface metal roughness of a pipe.  Rough pipes have higher friction.
See Uncertainty map.
Measurement of a substance (or rock) to resist the flow of electric charge. Opposite of Conductance.
Pipe through which liquid travels upward.
One of several reservoir drive methods including volumetric, depletion, gravity, gas cap, solution gas expansion, water drive, etc.
R/P, ratio of size of the field to the annual production capacity of that field.  The R/P is used to estimate the field’s productive life.
The lowest required reporting level for a material.

The pH of a soil solution is a measure of the active acidity [concentration of dissolved free hydrogen ions (H+)] in the soil solution. A low pH indicates an excess of hydro gen ions compared to hydroxyl ions (OH-). The lower the pH the greater the acidity in the soil, and the scale is logarithmic. In very acid soils (pH < 5), trivalent aluminum (AI+3) which is a component of numerous clay minerals becomes increasingly soluble. When dissolved, each aluminum ion is strong enough to split three water molecules (by three stages of hydrolysis) in order to bond with the three hydroxyl ions thus released. This releases three hydrogen ions to the soil solution, and further increases the acidity. When chemical amendments are added to neutralize an acid soil, the amount of chemical amendment applied (lime) must be sufficient to neutralize both the free hydrogen ions (H+) and the three species of free aluminum ions [AI+3, AI(OH)+2, and AI(OH)2+1] which are still capable of causing further hydrolysis and acidification. Because of the complex reactions involved, the amount of lime required to balance the pH is determined by titrating a known mass of soil with a base representing lime. When the titration stabilizes at an appropriate endpoint (e.g., pH = 7.0), the amount of base used correlates with the amount of lime which must be added to neutralize the hydrogen ions and aluminum ions. Reserve acidity is the combined acid potential of H+, Al+3, AI (OH)+2, and AI (OH)2+1 ions adsorbed on clay colloids, whereas active acidity is free H+ in the soil solution (not adsorbed).

A decision making tool that allows examination of the level and significance of workplace risk for humans, equipment, weather, operations or other conditions. Determines the probability of risk occurring, the impact the risk will have and how to mitigate the risk. Encompasses the methods of: Monte Carlo simulation, decision trees, and general uncertainty analysis.
Residual oil zone
Commonly written Krg.
The assembly of gears and connections that spins the kelly.
A downward bending of strata that often forms a structural trap for oil and gas.  The bending movement is initiated by tectonic forces.
Circulating down the annulus and up the tubing.

Hardness measuring scales relating penetration of a small indentation ball to ultimate yield strength, used to establish steel harness.  Rockwell C scale is used in determination of metal hardness limit to control stress chloride cracking.
The portion of reserves that can be recovered by currently available technologies.
RPB or release prevention barrier is liquid containment barrier installed underneath an aboveground storage tank that is watertight to the liquid being stored.
