The process of identifying and evaluating the technical and non-technical risks associated with a project.  It includes the amount or degree of potential danger perceived (by an assessor) when determining a course of action to accomplish a given task. Risk assessment may be qualitative or quantitative.
Request for proposal.
Break up the formation into pieces to improve the flow path.

A beam lift artificial lift method.  Useful for low rate wells (to 1200 BPD) of moderate depth (to 12,000 ft).  One of the few lift systems to be able to remove all but a gas gradient of back pressure from the reservoir.
A valve in a pressurized system that is set to open and relieve pressure at a certain pressure level.
Radioactive densiometer.  Fluid density measuring device.
Reference Kelly bushing or rotary Kelly bushing.
Return on capital employed.
A pipe 34 to 48 ft in length.

Any added reserves to an already described reservoir, due to drilling, testing, production, etc., that establishes new data on reserves or production limits outside the previously known limits of the reservoir(s).

Condensate that precipitates in the pore space of the rock in a previously dry gas (single phase) reservoir as the pressure drops below the dew point. The building condensate severely reduces the permeability to gas.
A rock containing porosity, permeability, sufficient hydrocarbon accumulation and a sealing mechanism to form a reservoir from which commercial flows of hydrocarbons can be produced.
Proved reserves.

The volume of liquid hydrocarbons that is estimated to be recoverable from the formation under planned production methods. This volume depends strongly on the revenue received from the oil and the operating cost because these economic factors will determine which recovery methods are employed and the duration of production.
Restriction enhancement drill (under reamer).
A rig that spins a drill string with a bit on bottom.
Resin coated sand slurry pack.
To stand pipe in the derrick.
The pore pressure in the reservoir, usually at current value unless otherwise specified.
Reservoir description tool.
Depth of investigation of a tool or logging process.
Using an injected plastic to increase the grain-to-grain bond strength in the formation.
A beam lift term where the pump is filled with gas from pump-off or too fast of an operating speed (rod speed).
The ability to perform a design function at a specified set of conditions over a target time period.
Resumed.
Response surface
Rotating BOP.
A term usually meaning flash setting of a cement or other material. May be intended or unintended.
In the context of beam lift, range of load is the difference in the peak load at the polished rod on the upstroke and the minimum load on the downstroke.
Remote operated vehicle, usually an unmanned underwater work vehicle.
The speed of a drill bit or a clean-out nozzle in penetrating a formation or a wellbore deposit.
A pipe 25 to 34 ft in length.
Remote telemetry unit.
A pipe 16 to 25 ft in length.
-A variable created by a random process whose values follow a probability distribution, such as a normal distribution.
In the context of failures, root cause is the most basic reason for a failure.
A tool used to locate, equalize and retrieve a plug or orther settable downhole device.
The radius of the guide arch, reel or bend through which a pipe is moved.
A steep-sided channel resulting from accelerated erosion. A rill is generally a few inches deep and not wide enough to be an obstacle to farm machinery.
Root cause analysis.
Commonly written Kro.

In the context of seismic activity, reduction-to-equator is A mathematical transformation of the total magnetic intensity field at its observed inclination (I) and declination (D) to that of the magnetic equator.  I=0o.
The portion of reserves that can be recovered by currently available technologies.
Returns.
Rack phase difference.
Acronym for risk adjusted return on capital. One of many metrics pertaining to risk; specifically the ratio of the mean NPV to the difference between the mean and the P5 value.
An unstable isotope of an element that decays spontaneously, emitting radiation.

A general term for the layer or mantle of fragmental and unconsolidated rock mate rial, whether residual or transported and of highly varied character, that nearly everywhere forms the surface of the land and overlies or covers the bedrock.
NRe.
Circulating the contents of a surface tank.
A variable that has some degree of spatial autocorrelation and lack of independence in the proximal values of zi .

Undeveloped reserves are expected to be recovered:   (1) from new wells on undrilled acreage, (2) from deepening existing wells to a different reservoir, or (3) where a relatively large expenditure is required to (a) recomplete an existing well or (b) install production or transportation facilities for primary or improved recovery projects (SPE).
In the context of seismic, RTE is Reduction-To-Equator.
A member of the rig crew.

Reserves subcategorized as non-producing include shut-in and behind-pipe reserves.  Shut-in reserves are expected to be recovered from (1) completion intervals which are open at the time of the estimate, but which have not started producing, (2) wells which were shut-in for market conditions or pipeline connections, or (3) wells not capable of production for mechanical reasons. (SPE).
The connection of the wireline to a threaded Roping:   sand and proppant falling through a vertical pipe faster than the downflow of fluid during placement of propping.  Bridging may occur.
Rig down for night.
The time, based on the separator volume and shape and the fluid flow rate that produced fluids spend in a separator.  It is based on the time needed to separate an emulsion.
Radial flow valve.
Rig down, move off or out.
A reflected wave is the portion of a wave that does not pass through a geometric or material discontinuity.
In the context of a pipe, an RH is a right hand thread.
Removing gravel or cement by shifting the packer or opening the sleeve and circulating out of a well by reverse circulating.
The percentage of the hydrocarbon in place that can be produced with each production plan:   primary, secondary and tertiary.
Rock or mineral fragments having a diameter of 2 mm or more (e.g., pebbles, cobbles, stones, and boulders).

R226, one of the natural isotopes that as a trace element may incorporate into the matrix of naturally forming barium or strontium sulfate scale and make it a very low level radioactive material (NORM scale).

In the context of coiled tubing, a roll-on connector is a type of connector (with grooves around its diameter on one end and threads on the other) is slipped inside the coiled tubing and the wall of the coiled tubing is deformed by a roller-type device into the grooves, securely connecting the BHA to the coiled tubing.
A chemical that slows a reaction.  In cementing, retarders slow the set time of the cement and prolong the pumpability of the cement.
Tear apart.
Actions taken to enter a well after it has been plugged or otherwise isolated.
Connate water that will not be displaced.  See also Irreducible Water.

The right to take an action at a specified cost for a specified duration. Similar to financial options but with a variety of actions, often having to do with either changing the scope or the timing of the project.
A sand that has been run through sieves a second time to remove fines and course particles.
Roughness of a hole.

The study of the deformation and flow of matter. Real fluids include non-elastic solids, non-Newtonian fluids and viscoelastic substances. The added materials that provide viscosity range from clays to polymers to complex surfactant chemistry.

In the context of seismic activity, a reduction-to-pole is a mathematical transformation of the total magnetic intensity field at its observed inclination (I) and declination (D) to that of the north magnetic pole.  I=90o,  D=0.
Coral reef built deposits.  Among the highest permeability reservoirs because of connected voids if there has not been extensive chemical modification.
In the context of an engine, revs are revolutions per minute.
A part of the BHA designed to separate on rate, pull or a ball drop.

Probable reserves are those unproved reserves which analysis of geological and engineering data suggests are more likely than not to be recoverable. In this context, when probabilistic methods are used, there should be at least a 50% probability that the quantities actually recovered will equal or exceed the sum of estimated proved plus probable reserves.  In general, probable reserves may include (1) reserves anticipated to be proved by normal step-out drilling where sub-surface control is inadequate to classify these reserves as proved, (2) reserves in formations that appear to be productive, based on well log characteristics, but lack core data or definitive tests and which are not analogous to producing or proved reservoirs in the area, (3) incremental reserves attributable to infill drilling that could have been classified as proved if closer statutory spacing had been approved at the time of the estimate, (4) reserves attributable to improved recovery methods that have been established by repeated commercially successful applications when (a) a project or pilot is planned, but not in operation and (b) rock, fluid, and reservoir characteristics appear favorable for commercial application, (5) reserves in an area of the formation that appears to be separated from the proved area by faulting and the geologic interpretation indicates the subject area is structurally higher than the proved area, (6) reserves attributable to a future workover, treatment, re-treatment, change of equipment, or other mechanical procedures, where such procedure has not been proved successful in wells which exhibit similar behavior in analogous reservoirs, and (7) incremental reserves in proved reservoirs where an alternative interpretation of performance or volumetric data indicates more reserves than can be classified as proved. Often referred to as P2 (SPE).
Recirculating mixer.
Ranges from 125 to 200 lb/ft3.
A rod pump with extremely loose tolerances (an loose seals) that may be temporarily run in a well to pump fluid that contains sand.  Used for clean-ups after a fracture treatment.
Rev Dust™ is a trademarked friction reducing material composed of very small particles.  Also used in lab tests to simulate mud cutting fines.
Methane gas containing other low carbon chain alkanes such as ethane, propane and butane.
Wireline stem with wheels to reduce sliding friction in highly deviated wells.
A bit with multiple rotating cones that bring cutters into contact with the formation as the string is rotated.
Radial cutting torch, a tubing cutting tool that uses thermite plasma.
In the context of seismic, regional gravity field is a long wavelength component of field density variations that are usually deeper than general exploration interest.
A cement squeeze that injects cement until a resistance is built.
Reserves to production ratio.
Assemble equipment at the wellsite for work on a well.

a Weatherford valve, retrievable dummy dump valve. It is a valve that is placed in a standard gas lift mandrel and has a fracture rod for pressure shearing (then has a check valve to prevent tubing to casing communication).  It can be used to displace the completion fluid from the "A" annulus during the completion.  It can later be pulled like a regular GLV and replaced with a dummy or live valve.
Resonance occurs when the frequency of the forcing function is equal to one of the natural frequencies of the system.
Running pipe in the hole.
Reverse.
Reservoir engineer.
Repair cementing.
A reference to the amount of time that a given volume of fluid spends in a location.  Related to fluid holdup and separation. Used in both surface separators and mud removal times.
In the context of seismic, RTP is Reduction-To-Pole.
A brand name for a retrievable squeeze tool.  Retrievable, test, treat, squeeze.
Slick line.
In the context of logging, RA is radioactive.
A close offset well drilled to intersect a well that is flowing out of control and cannot be killed with conventional methods.
The rotating shaft in a PDM motor.
A calculation of the amount of hydrocarbon reserves that are in the formation. Proven reserves have a very high degree of recovery with wells in place and techniques that are proven.
In the context of logging, Rmf is resistivity of the mud filtrate.
Rig workover.
In the context of perforating, RTG is a retrievable thru-tubing gun.

The permeability to a specific fluid based on permeability at 100% saturation of that fluid, when two or more fluids occupy the pore space. The relative permeability may change with changing fluid saturation.
The stress level at which rock fails under shearing or distorting load. Generally the same as compressive strength.
Any log with a radioactive source, e.g., Neutron Porosity and Formation Density.  A Gamma Ray log detects naturally occurring radioactivity and does not emit.
The point on the logging tool that is the depth reference.
A permanent deformation in metal caused by taking the stress loading past the maximum elastic point.
A downhole, surface readable gauge.
Any mixing device that circulates the fluid through one or more tanks with the intent of more evenly blending the fluid.
The driving force in the reservoir, usually gas cap, dissolved gas, water drive, gravity, or compaction of sediments.
A Tee fitting in the top of a rod pumped well.  The side ort allows the pumped fluids to flow into the surface lines.
Water extracted from the ground during oil production processes. Produced water is often, but not always high in salts and usually contains some hydrocarbons.
A downhole device used to collect reservoir samples at pressure.
A high pressure valve with a rotatable plug that allows or denies flow.
A small tube used for sensing pressures in a flowing stream.
In the context of reserves, pud means proved undeveloped.
Pressure temperature survey.
Elastomer seals on a packer.
Pressure safety valve.
A field instrument capable of detecting certain petroleum hydrocarbon vapors at low concentrations.
P&A.
The main type of power source for an application.
The amount of the reserves recovered by primary production, i.e., without injected fluid pressure support.
Pressure at the surface.  Typically displayed as Ps.
The innermost casing string that straddles and isolates the producing interval.
The first completion in a well.
Either a density function or a cumulative distribution (i.e., a functional relationship between a random variable X and its probability).
Any packer that forms a seal between tubing and annulus during production.
See Precipitation evaporation index.

In the context of a gas lift, a production pressure operated valve is a production fluid enters the valve and acts on the effective bellows area, compressing the bellows against the precharge pressure, lifting the needle off the seat and opening the valve.  The injection gas then flows through the seat, through the reverse-flow check valve and into the tubing.
A description of the flow properties (viscosity) of a fluid.  Power law fluids are characterized by decreasing viscosity with increasing shear.
The unconsolidated organic and mineral material in which soil forms.
Pressure.
-In the context of gas lift, PVC is the closing pressure at depth for a gas lift valve.
The amounts of the various soil separates in a soil sample, usually expressed as weight percentages.
Production technical limits.
A loss of permeability in a reservoir rock.  Often so severe that the pinch out becomes a barrier or a seal.
In the context of a rig, a pulling unit is a well servicing rig used specifically for pulling rods and tubing.
In the context of corrosion, passivation is the reduction of the anodic reaction rate.
Extremely localized attack that results in holes in the metal.  Will accelerate after start.
Hydraulic workover/snubbing tubing running term-when the weight of the pipe is not sufficient to pull the pipe into a well against the surface pressure and additional force (snubbing) is required.
Pounds per square inch absolute.
A slightly smaller I.D. that the tubing above it in a tool or profile that allows a set of seals to provide isolation.
Making a kriging estimate at a specific point (e.g., at a grid node or a well location).
Tools used in makingup pipe connections.
The geologic time from 570 million years ago to be beginning of the earth. Most rocks in this period have no hydrocarbons.
-In the context of drilling, pocket is the old term for rat hole.
A series of injection and production wells in a regular arrangement.
Well sorted and consistently sized sand or man-made materials that are  injected with the frac fluid to hold the fracture faces apart after pressure is released.
A fluid, usually dead oil or water, pumped downhole to operate a pump.
Professional development plan.
See Admissibility (of semivariogram models).
The main rocking unit of a rod pumped well.  Older uses were in central power units.

The likelihood that the impact or event will occur. Impact (or consequence) is the effect on conditions or people if the hazard is realized (occurs) in practice and probability is the likelihood that the impact will occur. Risk is a function of probability and impact (consequence).  With discrete data, it is determined by taking the number of occurrences for the particular type of event being considered and dividing that by the total number of outcomes for the event. Expressed as a deterministic value (quantative single value, or, high, medium, low, etc.) or as a range of values – i.e., uncertainty – that is represented by a probability distribution.
The study of fossils.  Useful for dating and identifying rocks.
Pounds per square inch.
Unit created by combining separate mineral interests under the pooling clause of lease or agreement.
Portable measurement, alarm and control system.
A radioactive tag or marker in the casing threads or the perforation that can quickly and positively be found with a gamma ray log.
An absolute flow property indication the flow resistance of certain types of fluids.  A measurement of shear stress.
The fracturing of a perforation tunnel. Often used to bypass damage or increase permeability.
Typically a non adjustable choke using a flow bean.
Polyphenylene sulfide (e.g., Ryton™)
In the context of a clay or polymer, prehydrated refers to an already wetted to make easier to disperse and fully wet.
Parts per billion or pounds per barrel depending on the use.

The phase angle (abbreviated to "phase") of a wave is the fraction of the distance the wave has traveled relative to an arbitrary reference. The points at which the various waves cross the average amplitude line do not coincide unless the phase is zero. The phase is negative if the crossing occurs before the reference wave crossing, and positive if it occurs after the reference wave crossing.

The probabilistic (risk weighted) approach of estimating recognizes that, in the real world, there are uncertainties associated with each project component. As such, for each component, there exists probabilities of occurrence within a range of possible values.  Likewise, for the total project estimate (Being an accumulation of individual components defined by a mathematical mode), there exist probabilities of occurrence within a range of possible values.  An estimate using a range of numbers with associated probabilities of occurrence for each of the components or, at least, for each of the components that have substantive certainty.
The primary flow path from the pay to the surface.
A plug run on a work string that is being snubbed into a well that can be pumped out when the tubing is landed.

A graph of a random variable X, the vertical axis of which represents probability density, while its horizontal axis represents the variable. The PDF is the derivative of a cumulative distribution function. Thus, the area beneath the PDF graph to the left of a given value a is P(X <= a); the area under the curve between a and b represents the probability that X falls between a and b; and of course the area under the entire curve totals 1.0. The familiar bell-shaped normal curve is a PDF.
A completion with no packer.  Common where ever gas has to be kept away from ESPs and rod rumps.
Disperse into a colloid.
Reservoir pressure.
Isolating a cement injection site between a packer and a plug prior to squeezing.
The lower limit of porosity that identifies a proven productive part of a particular formation.
Any tool that is pumped down the well by injected fluid.

A specially designed perforating charge that is designed to punch through only one string of pipe and not damage the outer string.  Useful for establishing a circulation path in a well with collapsed or plugged tubing prior to killing the well.
The seven volume Petroleum Engineering Handbook (PEH) published by the Society of Petroleum Engineers (SPE).
Pore volume to breakthrough
Petajoules.  1,000,000,000,000,000 joules.  1 kilojoule = 0.9478 BTU.
-Pressure integrity test.  Typically displayed as PIT.
A radioactive tag or marker in the casing threads or the perforation that can quickly and positively be found with a gamma ray log.
Value indicating that a corresponding percentage of data or probability is less than or equal to this number, in symbols P10 for the tenth percentile. Thus, P(X <= P10) = 10%.
Free floating bacteria.
An offshore structure from which a well may be drilled or produced.

The productivity index or PI is a measure of the well potential or ability to produce and is a commonly measured well property. The symbol J is commonly used to express the productivity index; as well as, being the preferred symbol by the Society of Petroleum Engineers.

A measure in vertical inches of the average annual abundance of rainfall for a given location. The mean annual class A pan evaporation in inches is subtracted from the normal annual total precipitation in inches to give the precipitation evaporation index. The PEl is calculated to determine if supplemental water will be required to leach salts from a salt-affected soil.
In the context of a gas lift, PD is bellows gas pressure at 60oF.
A plot of P/Z vs. cumulative production that indicates compartmentalization if not a straight line.
The point where the capital cost have been earned.
Movement of gas to and through an elastomer.
The entire collection of objects under consideration. Often, the population is the underlying theoretical distribution from which a sample is drawn.
A plug that is opened by pressure that is used for well suspensions.

Normal or straight carbon chain alkanes with carbon chain lengths of C18+.  The alkanes in this range solidify at temperatures from 80oF to over 200oF.  Paraffin is amorphous but may appear to have structure in slow growth examples.
Pump station.
Seal that blocks fluid communication.
Perforating depth control log.
A fire extinguished powder.
The thicker part of a pipe where threads are machined for the coupling.
Pulsed neutron log.
Latin origin is rock oil.
A geologic time period from 290 to 320 million years ago.
The fluid left in the annulus behind the packer. It may help offset pressure in the tubing or help reduce thermal losses.
An in-place, downhole repair of part of a tubing string.
Pump in spinner survey.
Poly crystalline diamond compact drill bit or cutter.
To set a plug (usually permanent) in a wellbore, giving a new bottom.
Shots per unit length.
The current time value of an income stream that extends into the future. Various calculation methods and interest rates have been applied.  Typically abbreviated as PNV.
A silica cement additive.

A cup and bar with a sliding weight, similar to a Mud Balance, but also having a screw on top with a slide valve through which a small amount of fluid could be added under pressure, collapsing the air dispersed in the fluid.  Better accuracy than an unpressurized mud balance.
A gas generating charge of explosive that is used for perf breakdown.
Any device, object, or material that blocks a flow passage.
The pressure and flow control tree on a producing well.
A homogeneous body of material that differs in properties from other phases (immiscible) – e.g., gas, liquid, solid.
A small scale test or trial used to assess the feasibility of a process to a reservoir or field.
Any land owned by the government in the US.  May compare to Crown or Federal lands in other countries.

One of the natural isotopes that as a trace element may incorporate into the matrix of naturally forming barium or strontium sulfate scale and make it a very low level radioactive material (NORM scale).  Typically shown as K40.
An enlarged section of a tank for settling solids.
A hydraulic workover/snubbing tubing running term-when the weight of the pipe is sufficient to pull the pipe into a well against the surface pressure.
In the context of a beam lift, a pump barrel is the tube through which the plunger of a rod pump reciprocates.
Pounds per gallon added. See PPG.
A unit of soil structure, such as an aggregate, crumb, prism, block, or granule, formed by natural processes (in contrast to a clod, which is formed artificially).
Pumping units used in bullheading, circulating or other operations involving liquid and foam pumping.

In the context of seismic, pseudogravity is a magnetic gravity field expression that is measured at or transformed to the magnetic pole. Susceptibility values are converted to density values and expressed as a vertical integration.
A gelled pill designed for piston-like fluid displacement.
Pipeline.
The rams in a BOP that seal around the pipe diameter for which they were sized.

A complex, non-Newtonian fluid whose shear force is not proportional to the shear rate.  Pressure is necessasry to start circulation of the static fluid.  Main low rate flow is plug flow.  Yield point is greater than zero.
A salt commonly used in brines to reduce or prevent clay swelling in the formation.
Produced water re-injection.
A pressure test of a vessel formed by the entire well or a part of the well. It usually measures the ability of a pressure vessel to hold pressure without leaking at a given pressure.
A cased-hole log capable of distinguishing between water and hydrocarbons.
In the context of risk, prescient is the foreknowledge of events. Human anticipation of the course of events.
The depth or zone in which the well is being currently produced.
In the context of brine, PCT is the pressure crystallization temperature.
In the context of a beam lift, a polished rod clamp is a device that fastens the polished rod to the bridle.
A condition when the metal shows a marked decrease in corrosion rate.
In value of information problems, the ideal case in which the predicting device makes no mistakes. Thus, for a given state of nature, the information always accurately predicts it.
A very high temperature perforating explosive.
Organophosphorus compounds that form the basis for many scale inhibitors that are squeezed into a formation and provide long term protection.
PIP™ is a trademarked name for a pin point injection packer.
Production casing.
The surface weight measurement when pulling a pipe string or wireline out of the hole.  Includes both string weight and frictional drag.
Pump in spinner temperature log.
Premature setting of packer.
Storage racks.
-In the context of a beam lift, a plunger is the traveling bar in beam lift pump internals.
Hydrostatic pressure.  Typically displayed as Ph.
The maximum potential from the best achievable production practices.
A tank with an agitation system used to more precisely mix components during a job.
Bottom-hole injection pressure.
-In the context of a gas lift, PT is tubing pressure.
An attachment to tubing or a plug that looks like an upside down umbrella. It helps hold cement or sand as a plug is started.  It has metal ribs and a tough fabric between the ribs.
The rate at which pressure builds up after a flow period.  It is related to permeability, fluid viscosity, pressure differential, hole volume, zone thickness, and time.
A volume of fluid, without proppant, injected in front of a frac job to establish frac width.
The own-use power consumed by a geothermal plant to produce hot water and/or reinject warm water (for example where as HT ESP is needed to lift the water at the required rates).
-In the context of a contract, PSC is a production sharing contract.
An analysis of well flow using a test that shuts the well in following a flow period and measures the rate or pressure build-up.
A chemist that specializes in hydrocarbon flow and emulsion separation problems.
When the well has produced sufficient net revenue to pay the cost of drilling and equipping the well.
Pick up.
The lowest temperature that a hydrocarbon fluid can be flowed before gelling or turning solid.  Related to pumpability.
A seal formed in the tubing or around the top of a screen or packer to isolate a flow path.
Pumping all the fluid out of the wellbore to the point where free gas enters the pump.

A thermal chemical process responsible for hydrocarbon generation from organic rich materials, like Kerogen, under pressure at very high temperatures. At temperatures of 300 - 600 °C (570 - 1100⁰F), increasing amounts of hydrogen gas will also be released from kerogen.
A log-log plot of resistivity (x-axis) vs. porosity. Helps determine which zones contain hydrocarbon.

Soil - The negative logarithm of the hydrogen-ion activity of a soil. The degree of acidity (or alkalinity) of a soil as determined by means of a glass electrode or indicator at a specified moisture content of soil-water ratio and expressed in terms of the pH scale (see reaction, soil).
Production engineering supervisor.
A volume of gelled fluid mixed for a specific purpose.  A fluid loss pill for example.
Pieces of charge cases, loading tubes, and alignment equipment generated by firing the gun. They may or may not be left in the well.
Plug back total depth.
A solid material that drops out of an over saturated solution.  Usually driven by an upset of equilibrium.
A chemical treatment of the tubulars to remove pipe dope, mill scale and mud or cement residue.
A mechanical valve that opens at a preset pressure to relive pressure in a vessel.
Chemicals derived from oil or gas.
-In the context of drilling fluids, PV is plastic viscosity.
A frac that grows up and outward.
A piece of the copper liner that forms a cylindrical slug.
A conical shaped reef-type deposit, usually with good permeability and porosity.
A high volume flow choke.
A measurement of a fluids capability to be pumped.  Usually refers to cement slurry and is also called the thickening time.
The first attempt at creating a cement seal in the annulus.

A range of the pore sizes plotted against frequency of that size. Mercury is injected at step-wise increasing pressures where large pore fill first, followed by smaller pores at successfully higher pressures.  Volumes injected at different pressures indicate the pore size distribution.
A surface rod pup joint that slides through the stuffing box on a beam pumped well.  The part is highly polished and generally chrome plated.  It must not be exposed to HCl acid.
An organic deposit, which, with time and burial stresses would become coal.
Permanent completion perforating or progressive cavity pump.
Prejob task hazard analysis.
The number of perforations per foot or per meter.
Perform™ is the trademarked name for a nodal analysis program.
The mass per unit volume of soil particles.
In the context of subsea, PLET is a pipeline end terminal.
Polytetrafluoroethylene, (e.g., TEFLON™).
A removable PBR anchored into the top of a packer.

A small (sometimes) diameter hole drilled through a pay zone to determine the pay top and bottom or various contacts, before the main well position is selected.  May also use a pilot hole to better control influx rate.
Detonation cord for explosives.  Primacord™ is a trademarked name for detonation cord. Normally used in a perforating gun.
Petroleum engineer or production engineer.
Positive displacement motor.
A unit of pressure equal to 1/100,000 of a bar.
In the context of rocks, the permeability of a layer is commonly written Kj.

A hole made through the casing and cement and into the formation.  It has a characteristic entrance hole and penetration.  It is the flow path from the formation to the wellbore in a cased and cemented completion.
Primacord™ is a detonating cord for perforating guns.
A layer of proppant with gaps between the grains.  High capacity but weak.
Pitting resistance equivalent number.
Resin formed by condensation of polybasic and monobasic acids with polyhydric alcohols.
Packing the perforations with gravel to prevent tunnel collapse.

Probable reserves are those unproved reserves which analysis of geological and engineering data suggests are more likely than not to be recoverable. In this context, when probabilistic methods are used, there should be at least a 50% probability that the quantities actually recovered will equal or exceed the sum of estimated proved plus probable reserves.  In general, probable reserves may include (1) reserves anticipated to be proved by normal step-out drilling where sub-surface control is inadequate to classify these reserves as proved, (2) reserves in formations that appear to be productive, based on well log characteristics, but lack core data or definitive tests and which are not analogous to producing or proved reservoirs in the area, (3) incremental reserves attributable to infill drilling that could have been classified as proved if closer statutory spacing had been approved at the time of the estimate, (4) reserves attributable to improved recovery methods that have been established by repeated commercially successful applications when (a) a project or pilot is planned, but not in operation and (b) rock, fluid, and reservoir characteristics appear favorable for commercial application, (5) reserves in an area of the formation that appears to be separated from the proved area by faulting and the geologic interpretation indicates the subject area is structurally higher than the proved area, (6) reserves attributable to a future workover, treatment, re-treatment, change of equipment, or other mechanical procedures, where such procedure has not been proved successful in wells which exhibit similar behavior in analogous reservoirs, and (7) incremental reserves in proved reservoirs where an alternative interpretation of performance or volumetric data indicates more reserves than can be classified as proved. Often referred to as P2 (SPE).
Fluid moves as a unit.
Personal protective equipment.
Parts per million.
Pressure build up.
A polished bore, typical in a packer to accept the seal assembly on the end of tubing. Abbreviated PBR.
A short rod for spacing out a rod string.
An era of geologic time lasting from 570 million years ago to 245 million years ago.
A synthetic or man-made gelling agent that increases viscosity and helps control leakoff.
The calculated solubility point of an ion in solution (scale/brine stability calculations).
Hydraulic power make up tools suspended above the rig floor.
Core removed from the formation and preserved by sealing or freezing to prevent drying or other altering of the rock or fluids.
Pulsed neutron capture.
The output of the pump at stated conditions divided by the ideal output.
Hardening caused by precipitation of a material (specific element or alloy) from a supersaturated solution.
The principle underground transport of produced gas and oil.
Oil with the BS&W removed and the contaminates brought within the contract specifications.
Pipeline natural gas.
A complex non-Newtonian fluid without thixotrophy. Flow starts with pressure but apparent viscosity decreases instantaneously with increasing rate of shear.
Horizons or layers in the soils that are strongly compacted, indurated, or very high in clay content.
J or PI. A measure of a well’s ability to flow.  Applies above the bubble point.
The total depth of penetration including the casing thickness, the cement and the formation.
Pounds per thousand barrels.
A rate, measured in distance per time or the penetration of a bit or cleanout sub through a formation or a deposit.
A lubricant, anti-gall, and sealer applied to the pin threads when making a connection in the pipe.
The depth of the well to the top of the last permanent plug.
A form of a financial option that entitles the owner to sell one share of a commodity at a specific (strike) price on or before a specific (exercise) date.
Various forms of a tool for bond evaluation, usually an ultra sonic emitter and detector.
A selected event on a seismic record.
A geologic time period from 250 to 290 million years ago.
Prosper™ is a trademarked nodal analysis program.
Hydrocarbon producing interval.
The number of perforations per unit length of pipe in an interval.
A geologic time scale that is less than an era and greater than an epoch.

A compressional wave.  It is sometimes called a primary (P) wave because it is the portion of a seismic wavefield that arrives first at an observation point.  A P wave causes rock particles to oscillate in a direction that is perpendicular to its wavefront.
A type and structure of frozen soil found in a new cold areas of the world. May extend to depths in excess of 1000 meters.
A carrier for shaped charge explosives that punches holes through the casing and cement and into the formation.  Guns may be run on wireline or tubing.

In the context of risk, probability distribution is a mathematical relationship between the values and the associated probabilities for a variable across the entire range of possible values for that variable.  Typically, probability distributions are displayed as frequency or cumulative frequency plots.
Pressure relief valve.
A short section of casing or tubing used as a depth identifier to a collar locator log or used at the top of the well when spacing out a string prior to hanging the string.
A stream, or part of stream, that flows continuously during the year as a re­sult of groundwater discharge or surface runoff.
Positive pressure pack-off test – tubing.
The sealing plug over a charge on a reusable perforating gun.
The rate at which pressure decreases at the end of an injection.  Related to rock permeability, and to fracture closure stresses when above the fracture point.

A parameter used to describe air-gun performance.  An air-gun wavelet consists of a high-amplitude peak followed by a high-amplitude trough.  The parameter PTP defines the magnitude of the source wavelet amplitude measured from the apex of the leading peak of the wavelet to the apex of the following trough.  A high PTP value indicates a high energy output.  Typically abbreviated as PTP.
A radioactive element whose decay produces stable daughter elements.
A type of valve common on early subsurface safety valves, where higher than expected flow through an orifice can move a round ball onto a sealing surface and stops the flow.

Proved Undeveloped Reserves are those Proved Reserves that are expected to be recovered from future wells and facilities, including future improved recovery projects which are anticipated with a high degree of certainty in reservoirs which have previously shown favorable response to improved recovery projects. (See Undeveloped) (SPE).
A monitored flow test.
The downward movement of water through the soil.
The period of time which a lease is effective without being renewed.
A shaped explosive charge used for penetrating casing and cement.
Produced water treatment.
Produced water injection.
The number of significant decimals expressed in a measurement.
The total space not occupied by soil particles in a bulk volume of soil.
Packer.
A pay zone or set of pay zones with proven commercial reserves.

Phase velocity is the velocity of a given point, as defined by the phase angle on a sinusoidal wave. When the phase velocity and the frequency remain constant, it is a nondispersing wave. If the phase velocity and the frequency are not constant, the wave disperses.
Particle size distribution.

A parameter used to define the performance of a marine airgun array.  "Primary" refers to the amplitude of the wavelet created by the output pulse of high-pressure air.  "Bubble" refers to the amplitude of the wavelet created by the subsequent collapse of the air bubble in the water column.  A high PBR value (~30) is desired.  Typically abbreviated as PBR.
The angle between the shots.  The phasing can have an impact on pipe strength, formation strength and productivity.
The connecting rod from the rotating counterweights to the beam on a beam lift pumping unit.
In the context of a gas lift, PSO is surface opening pressure of the gas lift valve.
P&A.  Setting cement and mechanical plugs to seal off pays, potential leak points, fresh water zones, and the surface.
Packing the perforation with gravel to prevent tunnel collapse.
Powdered metal liner.
Where only part of the pay zone is completed. Generally used to control coning of a fluid or to select the origin of the fracture in a stimulation.
A cement job done by spotting a column of cement then lowering a liner into the cement slurry.
The study of reservoir rocks and their reactions.
Polyetheretherketone,  (Victrex™, Arlon™).
A compacted layer formed in the soil directly below the plowed layer.
Water suitable for human consumption.
A device that delivers rapid thrust or blows to the assembly containing the drill bit.
A mathematical permeability correlation, normally based on porosity and rock type.
A sieve or laser analysis of the particle sizes in a sand.
Derivatives of phosphoric acid and alcohols. Used for scale inhibitors in process flow.
A polymer with a very stable carbon chain.  A good friction reducer in small amounts, but the polymer may cause formation damage.  Can be used to gel acid, but the polymer will not break.
Drilling only part way through a reservoir (near vertical wells).
Removal of a permanent packer.

A barrier to movement of a fluid through the rock. This may be a change in the rock where the pores are no longer connected or even present, or secondary mineral growth that filling in the pore throats and natural fractures. In one sense, a permeability barrier may be another rock that acts as a seal.
A vessel through which production passes and the multi-phase fluids are broken and separated.
A stress level, beyond the elastic limit, that produces yielding in tubulars.
A comparison of sand grain sizes in a formation where there are a broad range of coarse to fine particles.
Change in pressure with depth.
In the contect of cementing, a plug container is the housing with valves and bails that controls the position and dropping of the plugs used in cementing.  Also known as a dropper.
The area of crushed rock surrounding the perforation.  Usually 30 to 70% of initial permeability and ½” or about 1cm thick.
Produced water.
A nonbeneficial, water-loving plant that derives its water from subsurface sources.

In a logging context, a petal basket flowmeter is a petal basket that reroutes all the fluid over the diameter of the wellbore into a single flow stream near the middle so an accurate measurement with a flowmeter can be made.
Pounds per gallon.  Usually used as a measure of additive, slurry or cleanout.  Actually it is pounds of proppant in a gallon volume with liquid added to make up the gallon “space”.
Produced gas within pipeline spec and under sufficient pressure to enter the pipeline against the pressure of the fluid in the pipeline.
A liner with holes drilled for fluid entry.  Not usually for sand control but may be useful for increasing hole stability or access.
-In the context of electrical, potential is the difference in electrical power level.
Production efficiency improvement.
A nipple profile with an accessible side port to the annulus.

Generally salt and/or surfactant materials designed to simulate the effect of potassium chloride in preventing clay swelling.  Substitutes may work in the wellbore but generally fail in the formation where severe swelling conditions exist.
A reliable packer designed and intended to be left in place for a long period of time that seals and holds pressure or resists movement from both directions.
In the context of lifts, a PAL is a producer, artificial lift.
Total gas (solution + free) production divided by the oil production volume. Excludes gas lift gas.
A device that forms a seal between two chambers of the well.  Packers may be equipped with slips that anchors the packer and stops movement under high pressure.
A relative measure of a material's pitting resistance in corrosive service.
Pressure volume temperature data for fluids.
Permanent downhole gauge.
The oil recovered before pressure maintenance (flooding).
A sand control screen that uses a captured gravel or resin coated gravel to assist in restraining formation sand or gravel packing gravel.
Part(s) per million. A measure of concentration of a substance in a solid, liquid, or gas. In solids ppm equates to milligrams per kilogram (mg/kg) and in liquids to milligrams per liter (mg/L).
In the context of a gas lift, PTRO is a test rack opening pressure for a gas lift valve.
A flow line clearing device, pumped through the line with normal flow.
Permanent downhole gauge.
In the context of drilling and workovers, a power swivel is  a rig floor tool that can rotate a string.
Pull out of the hole. Also POOH.
Programmable logic controller.
Premature release of packer.

Production fluid enters the valve and acts on the effective bellows area, compressing the bellows against the precharge pressure, lifting the needle off the seat and opening the valve.  The injection gas then flows through the seat, through the reverse-flow check valve and into the tubing.
The diameter of the hole in the first string of pipe penetrated by the perforator.
A polished nipple is run below blast joints to allow a pack-off set point when by-passing a damaged joint.
A type of choke that is suitable for high volume and can stand some solids.
-In the context of formation, PP is pore pressure.
In the context of reserves, PDNP is proved developed non producing.
A technique in which the entry points and the amount of fluid entering the wellbore are identified.

Proved reserves are those quantities of petroleum which, by analysis of geological and engineering data, can be estimated with reasonable certainty to be commercially recoverable, from a given date forward, from known reservoirs and under current economic conditions, operating methods, and government regulations. Proved reserves can be categorized as development or undeveloped. If deterministic methods are used, the term reasonable certainty is intended to express a high degree of confidence that the quantities will be recovered. If probabilistic methods are used, there should be at least a 90% probability that the quantities actually recovered will equal or exceed the estimate. Often referred to as P1, sometimes referred to as “proven” (Reserve definitions are from SPE).
Premature valve closure.
Pressure shut annular standing valve.
In the context of a beam lift, a parted rod is a sucker rod string that has broken or come apart in the well.
A machined design in a short piece of tubing or casing that allows a plug to set, anchor and seal.
Modifications to the character of the rock through the matrix or natural fractures, where the permeability is a function of the pressure applied to the rock through fluid pressure or earth stresses.
See Photoionization detector.
A location where a well is to be drilled.

Proved Developed Reserves are those Proved Reserves that can be expected to be recovered through existing wells and facilities and by existing operating methods. Improved recovery reserves can be considered as Proved Developed Reserves only after an improved recovery project has been installed and favorable response has occurred or is expected with a reasonable degree of certainty. (See Developed Reserves) (SPE).Developed reserves are expected to be recovered from existing wells, including reserves behind pipe.  Improved recovery reserves are considered developed only after the necessary equipment has been installed, or when the costs to do so are relatively minor.  Developed reserves may be sub-categorized as producing or non-producing. (SPE) Producing  Reserves subcategorized as producing are expected to be recovered from completion intervals which are open and producing at the time of the estimate.  Improved recovery reserves are considered producing only after the improved recovery project is in operation. (SPE). Non-producing  Reserves subcategorized as non-producing include shut-in and behind-pipe reserves.  Shut-in reserves are expected to be recovered from (1) completion intervals which are open at the time of the estimate, but which have not started producing, (2) wells which were shut-in for market conditions or pipeline connections, or (3) wells not capable of production for mechanical reasons. (SPE). Behind-pipe reserves are expected to be recovered from zones in existing wells, which will require additional completion work or future re-completion prior to the start of production (SPE).Proximity Log:   pad contact tool that measures resistivity.
For CO2 corrosion potential; the mole fraction of the gas times the total pressure.
An alkane with a 3 carbon chain.
The valve on the flow cross that controls the exit point as produced fluids flow from the tree.
A general class of cement that encompasses the most common cements used in construction and the oil field.
Process and instrument diagram. Also called P&ID.
-Put on production.
In the context of rock, plutonic igneous is magna extruded into overlying rock that is not exposed to atmospheric conditions during cooling.
Oil with API gravity greater than 30.
Pressure setting assembly. A E-line tool used to set downhole tools.  Normally uses a gas propellant charge.
PB stands for pump bailer.
A seal between or around equipment to isolate pressure or areas within the well.
A string of casing used when drilling a well to protect an outer string of pipe from drill string contact or to protect a zone.
In the context of BP, PIE is a pressure transient data base.
A wireline tool to remove paraffin deposits.
A low temperature explosive used in perforating charges.
Pump in temperature survey.
The connection between the pores, often a fraction of the pore size and an obvious restriction.

Unconfined groundwater that is separated from an underlying body of groundwater by an unsaturated zone and a confining bed. The perched zone of saturation may be either permanent, where recharge is frequent enough to maintain a saturated zone, or temporary, where recharge is insufficient.
The best producing time of a field, before decline of total production rate begins.
A mixing chamber, usually in a small tank or pod that uses a rotating paddle to mix the fluid and the additives. Also called a paddle mixer.
Petroleum Environmental Research Forum.
The opening within the rock.  Interconnected porosity is linked together and results in permeability.
Production logging tool.
Allocation of production among commingled reservoirs according to reservoir production characteristics, tests, etc.
A geologic time period from 250 to 570 million years ago.

Possible reserves are those unproved reserves which analysis of geological and engineering data suggests are less likely to be recoverable than probable reserves. In this context, when probabilistic methods are used, there should be at least a 10% probability that the quantities actually recovered will equal or exceed the sum of estimated proved, plus probable, plus possible reserves.  In general, possible reserves may include (1) reserves which, based on geological interpretations, could possibly exist beyond areas classified as probable, (2) reserves in formations that appear to be petroleum bearing, based on log and core analysis but may not be productive at commercial rates, (3) incremental reserves attributed to infill drilling that are subject to technical uncertainty, (4) reserves attributed to improved recovery methods when (a) a project or pilot is planned, but not in operation and (b) rock, fluid, and reservoir characteristics are such that a reasonable doubt exists that the project will be commercial, and (5) reserves in an area of the formation that appears to be separated from the proved area by faulting and geological interpretation indicates the subject area is structurally lower than the proved area. Often referred to as P3 (SPE).
Pressure Fall Off test - a common injector test or a test after pumping in.
A comparison of permeabilities of a fracture proppant and the formation.
In the context of seismic, a PS wave is seismic energy that has traveled partly as a P-wave and then as an S-wave; having been converted on reflection at an interface.
A well that produces hydrocarbon in commercial quantities.
Product specification level. A rating for wellheads.
Calculation of well pressure vs. depth by integrating the pressure gradient for increments of pipe length (MD).
The formation or reservoir pressure divided by the depth.
Force per unit area exerted by a fluid.
A hard, native asphalt within the pores.  Does not ordinarily move or enter into reaction.
A five carbon chain alkane. Used in the lab to check for asphaltenes (precipitates them).
Generally a petroleum containing reservoir or group of reservoirs.
Pressure activated circulating valve.
The process by which a perforating gun is lined up to fire at the correct depth.
Seals around a moving shaft or other equipment.
Pull out of the hole.
Thermoplastic fluoropolymer.
Acrylamide polymer mud.
Pounds per square foot gauge.
A step-diameter mill that makes a pilot hole then enlarges it with the upper diameter.
-In the context of a pipe, a pin is the male end of the connector.
A crack in steel resulting from stresses produced during transformation from austentite to martensite.
See Quality assurance/quality control.
Functionality, Availability, Reliability, Survivability and Interaction.
Flow rate or initial flow rate.
A geologic time period from present to 2 million years ago.
Qualitative risk assessment.
A high pressure (10,000 to 15,000 psi) profile. N signifies that it is a no go design.
Heat treating requiring austenitization followed by cooling, under conditions that austenite turns into martensite.
Flow rate.
-In the context of foam stimulation fluid, quality refers to the percent of the total volume that the internal phase comprises.
SiO2 mineral with a variety of crystal shapes.
An epoch of geologic time from present to 10,000 years ago.
See Soil horizon.
A penetration under pressure.
Thickness (or pay height).
A test of injectivity that is useful for establishing formation behavior during pumping.
An acid that reacts with clays.  Very harmful to humans in concentrated form.
An instrument that is dropped in a liquid to measure its specific gravity.
Very high temperature perforation charge explosive, hexanitrostilbene.

In the context of a well, a hostile environment is a high temperature, deep, high pressure or highly corrosive or erosive producing environment (e.g.:   depth >20,000ft or 6100m, temp >325oF or 163oC, pressure >20,000 psi, H2S or CO2 content).
Hydraulic landing nipple.
A small hole in a coating.
A pressure sensitive receiver that transforms sound to electrical signals that may be recorded.
High sulfur fuel oil.
Inclusion of water into the structure of a material.
The formation of cavities just below the surface in a metal. Growth of the near-surface blisters may result in bulges in the metal.
In a subsea context, HXT is a horizontal tree.
High pressure, low temperature.  Identification of the problem zone for hydrate formation.
The pressure exerted by a column of a single density fluid.  For a non-compressible fluid the pressure (in psi) at any depth = 0.052 x depth x fluid density in lb/gal.
Packer set by hydraulic pressure.
Oil used for residential heating.
In the context of facilities, HP is high pressure facilities and lines.
A type of plant indigenous to, or which can adapt to very saline soils.
Compounds having the OH ion. Bases or caustics.
A natural deposit of iron oxide.
An artificial lift system that is powered by injected fluid (usually water), that powers a pump similar to the rotating pump used in electrical submersible pumps.
A harmonic is a frequency that is an integer multiple of a given frequency.
Higher temperature perforation charge explosive.  A modified RDX.
A column chart based on classes or bins of equal width. The height of the bars indicates either the frequency or the relative frequency associated with the data falling into the given class.

For a strict definition, a 90o deviated well.  Actually the well covers a range of “highly” deviated wells (80o to >90o).  In the strictest terms, the deviation is measured as 90o from vertical, but tilting bedding planes may make the deviation to the bedding planes a different judgment.
Operations requiring welding, cutting, grinding, burning, etc.
Rock with differences in texture, permeability, porosity or other factors.
High energy gas stimulation.

HCl. The most common oilfield stimulation acid. A mixture of hydrogen chloride gas in water.  Useful for removing calcium scale, some mud and cement damage and very shallow stimulation of formations with some calcium in the flow path.
In the context of fracturing, HSP stands for high strength proppant.
In the context of logging, heading is the information on the well at the top of the log.
Minute cracking just under a metal’s surface caused by exposure to hydrogen sulfide gas.
A corrosion mechanism in which atomic hydrogen enters between the grains of the steel, and causes the steel to become very brittle. Abbreviated HE.
Hydrocarbon
Lower gravity, often higher viscosity oils. Normally less than 28o API gravity.
Hydroxyl ethyl cellulose, a synthetic polymer.
Pressure exerted by a column of liquid.
Soil formed under conditions of poor drainage in marshes, swamps, seepage areas, or flats.
Repels water.
Packers equipped with drag blocks or springs so rotation of the pipe unlatches the slips and sets the packer.
A separator that uses heat to speed the separation of emulsions.
In a geologic context, a heave is the horizontal displacement (travel) of a fault.
Partial isolation without using a direct seal between the device and the flow path.  Efficiency depends on fluid viscosity, clearance and flow rate.
A profile with circulation port.

An effect, also known as water hammer, in which a pressure wave can be generated behind a rapidly closed valve.  The pressure wave travels at sonic speed, reflecting off of the pipe end or the bottom of the well and returning to the valve.  If the valve is closed before the wave returns, a hydraulic impact is produced on the valve.  Extreme cases are seen with slam closures of sub surface safety valves. Much smaller effects may be produced in front of the valve in a few cases.
The opening on a tank.
High energy gas fracturing.
A block of the formation that has been raised between two faults.
A buckling characterized by maximum wall contact. Takes the form of a wound spring.
The actual weight of a pipe string measured at the surface, affected by buoyancy, friction and other factors in the wellbore.

A fibrous form of illite, also described as spider-web illite. The hairs or fibers randomly project into the pore space.  In most cases, the clay is not overly reactive with water but the fibers do act as a trap for migrating particles.
A cone shaped device for separating fluids and the solids dispersed in fluids.

A property of water that causes formation of an insoluble residue when the water is used with soap and a scale in vessels which water has been allowed to evaporate. It is primarily due to the presence of ions of calcium and magnesium, but also to ions of other alkali metals, other metals (such as iron), and even hydrogen. Hardness of water is generally expressed as ppm of CaC03 (40 ppm Ca produces a hardness of 100 ppm as CaC03), also as mg/L, and as the combination of carbonate hardness and noncarbonate hardness.
In an offshore context, HIPPS stands for high integrity pressure protection system.
Top part of the structure, expected to be the best place to encounter accumulation of hydrocarbons.
HAZ, the metal adjacent to a weld or other heated area that has been altered by the heating.
Hold up depth.
Heat affected zone.  The area around a weld or other area in the steel that has been modified by heat and, as a result, is more subject to some forms of corrosion.
A snubbing job in which the well is workover without killing the well with fluid.  Usually accomplished by multiple barriers that seal on the tubulars.
A disconnect, usually in a BHA that is activated by hydraulic pressure.
The document containing operational and test data used to transfer custody of a well from drilling to operations or production after completion or from production to drilling when repairs are needed.

A column chart based on classes or bins of equal width. The height of the bars indicates the frequency (or relative requency) or number of occurrences of data (y-axis) in size classes of equal width (x-axis).
Hydrocarbons initially in place
Usually an oil with more than 1% sulfur.

Hydril™ is the trademarked name of a manufacturer of BOP and other well equipment.  Also a common term for a section of the BOP stack that utilizes a large rubber “donut” that can seal on irregular surfaces or even on itself.
Hazardous operations.
The processes involved in the decomposition of organic matter and leading to the formation of humus.
High density polyethylene plastic.
Cleaning at less than 5,000 psi water pressure.
Halliburton Energy Services.
Connect unions on treating iron.
High sulfur.
Absorbing water from the air.
High temperature, high pressure.
Water with a high mineral content.
A perforating gun that surrounds the charges and contains much of the shock of the detonation.
Suspending sucker rods in the derrick from rod hangers.
A downhole tool centralizer that is engaged by raising hydraulic pressure.
Change in the hydraulic head per unit distance.
Hydraulic.
The area of pay closest to the casing in a highly deviated well.
A highly deviated well.
A plug placed below the BOP prior to a pressure test.

A cement squeeze technique where the cement is squeezed into a channel or leak at a low rate, then allowed to sit and dehydrate by leakoff, before again raising the pressure. The action gradually builds a dehydrated cement node that blocks the channel.

A bivariate plot on which zi and zi+h, the pairs for the value for separation distance h , are plotted as the two axes. The shape and tightness of the cloud of points is related to the value of the variogram for h.
Hydrofluoric acid.
A tertiary recovery operation, consisting of first injecting  steam, followed by flowing the well back to recover oil that has had its viscosity reduced by application of the heat.
Differences.
In the context of a drilling rig, a hook is the hook on the traveling block from which the elevators are suspended.
The amount of time required for one half of the population of radioactive atoms to decay.

A clathrate type molecule (cage) of gas and water that forms in a certain range of temperature and pressure in wells.  In flow lines, hydrates are a problem in deep-water sub sea wellheads and flow lines, but also seen in some nearly dry, onshore gas wells.   In-situ hydrates are a potential natural gas resource.

A high density energy source and clean fuel which produces only water when consumed in a fuel cell and does not produce carbon dioxide when directly combusted. Energy resources like natural gas, nuclear power, biomass, and renewable power like solar and wind can all be used to produce hydrogen through processes such as steam methane reformation, electrolysis, and pyrolysis.

A condition or object that has the potential to cause harm  risk is the probability of an event happening times the impact of its occurrence on operations. (Impact is the effect on conditions or people if the hazard is realized (occurs) in practice and potential is the likelihood that the impact will occur.)
Materials that lower the formation temperature of hydrate molecules.
Health, safety and environment -

In a drilling context, a hydraulic window is the allowable effective fluid density difference between the fracturing pressure and the pressures exerted by a fluid that are needed to control formation flow and the wellbore.
A compound formed essentially of carbon and hydrogen.
HDR or Hot dry rocks as potential targets for EGS operations.
A pipeline interchange/delivery point. Used as a benchmark in gas futures for natural gas pricing.
Mixing chamber where dry components can be evenly mixed with liquids.  The dry materials are introduced at the bottom of the hopper through a nozzle.
A fault along which there is increasing offset or separation along the strike of the fault plane.  Measured from the initial point of separation.
A method of attaching a valve or port to a pressurized line without removing the pressure.
Having affinity for water.

A type of build up pressure test plot. The Horner plot uses a recording of the pressure during pressure build-up to predict its virgin reservoir pressure. The slope (m) of the extrapolated line reflects the nature of the reservoir rock and the fluids flowing through the rock.
Coefficient describing the total resistance to heat loss from a producing pipe to its surroundings.  Includes heat loss by conduction, convection and radiation.
Hipp Tripper™ is the trademarked name for a brand of a tool used to deliver rapid impact stokes to a small BHA downhole. Operated by fluid flow. Usually run on CT.

A diversion technique for injecting fluids into separate zones without added diverters.  Limited numbers of perforations or set obstructions in the wellbore can build pressure at higher rates and cause diverting to lower permeability or damaged zones.
Commonly written Kh.
Hydraulic horsepower.
The head of a beam lift pump jack, onto which the bridle to the yoke and polish rod attaches.
A larger device (usually of a fixed diameter) that enlarges the wellbore to a diameter equal to or less than the upper casing drift).  Compare to an under-reamer.
Step-wise internal cracks that connect hydrogen blisters.
In a subsea context, HWHR stands for hot water hydrate removal.
Partial or full collapse of the wellbore by particles of shale.
In the context of a reservoir, HCPV is hydrocarbon pore volume.
The body of rock that lies above an inclined fault plane.
Chlorine dioxide, a bacteria killer.
A specific sedimentary layer across a study plane.
The oldest eon in earth’s history.  Extends from the origin of earth to about 3.9 billion years ago.
A pipe end cut on a diagonal to ease the string through restrictions or guide tools through.
To close in a flowing well with the BOP with the choke line closed.

A subsea production tree with a horizontal valve arrangement to the side of the tubing hanger, permitting direct access to the tubing and tubing hanger without having to remove the tree during a workover.
Keeping an oil and gas lease in effect by producing the well.
An unplanned delayed firing of explosives after the initiation attempt - various causes.

A sand control operation in which gravel is injected into a well where a screen has been placed.  The pressure of the injection is usually at or near the fracture pressure of the reservoir and a pressure packing of all perforations ensues.  Some perf breakdown occurs.  The amount of gravel placed is about 40 to 75 lbs/ft of perfs. Abbreviated HRWP.
Hydraulic workover unit.
Hydrogen sulfide.
Layer thickness.
A mechanical device that suspends all or part of the weight from a tubular string, transferring the load to the well head and the earth.
The volume fraction of a specific fluid in the upward moving stream.
A toxic, corrosive, colorless gas with the characteristic smell of rotten eggs in low concentration.  An acid gas.
Hydroxyl propyl guar; a chemically modified guar.

Refers to soils grouped according to their runoff-producing charac teristics. The chief consideration is the inherent capacity of soil devoid of vegetation to permit infiltration. The slope and the kind of plant cover are not considered but are separate factors in predicting runoff. Soils are assigned to four groups. In group A are soils having a high infiltration rate when thoroughly wet and having a low runoff potential. They are mainly deep, well drained, and sandy or gravelly. In group D, at the other extreme, are soils having a very slow infiltration rate, and thus, a high runoff potential. They have (a) a claypan or clay layer at or near the sur face, (b) have a permanent high water table, or (c) are shallow over nearly impervious bedrock or other material. A soil is assigned to two hydrologic groups if part of the acreage is artificially drained and part is undrained.
To lift.  Also the equipment used to lift.
Hydraulic workover, usually working under pressure.  Some HWO units are set up with pipe handling capacity as are snubbing units.
Sodium chloride, NaCl.
A technique of injecting or circulating heated crude oil from the surface to help remove paraffin deposits.  It is usually only effective for shallow depths when circulated.

HFC stands for high frequency cycle, the smallest time-stratigraphic unit.  Also called parasequence, it is a unit composed of genetically related lithofacies deposited during one basic sea-level rise and fall.

High pressure, high temperature.  HPHT is where the undisturbed bottom hole temp at prospective reservoir depth or total depth is greater than 300oF or 150oC, and either the maximum anticipated pore pressure of any porous formation to be drilled through exceeds a hydrostatic gradient of 0.8 psi/ft, or a well requiring pressure control equipment with a rated working pressure in excess of 10000 psi.
A fracture creased by hydraulic pressure - usually intentional.
Hydrogenated nitrile (bunadiene rubber).
A tool that is set by hydraulic pressure.
A flow region in a near vertical well, in which rising fluid or gas hinders the fall rate of liquids of solids, enabling flow from the well.
Hydraulic multi-service valve.
In a seismic context, a high density basement is the deepest, thick, high density rock that serves as a density contrast in an area.
The well decomposed, more or less stable part of the organic matter in mineral soils. Hydraulic conductivity The rate at which water will move through soil under a unit hydraulic gradient.
A byproduct and precipitant of the HF – silica reaction.
Radial gap between the maximum rated casing ID and the minimum OD immediately adjacent to the packing element.
A subsurface interface marking an ancient erosional event that has removed portions of one or more stratigraphic units.  Typically abbreviated as ES.
The outside or continuous phase of an emulsion.
A well deviated above the pay to reach further from the drill site or further into the pay formation to expose my contact area with the pay zone. Abbreviated ERW.
The tendency of a body to return to its original shape and size once the stress is removed.
Elevation.
The snap-around latches that couple around tubing below the pipe coupling and enables the traveling block on a rig to grab and lift the tubular string.
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. http://www.epa.gov/
The primary division of geologic time -- from oldest to youngest - the Haldean, Archean, Proterozoic, and Phanerozoic.
In the context of hydraulics, equivalent hydraulic diameter is commonly written De.
Thermoplastic fluoropolymer.
A physical mixture of two or more immiscible phases.
Loss of volume due to removal of gasses or liquids during processing.

One of several techniques used to break the rock in the near well area.  It was an early stimulation method.  Fractures formed in this method are short. Although still used, its best application is in perf breakdown and overcoming some near well damage.
Ethylene diamene tetra acetic acid.
The maximum stress that a material can withstand for an infinitely large number of cycles (NACE).
An electrical powered rotating pump capable of lifting very large flow rates (>20,000 BPD). Abbreviated ESP.
Typically a resistivity log.

Wellbore tubulars run in like conventional completions but mechanically enlarged downhole once in place.  Can include combinations of sand screens, blank pipe and annular isolation seals used in lieu of gravel packs.
End of tubing.
Extreme overbalanced perforating.
Emergency shut-down valve.
Equivalent mud weight.
Formed by wind.
A wireline with a conductor in the middle and woven electrical braid over the conductor. Also called an e-line.
A division of geologic time, next shorter than the eon and larger than a period.
The total charge of the adsorption complex active in the adsorption of ions.
Echo Meter™ is the trademarked name for a commercial tool that measures the height of a fluid (or solid) level by means of a reflected sound wave.
A emulsion stabilizing mechanism, usually either surface active agent, fines, viscosity and/or charge.
Equivalents per million. The epm is equal to the ppm divided by the equivalent weight.
Proppant that has partly or completely sunk into a formation through displacement of the formation around the grain.
Error function.
Observed response, often well proven by experiences but not theoretically derived.
The bars that attach the elevators to the hook on the traveling block. Also called elevator links.

A chemical or physical effect that prevents separation of two or more, normally immiscible phases.  Normally surfactant, electrical charge, liquid or emulsion viscosity, or micron sized solids at the interface.
A two carbon chain alkene – double bonds between the carbons and a formula of C2H4.  A very common starting material for synthesis of various products.
A rubber or plastic material used as a seal. May occur naturally or be synthesized.
When the revenue from the produced fluids falls below the cost of operations set by the company.

The extent to which the adsorption complex of a soil is occupied by sodium. Amount of exchangeable sodium expressed as a percentage of total exchangeable cations. Refer to discussion under exchangeable cation percentage. It is ex pressed as follows: ESP= Exchangeable sodium (meq/1OOg soil) Cation exchange capac1.ty (meqI1OOg sol"I) x 100
Electrical submersible pump.
Extended reach well.
Ownership of part of the well.
A well drilled on the edge of the existing field that may extend the known area of the field.
Equilibrium step rate test.
A resin formed by reaction of polyols with epichlorohydrin.
The permeability of the formation matrix to a particular fluid when two or more phases are present.
A method of rock and fluid identification or evaluation that began in 1927. The first log was run by Conrad Schlumberger.
EGS or Enhanced Geothermal Systems involving the use of rock shearing or fracture stimulation technologies to connect an injection well to hot water production well to harvest heat at high rates.
An increase in length expressed numerically as a percent of initial length.
A gun made up of perforating charges linked together with wire or clips.  The debris is not recovered on the wireline run.
Worldwide sea-level changes affecting all oceans.  It is thought that eustatic sea-level changes can be linked to climatic changes and to eccentricities in the Earth's orbit.
Enhanced oil recovery.

Cations on cation exchange sites or in the soil solution that can participate in the cation exchange process in soil. The most common exchangeable cations in soils are calcium, magnesium, sodium, potassium, aluminum, and hydrogen. Other exchangeable cations include ammonium, iron, manganese, copper, zinc, and other positively charged dis solved ions in the soil. Exchangeable cations are in dynamic equilibrium between the soil solution and adsorption on cation exchange sites.
In the context of corrosion, an electromotive force series is a list of elements arranged according to their standard electrode potentials.
Commonly written E&P.
A device in a length of pipe that allows some pipe length expansion or contraction.
The theoretical radius of a wellbore that would flow the same rate as a wellbore with a fracture. Effective wellbore radius is a comparison of flow improvement related back to physical radius.
Equalizing prong.
Brittle fracture of a normally ductile material in which the corrosive effect of the environment is a cause (NACE).
Development of a producing reservoir.
A perforating gun with exposed charge capsules.

A gulf, basin or sea surrounded by two or more States and connected to another sea or the ocean by a narrow outlet or consisting entirely or primarily of the territorial seas and exclusive economic zones of two or more coastal States. PDF
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency National Response Center. http://www2.epa.gov/emergency-response/national-response-center

The titratable hydrogen and aluminum that can be replaced from the adsorption complex by a neutral salt solution. Usually expressed as milliequivalents per 100 grams of soil. Acidity in a soil is primarily the result of hydrogen ions (H+), aluminum ions (AI+3), and aluminum mono and di-hydroxide ions [AI(OH)+2 and AI(OH)2+1, respectively]. Because they have a positive electrical charge these ions participate in cation exchange reactions, and because they cause soil acidity they are called exchangeable acids. Exchangeable acidity is therefore the number of meq/100 grams of soil which consist of hydrogen, aluminum, and aluminum mono and di-hydroxide ions. The remainder of the cation change capacity would consist of exchangeable bases such as sodium, potassium, calcium, and magnesium. The role of aluminum ions in acidity is described in the definition of reserve acidity.
Commonly written E&A.
Reserves consistent with the cost recovery plus profit hydrocarbons that are recoverable under the terms of the contract or lease are typically reported by the upstream contractor (SPE).
A separation device that uses alternating current charged plates to help break emulsions.
Engineer in training.
In the context of sand control, ESS is expandable sand control screen.
Susceptible to erosion.
A general term covering the search for oil and gas.
A description of rock resulting from a magma breach to surface and exposed to atmospheric conditions during cooling.
Localized and subsurface corrosion in zones often parallel to the surface that result in leaving thin layers of uncorroded metal resembling the pages of a book.
Deformation of a body in the elastic range, i.e., recovery to the initial shape is possible when the stress or load is removed.
Equivalent mud weight.
External gravel pack.
One or more of a variety of processes that seek to improve recovery of hydrocarbon from a reservoir after the primary production phase.

Field instruments which sense the ability of the local surroundings, including soil, to conduct electricity by detecting resistance to induced electromagnetic radiation. Used to sense variations in soil EC within a field, but also responds to soil water content, porosity, type and amount of clay, electric power lines, and buried pipes.
A material that, when dissolved in water, causes or increases the fluids’ electrical conductivity.
Electronic Gas Measurements.
