The equivalent mud weight felt by the formation when circulating with a certain mud weight and holding a backpressure.  A 10 lb/gal mud in a 10,000 ft well with 1000 psi backpressure would generate an equivalent mud weight of about 11.9 lb/gal.
A combination hanger and packer run like conventional hangers for drilling liners and well completions but permanently mechanically expanded once in the well.
Interconnected, drainable porosity.
EZSV™ is the trademarked name for a drillable bridge plug.
An “L” shaped fitting in surface piping.
Chemical reactions that gives off heat.
Gas dispersed in a produced fluid.
A thread with 8 threads per inch.
In a subsea context, EXHT™ is the trademarked name for an enhanced horizontal tree.
In the context of elastomers, ED stands for explosive decompression.
In a subsea context, EVXT-BD in an enhanced vertical tree, dual bore.
Environmental impact statement.
The effective fluid density that the formation sees when the friction pressure on the fluids returning to surface is added to the fluid density.
A formation formed by the evaporation of water from shallow seas.  Very low permeability.

A stream which flows only in direct response to precipitation in the immediate watershed or in response to the melting of a cover of snow and ice, and which has a channel bottom that is always above the local water table.
A pipe connection with a thicker connection body than the pipe body.  In an external upset, the thickness is offset to the outside diameter. Abbreviated EUE or EU.
Electric line measured depth.
A reaction that absorbs heat.
Corrosion acceleration by passage of a high velocity flow or impingement of solids.  May remove the thin, protective oxide film that protects exposed metal surface.
The amount of cement over that required to cement the zone.  Usually between 30% and 100% depending on hole diameter unknowns and contamination risk.

In a seismic context, euler method is a profile or map-based depth estimation method based on a concept that magnetic fields of structures are homogeneous functions of depth and location. This is used to satisfy Euler’s equation.
Decentralization of pipe in the hole. 100% eccentric is against the hole wall.
In the context of BP, ETP is engineering technical standards.
A wildcat or well in a new area with unknown producing potential.
A device that through flow of a power fluid through a nozzle, creates a low pressure area useful for moving fluids.
Commonly written EL&P.
In a subsea context, EVXT™ is the trademarked name for an enhanced vertical tree.
A form of financial option that requires that the purchase be made on the exercise date; expected value.

An equivalent weight of an ion or salt per 1 million grams of solution or soil. For solutions, equivalents per million (e.p.m.) and milliequivalents per liter (meq/L) are numerically identical if the specific gravity of the solution is 1.0 as it is for freshwater at 20°C.

A method of applying a very high pressure surge to the formation at the instant of perforating.  Usually in excess of 1.4 psi/ft.  Designed to overcome frac initiation pressure and break down each perf with a very short (<1 m) frac.
In thermodynamics and phase behavior, extensive properties depend on the amount of the phases (e.g., total volume and moles of liquid).  See also intensive.

Water at the sides or edges of the hydrocarbon deposit. Often causes problems because the channels that deplete the fastest are the highest permeability and water production through them can be severe.  These respond well to treatment if they can be isolated.
A rubber bladder over a section of casing that is inflated, usually with cement, to give an annular seal in open hole sections.  Frequently used with liners and set at intervals along the open hole.
Complimentary error function = 1 - erf(x).
Conductivity measured directly in reciprocal units of resistance and reported in mmhos/cm. EC is an indirect measure of total dissolved solids (TDS).
The upper range of elasticity, just before the body is permanently deformed.
Extended reach drilling.
Ethyl alcohol.
In a subsea context, EVXT-SB is an enhanced vertical tree, single bore.

In the context of risk, an expected value is the weighted average using probabilities as weights.  For decisions involving uncertainty, the concept of expected value provides a rational means for selecting the best course of action and for forecasting portfolio level performance.
Filtration control established on the surface of the wellbore by particles large enough to bridge on the entry of the pores.
That number of the perforations that are open and flowing.
In the context of computers, ethernet is a local area network protocol standard defined by IEEE 802.3.
A pipe cut-off tool composed of linear shaped charge that is designed to sever pipe.  Works on the same principle as a perforating charge.
External casing packer.
A part of a plug that allows equalization of the pressures above and below a plug.
Remaining life.

The extent to which the adsorption complex of a soil is occupied by a particular cation. The proportion (in percent) of the total cation exchange capacity of a soil (at a given pH) which is satisfied by a given species of cation at a given point in time. The exchangeable cations are determined by displacing them with a concentrated solution consisting of a different type of cation. The type and quantity of displaced cations are collected and measured in the laboratory. The resulting data give both the cation exchange capacity and the relative cation percentages. For example, if 8 meq calcium, 4 meq potassium, 4 meq sodium, 1 meq aluminum, 1 meq magnesium, 1 meq ammonium, and 1 meq of other miscellaneous cations were displaced by cation exchange from 100 grams of soil, then the cation exchange capacity would be 20 milliequivalents per 100 grams of soil, and relative exchange able cation percentages would be 40, 20, 20, 5, 5, 5, and 5, respectively. It is expressed as follows

The geosciences, engineering, and associated studies, including economic analyses, conducted on a petroleum exploration, development, or producing project resulting in estimates of the quantities that can be recovered and sold and the associated cash flow under defined forward conditions. (Also called assessment.)
Eddy current measurement for wall thickness in corrosion and wear determination.
In the context of brine, eutectic is a mixture of substances having a minimum solidification/melting point.
Cement with additives that promote volumetric cement expansion.
A mechanical, chemical or explosive device that is lowered over a pipe to cut from the outside.

Anions on anion exchange sites or in the soil solution that can participate in the anion exchange process in soil. The most common exchangeable anions in the soils are chloride, sulfate, bicarbonate, and carbonate. Exchangeable anions are in dynamic equilibrium between the soil solution and adsorption on anion exchange sites.
The low and high range (wt %) of a combustible gas mixed in air that can be ignited at ambient pressure and temperature.
Electromagnetic propagation tool.  Measures propagation time and attenuation rate of microwave energy through the formation.  Helps distinguish between oil and water.
A time division of geologic time next shorter than a period.
Equation of state.
End of build (horizontal wellbore).
See electrical line.
Electric line coiled tubing unit.
A two carbon chain alkane, C2H6. A gas under standard conditions of temperature and pressure.
Emergency shut-down.
A rapid reduction in pressure that may cause trapped gas to try to break out of rubber/elastomer seals and ruin the seals. Common at the surface but uncommon downhole.
A choke capable of handling high solids content flow.  The external sleeve is moved over a perforated hub with high erosion resistance properties.
Breaker in small pill-form particles that stays with the polymer and helps break the mud cake.

A geostatistical linear-regression technique that uses a secondary regionalized variable (e.g., a seismic attribute) to control the shape of the final map created by kriging or simulation. External drift uses a spatial model of covariance.
A geological epoch from 38 million to 55 million years.
The kriging variance at each grid node. This is a measure of global reliability, not a local estimation of error.
EconoProp™ is a trademarked name for an inexpensive light weight ceramic (man made) proppant.
Ethylene glycol mono-butyl ether. A mutual solvent.
The loss of water from a soil by evaporation and plant transpiration.
Corrosion potential.
Well construction tubulars run in like conventional casing but mechanically enlarged downhole before the cement is set.  Used mostly as drilling liners to isolate unstable intervals.
In a subsea context, EDP stands for emergency disconnect package.
In the context of wirelines, ES stands for equalizing sleeve.
The fluids and solids, perhaps in a mixed stream, produced from a well.
A facility for removal of liquids from gas.
A fatigue state of metal that may be caused by trapping atomic hydrogen in the structure of the steel.  Characterized by loss of ductility. May also be caused by work hardening or other factor.
Expected ultimate recovery from a field.
Electromotive force. The force that drives electrons and creates an electric current.
Non-permanent structural deformation during which the amount of deformation (strain) is proportional to the applied stress (load).
A flex joint in a tool string that allows alignment with a target not in the same plane. Abbreviated KJ.
Kelly bushing on a rig with a rotary table.  A depth datum.
A highly chemically modified carbonate.
Kick-off point.
Kinley Caliper™ is the trademarked name of a multi-finger caliper for determining casing ID condition.
A kill line port located between the shear ram and the slip ram on a BOP.
The permeability times the height; a measure of formation conductivity.
Kill pill.
KALREZ™ is the trademarked name of a brand for a high temperature seal.
The density of a full column of fluid when the density of that fluid is just high enough to prevent pore fluid flow.

A naturally occurring, solid, insoluble, organic material that occurs in source rocks and can yield Oil, Gas, Helium and Hydrogen oil upon heating under pressure. Kerogen is also defined as the fraction of large chemical aggregates in sedimentary organic matter that is insoluble in solvents (in contrast, the fraction that is soluble in organic solvents is called bitumen).
Liptinite has a high hydrogen to carbon ratio and a low oxygen to carbon ratio. Oil prone with a high yield – up to 80%. From algal sources. Somewhat rare.
An unwanted flow of fluids from a formation into the wellbore. Can happen during drilling, completions or interventions.
The valve on the Kelly.

A out of round bore hole worn to the side, often with the side of the drill pipe in a crooked hole, that looks like a key hole.  Keyseats create problems with passage of tool joints and larger pipe that does not bend as easily as smaller diameter pipe.
Key performance indicator.
A downhole valve in the tubing string used to isolate the string and allow a kill without having fluid on the formation.
The gas injection pressure available for unloading fluids from a gas lifted well down to the last valve.

In a seismic context, a kringing is the geostatistical method of applying known values in one sample to produce an unbiased estimate of values in another by using a linear combination of weights obtained from a model of spatial correlation. Kriging is the univariate version of cokriging.
A separator used to remove easily removed or excess gas or water from the produced fluid stream.
The point at which a rapid change of deviation is made in a vertical well.
A medium range (C9-C16), straight chain blend of hydrocarbons.  Flash point is about 60oC (140oF). Boiling point is 174o to 288oC.  Density is 0.747 to 0.775 g/cc.

In a viscosity context, K is the consistency index, is the shear stress or viscosity of the fluid at one sec-1 shear rate.  An increasing K raises the effective annular viscosity, increases hole cleaning capacity.
In a drilling context, kwn is kill weight mud.
Vitrinite has a low hydrogen to carbon and high oxygen to carbon ratio.Low quality gas prone with low yields. Source is wood and high order plant debris. Coal precursor.
The ratio of the viscosity to the density using consistent units.  Same behavior as in a Marsh Funnel.
Potassium chloride salt.
Kilopascal, 6.9 kPa per psi, 1000 psi = 6900 kPa.
The bushing that directly transmits torque from the rotary table to the kelly.
A pill with fluid loss control materials selected to stop losses in the well. A kill weight pill is a fluid with a density high enough to control the well.
One thousand metric tons.
1000 barrels per day.
A fishing tool that decentralizes the retrieving tool.  Commonly used in gas lift.
A liquid with a density sufficient so that a full column of the fluid would control the well and prevent fluid entry into the wellbore from any exposed formation.
An inhibitor that prevents solid hydrate plugs.
Storm Choke.
About a BTU (British thermal unit).  Used to express the heat content of gas.
Vertical permeability.
KEVLAR™ is the trademarked name of an extremely strong fiber, common in composites.

The square or hexagonal rotating shaft on a drilling rig that receives torque from the kelly bushing rotary table and transfers it to the drillstring. (Not used where a Top drive is used to turn the string).
kPa, 1000 Pascal, 6.9 kPa per psi, 1000 psi = 6900 kPa.
1000 liters per day.
A term used to describe various methods to stop flow from a well.  Commonly pumping a kill weight fluid into a well to create an overbalance into the formation.
Inertinite very low in hydrogen, principally a dead carbon.
Kilogram, 1000 grams.
Kerr McGee.
A source rock in with sufficient heat and other inputs to produce hydrocarbons.
Flow lines to the BOP stack, entering below the pipe rams, through which kill weight fluids can be pumped.
In the context of a process, a kuff is the partly broken emulsion layer between water and oil in a separator.
Kick over tool.
Potassium formate.
Exinite has an intermediate hydrogen to carbon and oxygen to carbon ratio. Oil and gas prone with yields of 40 to 60%. From plant sources.

One of three common goodness-of-fit metrics used when fitting probability distributions to data (the others being the chi-square and Anderson-Darling), which uses numerical integration but otherwise is similar to the chi-square test.
A statistic that measures peakedness of a density function. A normal curve has kurtosis of 0.
See Estimation variance.
Geophone.
In the context of a platform, a jacket is the steel support structure from the sea floor to the top sides.
Joint operating agreement.
Job safety analysis.
A pin and groove assembly that keeps a tool in the unset position while running and then can be worked or “Jayed” to operate the tool.  Common in retrievable packers and liner hangers.
Junk basket.
A nozzle through which fluid is pumped to produce an impact force.  Used in jetting tools and bits.  These nozzle often have a designed shape to maximize impact.
A profile design (less common than F, S, and X).  The F allows circulation with the annulus.  Used in place of a sliding sleeve, but does present a restriction.
In the context of a connection, a joint is the tubular connection.
JRC™ is the trademarked name for the Jet Research Center.
The probability that both of two events, say A and B, will occur in symbols P(A&B).
A device run on slickline, coiled tubing, tubing or drill pipe that will sharply increase the impact force of the conveyance when trying to retrieve a stuck tool or equipment.
A type of mixer for cement that uses air pressure to propel the dry cement into the flowing water.
A radial shaped charge (explosive) cutter for pipe.
A hydraulic tool used in combination with a jar to increase the impact of the jar on the fish.
Injecting fluid at high pressure against a target, often with fluid focused through a nozzle tool.
A rough, sturdy mill for grinding up odd shaped materials in the well.
In the context of a beam lift, a jack is usually a pump jack, operating the rods in a lift and fall motion.
In the context of a drilling rig, a jerk line is a cable from the tongs through a pulley in the mast and to the cat head.
An offshore rig with retractable steel legs that can be placed on the ocean floor and raise the rig above the water line.
A project in which two or more parties are involved. Funding may be in direct money or work-in-kind.

The intersection of the lateral and the mother-bore when two or more laterals are drilled in a multilateral well, or when a single kick-off lateral is drilled from a vertical well.  The junction may be unsealed or sealed and may or may not hold pressure.
A bearing on a rotating shaft.
In the context of gas, JT stands for Joule Thompson.

When a real (not ideal) gas expands, the temperature of the gas drops. During passage of a gas through a choke, the internal energy is transferred to kinetic energy with a corresponding reduction in temperature as velocity increases.  The effect for natural gas is approximately 7o F for every 100 psi pressure reduction.
A rig with a folding mast that can be lowered and raised relatively quickly.
A mixer that introduces additives to a moving fluid stream though use of the low pressure formed with fluid passage through a nozzle.  An “on-the-fly” mixing device.
The symbol J is commonly used to express productivity index and is the preferred symbol of the Society of Petroleum Engineers.
A device with nozzles and a basket or catch basin to catch smaller pieces of junk stirred up by circulation. May also be called a Jet Basket.
Debris in the well.
